I thanked her and asked her should we grab our luggage out of the room, as we were going to the World Market, and wouldn't be back until 4:00pm, She said no problem, I will have the room ready for you when you come back, and @ that time we will take your luggage to the next room, again, I thanked her for her help. Well my wife and I come back to Aria, again @ the Invited guest service. Toney was already off for the day, and we were greeted by a guy named Anthony, I explained to him that we were changing rooms, and Toney had a new room reserved for us, he immediatley ask what room we had and he said oh you have a great room, why would you want to change, between my wife and I we tryed to expalin everything that happened, but he didn't care, he kept repeating that Toney had no business giving us our new room, remember this is my wife's birthday, and he is making her feel pretty low by now, he then preceded in telling us he is going to get the manager, I said great, I would love to talk to your manager, I have owned a service business for over 30 yrs, and this guy would be fired in a heart beat, in the way he was treating us!! The manager came over, and introduced her self as Gabby, she went on to tell us they had no rooms to give us, Tuesday night in Vegas, in a Recession, ya right. Se was just as rude as Anthony, and I preceded to let her know we would like to cancel our last two nights, she said we need to go to our room first to grab our luggage, because our keys would not work, if she cancel right then. We preceded to go to our room, got our luggage, My wife called down talked to Gabby, and Gabby all of a sudden bagged us to stay, and out of no where she had another room for us. Needless to say, we did not accept her offer, she had already destroyed my wife's birthday plans. We travel a lot, and this is the WORST EXPERIENCE we have ever had. Do not recommned this place @ all!!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent”
Reviews.Author: truetous
Reviews.Content: Excellent hotel on the Strip. Very comfortably located. Easy access to public transport. Hotel interiors very well done up. Concierge was very knowledgeable and reception handled check in well inspite of there being a large crowd. Large casino. Lots of tour options. Show tickets can be booked through concierge. Hotel food was avrage though. But given the number of food options in the vicinity, this is not much of an issue.

Reviews.Title: “DON'T pay for "strip view"... no such thing with Aria”
Reviews.Author: Luv2GetAway23
Reviews.Content: Matt and I stayed at Aria from July 28th through August 2nd. We reserved a Deluxe Strip View room (king size bed). We were able to check in right away and our room was on the 24th floor. The room and amenities were very nice but after the 3 LARGE buildings they built for the City Center RIGHT IN FRONT of Aria... there is NO STRIP VIEW. Yes, the room would face the strip but you can barely see the lights. We were extemely disappointed. The idea of City Center is that you would not have to leave the "resort" but the truth is that even though you might get a great rate on the room everything else is extremely expensive. We ended up hanging out at the other hotels on the strip everyday just for that reason. If you are a normal income couple going away for the weekend... check out somewhere else. This place was very nice but doesn't necessarily fit what a young fun couple is looking for for value + fun. OH! by the way.. for what you pay for the room ... the Wi-Fi is extra! Try New York New York, Ceaser's, Bellagio, or Palms...

Reviews.Title: “Bad reservations policy, dirty room”
Reviews.Author: Aqua52
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Aria August 1-4, 2010. On June 1, I made our reservation for a non-smoking room with two queen beds. I fully paid for the first night. When we checked in on Sunday, August 1st at around 5:30 p.m., we were told that we couldn't have a room with two beds. I questioned this, since I had reserved two beds and paid for the room two months prior. The man at the counter, who was named James, told me that according to their policy, our reservation was only a request and was not guaranteed! I explained to him that my husband has chronic severe back pain and terrible insomnia and that there was no way we could share a bed. After several minutes of discussion, James offered to have an extra twin bed put into our room. At this point, I had no other options, so I accepted his offer. One of Aria's main selling points for their rooms is their wonderfully comfortable beds. Unfortunately, even though I had a fully-paid reservation made two months in advance, I never got to sleep in one of those comfortable beds. James told me that the only way you can be sure to get a room with two beds at Aria is to make a reservation for four people, which adds $70 per night to the cost of your room. Even if I were traveling with my father, they would expect me to share a bed with him. What about if two straight guys are traveling together and are sharing a room to reduce their costs? At Aria, they might have to sleep in the same bed. I think it's important for people to realize this. I know that I will never stay at Aria again, even though there were things that we liked, because of this policy. I paid for a room that they gave to someone else and received an inferior room with absolutely no concessions made to us. And to top it all off, it was a smoking room, complete with an ash tray that hadn't even been cleaned after the previous guests left. We also had to endure three nights of smoke coming under the door from the adjoining room, since apparently our next door neighbors were smokers. Once again, Aria displayed complete disregard for our reservation. Not everything was bad, however. We had paid the additional charge for a deluxe view room, and it was nice, although nothing compared to what we've had before at Bally's, Monte Carlo, and even Excalibur. We were able to see the City Center complex, New York New York, and the MGM sign, although not the hotel. The technology in the room was fun, although we stood in a dark room for five minutes when we first arrived until we could turn on the lights. Forget their comments on the website about the curtains opening and the TV turning on to welcome you to the room. Nothing like that happened for us. The bathroom was large and functional, although without an exhaust fan, it was warm and humid all day long. The dressing area was nice, but it would have been much nicer with a mirror over the counter instead of a painting and some handy electric outlets. One other thing that has totally turned me off to the Aria is that soon after we arrived in the room, we noticed blood on the window right in front of the chairs. We cleaned it off ourselves with a wash cloth and then disinfected the area with hand sanitizer. That, along with the dirty ash tray and hair all over the bathroom floor by the toilet made us realize that our room was probably not nearly as clean as we would like it to be. Even though each room has it's own temperature control, it took two days of constantly running the A/C and keeping our curtains closed to get our room down to 72 degrees. Many times it was cooler in the hall than it was in our room. The tram that runs by the Aria is very convenient, and we were excited about using it. We rode it to the Bellagio several times and loved this amenity. However, when we first tried to locate it, we were extremely disappointed to discover that two Aria employees blatantly lied to us in an effort to get us to spend more time in their casino. We had watched the tram from our window the night before and knew that it made a stop on the north end of Aria. We left our hotel room and headed towards that end of the resort. When we were almost to the lobby, we asked an employee where to get on the tram, and she said we had to walk all the way through the casino to the south end of the resort to get on the tram at the Monte Carlo stop. I pointed out to her that the website said the tram stopped at Aria, and she said no, we had to walk to the other stop. We did as she suggested and stopped shortly to ask another employee, who also directed us to the tram stop on the south end. Once we got on the tram and rode it north to Bellagio, we discovered that the tram did indeed stop right where we thought it did, and we were, in fact, very close to that stop when the employee told us to head in the opposite direction. It became obvious to us that the employees were instructed to direct guests to the more distant tram stop, because that insured that they would walk through the entire casino and hopefully stop to gamble along the way. As I mentioned earlier, my husband deals with significant back pain, and we didn't appreciate the long, unnecessary walk that we were subjected to by a resort policy that forces their employees to lie to their guests. We ate at the buffet, but I'll put that in a separate review under restaurants. I will say that the pools were a highlight of our stay. There are three beautiful pools, and we had no trouble at all getting lounge chairs each afternoon. The pool area was very clean and the water was the perfect temperature. We really felt that the pools and surrounding area were the nicest we've experienced at an Las Vegas hotel. The maids were very slow in cleaning the rooms. There were many rooms that still had their service lights lit at 6 p.m. each day. We were surprised that our maid saw us leave our room one morning because she was working right next door, and yet when we returned to our room three hours later, it had still not been serviced. The internet is $15 a day in your room, but they don't advertise that. I had to call them to find out. Also, the signs along the strip aren't very good. I believe one employee we talked to use the word "atrocious". Our first attempt at finding the self parking led us to the back of the hotel. I assume the signs will improve once the construction is completed. The elevators were very efficient. That's quite an accomplishment, considering how many guest rooms there are. If you are lucky enough to get the room you reserved at Aria and have it be clean, you will probably have a pleasant stay there. The architecture is breathtaking, and the TV and other technology in the room were very enjoyable. Unfortunately, their very poor reservations policy will prevent us from staying there again.

Reviews.Title: “Great new addition to Vegas”
Reviews.Author: msmall
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at Aria from July 25th-27th. We had already been in Las Vegas for 4 nights staying at the Vdara, as we were in Vegas for him to attend a conference. Before coming to Vegas we decided that the last two nights of our stay we would like to stay at a hotel with a casino. We got a great rate at Vdara with some free slot play and decided we would give it a try. It was a very nice hotel. Everything was as expected - new, modern, trendy, etc. We had two free buffets each day but only used it on the first day. I was particularly anxious to try the crab legs and found them tasty, I just did not prefer them cold. I was told by the wait staff that I could take them up to the kitchen staff and they would be glad to warm them for me but it just seemed like such a bother. The cheesecake, however, was simply divine. The staff at Aria were exceptionally pleasant and courteous. Anytime we had a question about anything, staff were readily available and seemed more than happy to give us an answer. The valet service was a little slower than we had been accustomed to at Vdara but then Aria is a much larger hotel so that is to be expected. All-in-all I would definitely stay at Aria again. I am very, very picky when it comes to the places I stay (almost to the point of paranoia) in terms of cleanliness and comfort and I was more than pleased with my stay at Aria, and I suspect I will be staying there in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Everything you need to know about Aria.”
Reviews.Author: TSLive
Reviews.Content: Let me start off by saying that I am not a person that needs to be pampered. I've gone to Vegas once per year for the past 6 years. I've stayed (in order) at Excalibur, Imperial Palace, Imperial Palace (again), Paris, MGM Grand, and Aria - the latest being for March Madness with my girlfriend, my friend and his wife. I will no longer stay at the budget places such as the IP but I am big on keeping the fixed costs to a minimum. Here are the bullet points of all you need to know vs. what everyone else wrote - I'll save my complaint (a big one) for the end in case you don't want to read my whining! - Massive hotel with a lot of empty space. - Yes it's a dark casino but it is not a big deal. - I had no problem with the remote control or the maid service as some have cited. - The beds ARE great. - I attended the brunch buffet and it wasn't the Bellagio, but it was good. We ate at nice restaurants outside of City Center because frankly the value didn't seem to be there. - The mall (Crystals) is nice but upscale - you often cut through on your walk to Aria. - You walk almost as far to the tram as to walking to the Bellagio or Monte Carlo directly. - Yes you have to walk through the casino floor dragging your luggage to get to the elevators. - The slots, table games, and poker room are all good not great. I want to say $15 minimum blackjack. - Anyone that wrote on here "the slots are tight"... well, let's just say don't let their poor luck sway your judgement. - Check-in is absolutely and utterly the worst that has ever existed at any hotel in the entire world! It takes people 15 minutes to check in and the lines are random. It's really a customer service, hotel check-in and complaint center all rolled into one. Now here's my inexcusable experience: - We have 4 people (2 couples) in a room so we require 2 double queen beds. I had read on trip advisor MANY people saying they ordered 2 queens to be stuck into 1 king bed. I couldn't let this happen with 4 people and would pay $100 more to be certain this wouldn't happen. So I took steps... 1) I called to confirm the two double queens. It can't be guaranteed but I needed it to be. They said Iw ould get the two queens. 2) I called the conceirge and explained I was thinking of switching to another hotel because I didn't have confidence they would honor our two double queens since my flight was arriving late (11pm Friday night). I received a response "please don't change your reservation, you can be absolutely certain that we will do everything in our power to ensure you have a pleasant stay and we understand the two beds is part of that. I printed this email and brought them with me. So we get there around 11:45pm. Took FIFTY minutes to get to the receptionist. Sure enough, sorry we need to put you in a king room. I was so aggravated. I showed them the email and how I predicted this whole thing. Had to wait 15 minutes for the manager, and in the meantime the receptionist can't help anyone else. Gridlock! I am pretty good at negotiating in cases like this and not just being a jerk about everything. Here's what I was able to muster.... still inadequate, and let me tell you it took a lot of conversation to get this far. - We would get two separate king-bed rooms for the night. They would charge us $109 additional for the second room and I could do nothing to get out of this. I got a lousy $50 food credit I used on the buffet. Then, after a fight, basically, I got them to guarantee we get a double-queen room tomorrow by 12pm or else we stay in the separate rooms with that 2nd room comped for the remaining two nights. Sure enough, they had our room ready by 11am. After an exhausting flight from Boston, I look at my watch and it's 1:20am. That's right folks, ONE HOUR and FORTY minutes to check in and pay an extra $109 than our agreed upon rates. So, yeah, I'll let you decide for yourself. For myself, I will never stay at Aria again simply for the reason that Vegas hotels are so competitively prices and I keep getting comp room offers from Harrah's casinos. Good luck MGM, no wonder your company is in shambles. On another note, here's a rating of all the Vegas shows I've seen: LOVE - 10 out of 10 (best show in Vegas, in my opinion) KA - 8 out of 10 O - 7 out of 10 (my fiance would give it a 10) Carrot Top - 9 out of 10 David Copperfield - 9 out of 10 Lance Burton - 8 out of 10 Mac King - 8 out of 10 Amazing Jonathan - 8 out of 10 V Variety - 3 out of 10. Free tickets from friend, no wonder they were free! Dave Matthews Band at MGM Grand - 9 out of 10!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful hotel and service”
Reviews.Author: jooxo
Reviews.Content: Spent a week at this hotel. Had a fab time. The very latest---electric curtains etc. Great buffet breakfast. Found the resturants a little pricey--ok if you're winning! Had to pay for internet which I thought for a hotel of this rating was mean.

Reviews.Title: “very nice”
Reviews.Author: lc932004
Reviews.Content: my wife and i stayed here aug. 2 for three nights, i read alot of the reviews on here before going as i switched to the aria from the wynn because of their stupid resort fee's. so reading alot of the negitive on here i was questioning if i made a good choice or not. so we got to vegas monday at 11am we went and had lunch and went to aria to check in. we waited about 2 mins in line and checked in with no problem. the girl behind the desk was very nice. we went up to our room on the 24th floor and the room was very clean and just very nice overall. i had zero complaints. we also saw the elivis show and it was great too. soo do yourself a favor and go stay at the aria you wont be dissipointed.

Reviews.Title: “Modern amenities, great design”
Reviews.Author: Archer11
Reviews.Content: We really enjoyed staying at Aria! The rooms were super modern and practical - loved the bathroom and the plush beds. The walk to the room was quite long, but we got used to it after a while. We were a little disappointed that we didn't get the door opening experience with the drapes and music, but not the end of the world. Food was expensive but not outrageous. Discovered a little food court between the Monte Carlo and Aria that had fast food and Starbucks, which helped to save money. Lemongrass (Thai restaurant) was good and they will make a dish to your specs if you don't see your favorite on the menu. The train between Monte Carlo, Aria and the Bellagio seemed pretty pointless because it was faster to walk most of the time. Overall, a good experience and we would definitely stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Service needs to be improved”
Reviews.Author: pammcgarry
Reviews.Content: I have to agree with other comments. The reason I did not give this a better review is the poor service. Due to the fault of the hotel we were forced to move after 2 nights of our 4 night stay. We got minimal help with the move and were still expected to help carry our bags. This took an hour away from our visit. They did upgrade our room (only to the next level) but it would not have hurt them to give us a bottle of wine or a snack plate. The next morning, I emerged from the shower to find out that the hair dryer was missing. I was getting ready to go out with my son who lives in Vegas and was in a hurry but an hour later, I still did not have a hair dryer. Again it was their mistake but they just didn't care. They told me they would bring up a dryer when they had a chance. Not acceptable service. Checking out was slow and their solution was to place someone in the line to tell everyone they did not really have to go to the desk to checkout. Well there are circumstances when you do not trust them to get the bill right so you have to stand in line. This is one of those times. Yes this is a beautifully designed hotel and the rooms are to die for especially now with all the deals, but they will not build a good reputation, if their service remains to be poor.

Reviews.Title: “GREAT stay at a GREAT hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Zacura
Reviews.Content: This hotel was awesome. Very contemporary design, but still very comfortable. We got upgraded (for free) to a corner suite for our anniversary, which was a nice surprise. I suspect they did this b/c it was relatively empty compared to the other big hotels/casinos/shopping centers that we visited (like Cesar's and Belagio), but we were fine with that! I suspect it's kind of empty in the casino (again, fine with me) because all of the shopping isn't open just yet, but it's going to be every bit as nice as Cesar's Forum when everything is open... My wife does the shopping, so I wan't bothered at all. The pools (all three) were pretty damn nice. Lots of tall palms. Seems like they would have made one of them adult only, but it the back one had almost no kids every day were were there, so it wasn't a big deal. On our first night, after we went out for dinner, the guest services manager had them take chocolate covered strawberries and coconut pastries to our room. They were delicious. Another GREAT surpise. The only things I can complain about: (1) the wi-fi wasn't free once we had to "downgrade" from our corner suite to the regular room. (We decided to stay an additional night, but they wouldn't let us have the corner suite at the AWESOME $109 a night that we were paying -- it was supposed to be $325 a night. So we moved to what they call the deluxe room facing to the west, away from the strip. It was $129, but still very well worth it. We stayed on the 52nd story. ASK FOR THE TOP! Great views, even without the Strip!) I know you don't go to Vegas to use Internet, but we had to use it for some school/work issues. If it's free at a $69 Best Western, the City Center can spring for it, too. (2) The best, while very plush, was too soft and the down top was very hot... However, given the fact that you can control the air (and curtains, TV, radio and everything else) from a remote next to the bed made it easy to turn the air down to 60. I got my wife a massage at the spa, and she loved it. Spend the money, fellas. It's worth it. All in all, we had friendly service at a great value. Check it out!

Reviews.Title: “Good first impression”
Reviews.Author: cmrVancouver
Reviews.Content: First impression of Aria was very nice. There was a staff member near the check-in who was directing visitors to the appropriate desk. There was hardly any wait and we were checked-in and up in our room within 10 minutes. The reservation included an upgrade to a City View and we had requested 2 queen beds. Walked in and were greeted by name on the screen and the blackout drapes opening. Room 12-026 was exactly what we had requested, however, it wasnt much of a view as reported previously about the City View rooms . We also found that it was a LOOONG walk to our room and we really couldn't see us doing it every day. A call to the Front Desk to ask for a room higher up and closer to the elevator and they quickly and pleasantly changed our room. However, they could not provide us with 2 queens, so we decided we would just a share a king bed. The room key was changed automatically and the new room 16-054 was much better. It was only 6 doors down from the elevators, but we never heard anything from either the hallway or our neighbors. Rooms are very luxurious although the electronic gadgetry takes some getting used to. Rooms have 2 wardrobes with plenty of hangers each. There were also robes and plenty of towels. In fact, we liked the robes so much, that I bought one to bring home ($60 at Elements downstairs). Bed is extremely plush and soft which we thought would be a problem as we both prefer a harder mattress, but we both agreed that we had never slept better. Also, the safe is not apparent and I would not have known where to look if I had not read in TA previously that it was the bottom drawer of the nightstand. Mini-fridge is fully stocked and very expensive ($8 for large bottle of Fiji water... ouch!). Decided we would just buy anything we needed elsewhere. The pool was very nice and not crowded at all and no towel games were played. We found the best place was the pool on the right hand side which had both shade from the hotel and umbrellas. There were plenty of servers and prices weren't too ridiculous $14 for a 12 oz drink. Cafe Breeze at the pool had a good selection and was reasonable. I played some slots, but found they weren't really paying out, although that was true of all the casinos. I did get a couple of good payouts at Venetian and Bill's but they were the exception. The one thing I found missing, but didn't realize it until after I had been to the Bellagio, is that there is nowhere to sit down either in the lobby or elsewhere in the hotel outside of the lounges and restaurants. The Bellagio has small tables and chairs spread out throughout the main floor which allow for conversation and a rest for your feet. I would return to the Aria if I got a good rate, but I will probably try another hotel such as the Bellagio as I could have gotten it for the same price at the time I travelled.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous Hotel”
Reviews.Author: PaulaK13
Reviews.Content: The new Aria was outstanding. The staff was always nearby and willing to help. Rooms excellent, and the bathroom set-up was the best I have ever enountered. Securoty at the elevators needed to see you key in order to even get upstairs. Casino was clean, not smokey like one might expect. Meeting rooms were great.

Reviews.Title: “What a shame! Great room, bad service.. stay elsewhere”
Reviews.Author: AmericaninPT
Reviews.Content: I was eager to try the Aria, having watched the City Center under construction. I walked through it in January, so decided to pay the premium room rate and see just how nice it could be. What a disappointment! I had made my reservation months before online and when we arrived around 10 pm there were long lines to check in. There was no organizatioin as some lines moved quickly and others did not. Unfortunately I was in one that did not. When some officious looking woman in uniform came over, I thought she was going to do something, but instead she shyly told us to not congregate but make sure we were in line. Thanks. The gentleman in front of me apparently had some issue that required several trips to a stern manager, who kept shaking his head no. I would've appreciated it if the manager would have stepped in, dealt with the guy and thus sped up the line! Very quickly I was becoming unimpressed. When I finally made it to the desk clerk, I got a half hearted greeting, and when I asked what that was all about (as in you are aware I've been waiting now 20 minutes for him to finish) she quickly replied "sorry he wanted to change his room." Then she tells me that they are booked and can't give me the Deluxe room I reserved (and consequently paid for) but one on a much lower "smoking optional" (come on smoking optional???) floor. She'd even take $50 off the rate. Not just no but heck no. I could have and would have stayed at the Palazzo, the Bellagio, Planet Hollywood or any other hotel on the Strip for that price. Which is what I'll do next time. Smoking optional? What does that mean but it's a smoking floor? Shame shame shame. So discussions with another "manager" and instead of two beds we can get one in a "deluxe room" which I should've have been offered to begin with! I had wasted already and hour of what was a brief visit to Las Vegas so I asked for a late check out and was told no. Housekeeping knocked on our door at 9 am. That will teach me not to set the "privacy" switch! I am not what the purpose of knocking was really because either the room was vacant or we didn't want to be disturbed, in all places Las Vegas at 9 am! The view was great -- if not exactly as depicted online. The room was cool but by then I was too tired to mess with all the gadgets. I liked that we could hook up our iPods to the sound system and the bed was unbelievably comfortable. The bathroom was nice. I wish I had better things to say about our stay. Check out was efficient, and I got a mechanical "sorry" when I said our stay was disappointiing. When I heard that they are struggling, it was easy to see why. And when I was reminded by locals that the Bellagio sets the standard for service in Las Vegas, I knew I wouldn't be staying at the Aria again.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Stay”
Reviews.Author: StarbucksGuru14
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the SkySuites section of this amazing hotel. Our room was very spacious with a HUGE bathroom. The toilet was amazing, heats, rinses, dries-figure out the rest. The shower had great pressure and would be large enough to sleep the Russian army. The bed was the most comfortable i have ever slept on. I am considering purchasing one. The room also has free WiFi as well as ethernet. The WiFi is also free throught the SkySuite part of the hotel. I loved the Control 4 system and could sit all day and watch the drapes open and close. The SkySuites do a fantastic job of treating their customers. The lobby lounge has complimentary snacks and drinks, including mini Fiji and full size San Pellegrino waters. The whole staff is very warm and efficient. It is simple to get to the casino from a door on the lobby or promenade levels; both are either guarded or use a lock and need your room key to access. The complimentary limo transports to and from the airport eliminate the need for a rental car or taxi. My only complaint is that there is no Starbucks in Aria and the Roasted Bean is insanley expensive. There also is no food court for a quick bite or pick-me-up. I highly reccomend Jean Pilippe Patisserie for anyone with a sweet tooth or wants a light lunch or breakfast. I think next time I might choose the Mandarin Oriental for a bit more of a luxury feel and even better service but will come to Aria when in need of a casino. Overall, the hotel is a wonderful choice for all ages and would stay again.

Reviews.Title: “excelent hotel”
Reviews.Author: OctaviO_10
Reviews.Content: Brand new,great location,not croweded,fantastic swiming pools,enjoyable restaurants,high tach rooms!!

Reviews.Title: “In the top 10- not the Top 5- of Vegas Hotels”
Reviews.Author: SterlingGuy
Reviews.Content: Had a two-night stay on a special deal $79/night + free buffets. Check-in was strange. When I asked if I could have a "city view" (instead of a "mountain view"), she said they are never given for free- then didn't tell me how much (?). She kept having to look things up in booklets and notes just to check me in. Also, very few people at reception- no line, no waiting. Strange for a 4,000 room hotel. I was told that occupancy was 75%- that seems like a stretch. The route from reception requires you to wind yourself through the casino in a zig-zag pattern. The room was new and well-thought out- sorta. I liked the tub/shower combo with the tub in the back and shower in front. My view was toward the west, with a view of Vdara and Harmon street. The much-lauded control panel was more annoying than helpful. Very big, heavy and wired- An iPad it's not. Want to turn off a lamp? Go to lighting, then guestroom, then choose the light you want to turn off, then push that button. Video checkout was interesting (see photo). They want you to input your email address with the tiny TV remote control (not the bedside control panel)! Are you kidding? All in all, I think Aria is a flop. This is not a Vegas hotel. Feels like you're in a large chain hotel in any big city in the world. Part of that is because you are so far back from the excitement and lights of the LV Strip. MGM-Mirage put over $5b into City Center and could have done so much more with that kinda cash. What a poor result.

Reviews.Title: “NEVER STAY IN ARIA”
Reviews.Author: NDD362
Reviews.Content: My stay for the week was pleasant, however as I reached the tail end, I could feel that Aria hotel had absolutely no intention of making a relationship with its customers. This place and its staff do not care. The final one came when on my last night, the fire alarms went off at 2 AM. I was trying to catch some sleep before my 15 hr long flight, however this alarm made me jump out of bed. There was no announcement from the hotel staff that it was JUST A DRILL!!!!!!! at 2AM.... Its been one hour that I left the hotel and I am writing this review from the airport lounge. The staff at checkout was very very rude and asked me to leave if I had issues. My suggestion to travellers, look for a better place. the facilities in this place are mediocre and do not match even the discounted price if you get it. Aria is a BIG NO for me in the future

Reviews.Title: “Tried it. Won't be going back.”
Reviews.Author: NatCordova86
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Aria and on first impression alone I must say Its definelty a beautiful place. Now I must say I had heard nothing but bad things about this place before I had even arrived. Since I went with friends and we were staying during the week after July 4th we got an excellent deal. I was still bracing myself for the worst. I have been to vegas several times before but decided since its the newest hotel on the strip, why not? The one major thing that I had a problem with throughout my stay was the STAFF! The front desk lady was so condescending and insisted there were no double bed rooms and only king sized bed rooms for non smoking. I got angry at that because how was it possible that on a monday night after the huge weekend rush, there would be no two bed rooms available. She said the only one she could offer was in a smoking room. I could tell she just had a bad attitude. She stuck us on a stinky floor with a crappy view of the back. The reason I was annoyed by the stench was because for such a new hotel, the smell of smoke residue is unbearable. The other thing was the cleaning staff. The just barged into the room at least three times during the 4 nights we stayed. One time i was even changing. The hotel is beautiful and the beds were comfortable and to be honest those were the only memorable things to me. Its a shame. I'm not going to say DONT STAY here, because my experience wasnt horrible but I didnt even feel like hanging around and preffered to eat and exoplore all the other hotels on the strip. If you're getting an awesome deal to stay there, then I say go and check it out for yourself. It's so annoying that the incompetent staff is a complete contradiction to the pretentious atmosphere they are trying to create. Underwhelming!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, poor service”
Reviews.Author: JenAnn28
Reviews.Content: The hotel is gorgeous. Very modern-sleek decor. The room was very large and clean. Fantastic shower/tub. I loved the remote control for the room which controlled the tv, lights, ac, curtains, etc. However, the service is horrible. Maybe they are too new and too large to have it all together? Front desk was not helpful at all and the front desk manager was very "upity." It took 2 hours for the valet to pull our car out! They were very backed up. Also, the pool waitress overcharged our card! She wrote in a $300 tip. We called the hotel when it posted to our account. The lady on the phone was helpful but it took forever to clear up...and guess what...they never could locate the signed receipt. Wonder why? All in all, the hotel was great but very disappointed in the service. They are too new and too large to get it together.

Reviews.Title: “My new favorite Vegas resort”
Reviews.Author: bubbafb
Reviews.Content: Wow, what a resort. The new City Center on the Las Vegas strip is an amazing grouping of hotels, shopping plaza and condominiums. The Aria is the centerpiece of the complex with the only gaming, a bunch of restaurants & bars, and about 4,000 hotel rooms. We checked into the Aria from the north valet (valet is free and convenient) which is quite a walk to the main lobby but close to the room elevators. First thing of note: the staff at the Aria – quite frankly, I believe everyone we encountered – was courteous, polite and helpful. They must work hard to find the best of the best. With that, check-in was fairly quick and the reception associate helped get us adjoining rooms on a high floor. The rooms are absolutely gorgeous and over-the-top. The beds are comfortable, the TV had a ton of options for music and TV (not that you want to be in the room that long), the bathroom with a separate shower and large tub was awesome and best of all – the room can be controlled from a computer panel. And at night, you can hit the “goodnight” button next to the bed and it will close the curtains, turn off the TV and turn down the lights. Amazing technology. The pool area is very nice, with lots of shade and chairs. There are a bunch of dining options and this was our experience: The Buffet (for breakfast) – fantastic; Lemongrass (excellent Thai in a swanky setting); Café Vettro (a sleek, modern looking café with typical, but very tasty, diner food). There are plenty of bars to grab a cocktail and enjoyed Union (good happy hour prices) and Sage. Note about prices: the nice places in Vegas are expensive. Don’t be fooled by the low room prices of any of the top end hotels; the food and drink will be on par (both price and quality) with a city like NY. For the kids, we took them to McDonald’s in the food court at the Monte Carlo (which is attached to Aria) and they were thrilled. The casino has the games you would expect and there were $10 blackjack tables available throughout our stay, which is becoming harder to find. I guess $5 is gone for good from these nicer casinos. I have stayed in about 20 different Vegas hotels and this rates in the top 2 (along with the Venetian) and because of the newness, I will give it the top spot. For $109 (including $75 dining credit), this will be among your greatest resort experiences at the cost of a low-end chain room.

Reviews.Title: “stunning, fantastic, awesome from the get go!”
Reviews.Author: driftnup
Reviews.Content: The buildings that surround the Aria are like a gigantic movie set you never want to leave. Visionary in concept and design, even through the setbacks and heartaches the Aria is a marvel. When I opened the door to my room and the darkened room became slowly brighter due to the automatic curtians and the most stylish decor was unvieled, I was hooked. I travel to Las Vegas several times a year and have stayed in many beautiful hotels but the Aria made me go wow! The food, the service were excellent. Clean and bright. Fun slots and great tables. Several pools and quiet areas. The Bed was just awesome, seriously cozy. Valet was fast and professional. I look forward to my next stay at the Aria.

Reviews.Title: “ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!!!”
Reviews.Author: Heavenly2009
Reviews.Content: The Aria Hotel is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!! I left Las Vegas on yesterday and couldnt wait to write this review (I almost wrote the review before leaving!). The City Center as a whole is gorgeous, and Aria is definitely top notch. I booked a room under a Camp Vegas promo that included a $50 resort credit (for food and beverage only), free t-shirt and cap, and a $30 voucher to be used in the spa/fitness center. The hotel location is great and they have built a walk way that will put you right on the corner of the PH property. Or if you go the other direction (south), you can cross the street in front of Monte Carlo. There is also a shuttle that runs from City Center to other hotels (we caught the shuttle the first night to Treasure Island, cost was only $8. Monorail also runs through City Center, but did not take advantage of that). Upon walking into the hotel, there was a hint of a vanilla scent coming through the vents, so the place smelled wonderful (it wasnt an overpowering smell to us as other reviewers have indicated, but everyone's sense of smell is different :)). Check in was quick and painless and the attendant who assisted me was great (thank you Sadhika!!!). We were even upgraded to the 23rd floor which had amazing views of the pool area and the mountains. When you walk into the room, it comes alive, and that was cool! The curtains automatically opened, the tv came on, and so did the lights. There is a remote that controls the entire room which we didnt find to be very difficult to use, but we also love electronics sooooo.....we were in heaven:) The bed was so comfortable, you could literally lay in it all night and all day (you can even purchase one when you get back home, how cool is that??) Bathroom was huge with double sinks, seperate space for tub/shower and a glass w/c. Overall, room was great!! Only word of caution: DO NOT TOUCH ANY OF THE SNACKS IN THE TRAY ON THE TABLE, THEY ARE SENSORED AND IF YOU JUST PICK IT UP TO LOOK AT IT, YOU WILL AUTOMATICALLY BE CHARGED!!! Ate at "The Buffet" twice for breakfast and once for lunch and the food was amazing ($14.95 pp for breakfast/$19.95 pp for lunch/dinner). So many choices to choose from (the crab legs were delish!!!) and the staff was very friendly. Also ate at "Cafe Vettro" twice (open 24hrs) which was also good (buffalo wings are to die for :)). We also visited the adult pool lounge (Liquid) which was very cool. They were even giving away day passes for ladies so it was free (and only $20 for guys, which isnt bad). Its a more intimate environment but lots of energy in there. It is tucked away so you almost dont know that the general pool area is on the other side of the wall. And when you visit the general pool area, you cant even hear the music coming from Liqiuid. The water felt great and the food was good (a little pricey, but hey, its Vegas!!). We are not big gamblers but did spend a little time in the casino and had a great time. You can hardly smell the evidence of people smoking, and that was great. We also visited Crystals, it was nice walking through the different shops. There is a little place in Crystals called "The Cup" that makes delicious smoothies (if you go, try the Mango and Lemon Cream smoothie, I promise you will be hooked :)). Also ate at Wolfgang Pizzeria and it was good as well :) We had planned on going to the night club "Haze" inside Aria, but instead ended up going to TAO in the Venetian. However, Haze looks like a really nice club and is probably a nice place to hang out for an evening of good music and good fun :) There are some charges that I have seen other people mention that Aria does implement, like the internet ($15/day, i believe) for example as well as the fitness center ($??). I was there for fun however, so it didnt bother me about those fees, I hadnt planned one using either of those services anyways. If I had to say one bad thing about Aria, it would be that they charge $130 PER DAY for incidental charges (this seems a bit high to me, why not charge ppl as they incurr the charges as supposed to charging someone before they have purchased anything??). Please use a credit card as they will only authorize the transaction and as long as you dont mess up the room or charge anything to the room, they will remove the hold when you checkout. If you use a debit card (which they discourage, but can be done), its a hard transaction, so they will take the money out (if you stay 4 days like we did, thats $520!!!, and who knows the how long it may take to get your money back). This was my third trip to Vegas in the last 3 years, and I definitely plan on going back to visit Aria (more than likely next year since Ive been going every year!). The City Center is a city in itself and while staying there, we sometimes had to remind ourselves that we were in Vegas! You really dont have to leave the property for anything if you dont want to. I like the idea of staying at a different place each time, but after the experience that we had at Aria, the question is not "IF" we will return, but WHEN!!! If you choose Aria, I hope you have as much of an enjoyable and fun experience as we did!! God Bless and Safe Travels!!!

Reviews.Title: “we loved it ..pleasantly surprised wonderful stay”
Reviews.Author: purple81852
Reviews.Content: we come to vegas 3-4 times a year aways stay at Monte Carlo,, its like home ,, but decided to try Aria ,, what a beautiful place,, despite some of the negative reviews we decided to see for ourself,, staff were very helpful and friendly, over and above what I expected, the buffet was only disapointment ,, food not so great,, all though the other restaurants there were fabulous ,, rooms were great,, almost hated to leave room to gamble, but loved the casino,, great variety of machines and tables,, we like both ,,, cant wait to go back again in october.. Terry and bernadette

Reviews.Title: “very modern”
Reviews.Author: WithLove71
Reviews.Content: The hotel was nice, very modern with friendly staff. I expected the rooms and bathrooms to be a little more spacious. I'm very picky when it comes to cleanliness so when I found a black hair in the tub and another one on a pillow , that just didn't go well with me . The pool area closes early unlike other hotels and we were expecting the 3 pools to be much larger. There is a $30 /person per day fee for the use of the gym which I found ridiculous as a hotel guest keeping in mind that I pay half of that amount for a full month's membership at the local fitness center... Other than that, the food was good, u don't see the huge crowds u see at other hotels, beds are comfortable, the hotel just grows on you the longer you stay.

Reviews.Title: “Worst. Service. Ever.”
Reviews.Author: icantthinkofascreenn
Reviews.Content: I booked a non-smoking king room on Aria's website. The website makes you pre-pay the first night, and they've got a 48 hour cancellation policy. We checked in late, there was no rush. The only available rep was talking on the phone and could not even make eye contact while we stood there being ignored. Finally he gets off the phone only to tell us that we can't have the room we pre-paid for. They demand prepayment and won't give it back to you of you cancel inside of 48 hours, but they'll give away your room if you are unlucky enough to be on a late flight. A short "discussion" later in which he refused to let me speak to his superior we accept a room with 2 queen beds. What were we supposed to do? It was 9pm on Saturday night. We had no options and they knew it. No discount, no apology, no nothing. The sinks in the bathroom were designed by a retarded yellow labrador who likes getting sprayed with water. You must take off your cloths before washing your hands. Warning about checkout: Your RFID key will be disabled the exact second you press "checkout" on the TV. We let the door close on us while we were putting our luggage in the hall and couldn't get back into the room. Housekeeping was nearby but refused to help us. We had to wait 15 minutes for security to come find us and interrogate us before letting us into our room. You would think that with 14% unemployment in Nevada they could hire some friendly people.

Reviews.Title: “WAS MORE THAN EXPECTED....”
Reviews.Author: travelingoften
Reviews.Content: We just wanted to get away for a few days so we decided to go to Vegas. I go often and I have seen the Aria under construction for months. Well I went on the website and since they were running a midweek stay discount I decided to check it out. Well it was so much more than I expected. Check in was simple most of the counter was manned so check in was a breeze. We had booked a deluxe room (which is their standard room). Upon entering the room the electric shades opened and music started playing WOW!!!. The TV has your name on the screen and many options of delightment! The TV, lights, shades are controled by a control panel located next to bed. The bonus is that if you don't get all of the high tech stuff there is a regular remote too for the TV. The bathroom is very hip and functional. I cant say enough about the bed except WOW. It felt as if it was one huge fluffy pillow. Even a gentleman on the elevator said wait until you lay on your bed!! It was soft but comfortable I didnt even feel my husband get in or out of it. That's how it engulfed you. We had a room close to the elevators becasue the halls are EXTREMELY long. As promise from the woman at check in there was no noise. Our view was behind the building looking at the mountains which was just fine for us. The casino was lively and fun. The stores there are very expensive but what would you expect from such high end designers. We did partake of the breakfast buffet but bonus it was just before they started the lunch buffet so we had both for the price of breakfast. I like how they don't close the buffet but just transform the different foods at the appropriate time. Again great service there too. We self parked which was an easy in and out. Check out was quick and correct !! I have stayed at many of the high end hotels for a lot more money and haven't had an experience like this one. They have made a loyal and repeat customer for my future stays in Vegas...(Side note it states that it has a DVD player but it just had the options if you brought your own laptop or portable player. Bring your cords!!!)

Reviews.Title: “Poor Customer Service”
Reviews.Author: c12ack
Reviews.Content: A letter written today to Aria/MGM/Mirage Management To Whom It May Concern: Please forward this email to the appropriate department and/or persons. Please forward this to management, regional managers, if any. I stayed at Aria this past weekend from July 23rd, 2010 through July 25th, 2010. I want to share with you my experience. Let me note, this is my second time at your hotel. The first time I stayed in your hotel was in March 23, 2010. Let me also say, I did NOT want to stay at Aria this past weekend because I had complimentary rooms at the Venetian. However, my wife loved Aria soooo much from our first stay, she wanted to come back. And I want to stress that I shouldn't have listened to my wife. We checked in on Friday around 5:30pm. I thought it was going to be a good trip from the get go. The valet line was running smoothly and there was no line at the checkin/registration section. We found our room 16-262 easily, which was by the elevator. Unlike our previous stay, we were placed far from the elevator and on the right side of the "split." Entered our room and as expected, the curtains opened, the lights turned on, the.....the tv was frozen. My wife unpacked while I kept turning the TV on and off. Pressing the channel up and down. Pressing menu, guide, menu, etc. Finally after about 7 minutes, I called the front desk. Told them about my TV. The lady at the front desk said she would said some one up to fix it. The lady said it was probably a glitch. It happens often. "Wow," I thought to myself. "This sucks." "This happens often?" Something a guest and a possible future guest shouldnt be hearing. Being a guy, seeing the TV turn on with my name on it is probably the thing I anticipated the most. Forget the lights turning on, forget about the curtains. I want to see my name on the TV! But no, no name. No nothing. Just a white "Aria" written on the bottom right on a black background. About 10 minutes past. Still no one came up. My wife wanted to go downstairs. I wanted to wait for someone to fix the TV. Anyways I listened to my wife again and we went down. I dont know if someone had to come to the room to fix the so called glitch or if someone could do it remotely. I was reluctant to leave the room. But I didn't anyway. When we came back, the TV was on, working normally. We got ready that night to enjoy the nightlife. My wife was rather mad because there was no outlet by the large mirror next to the closet. She wanted to do her hair and makeup. But wanted to sit down and be extremely close to the mirror. She kept getting frustrated because usually at home, she sits down to do her hair and makeup. Because she was getting frustrated, she was getting me frustrated. In comparison, Venetian has a separate vanity with a chair in all their rooms and suites. Let me note that the first time we were there, we didn't go out to a club, so this is essentially the first time my wife has had an experience with the vanity. The more I heard her complain, the more I WISHED we had stayed at the Venetian. First, the TV, now no outlet, no chair for the vanity. So both my wife and I found flaws at this hotel. Something we didn't experience in March. We eventually got into a fight. I called the front desk to ask for a roll-away bed. The person at the front desk said there was a charge of $35/night! What? Are you kidding me? I said nevermind. Of note, I wanted a roll-away bed just in case I might not want to stay in the bed. I heard my wife keep complaining about how she cant do her makeup right. Her hair doesn't curl properly. I told my self I Needed a roll away bed. I was getting irritated already. I tried to call housekeeping to avoid the $35/night charge. I couldn't even believe there was a charge. Venetian does not charge. At this point I felt, this would be the LAST TIME I would stay here. Housekeeping said they would transfer me to the front desk. Oh geez. I said nevermind. Just give me more pillows and blankets. I rearranged the two chairs to make a "bed". At least it was better than the floor. I could hear my wife, still irritated. I tried the front desk one more time. I just couldn't take it. I told my wife SHE wanted to stay at this place. I wanted to goto Venetian! Poor service, no TV, cant even get a roll away bed! She wanted to goto Venetian now. I told her we were already here so lets just deal with it. I called the front desk again to try to get a roll away bed. Surprisingly, the gentleman I spoke to said ok. Wow. I was shocked. I ordered room service. Got a burger again like last time. The best thing I noticed from both this trip and the last was your ROOM SERVICE IS TOP NOTCH! Food is awesome. Food is hot. The delivery people are kind. However, it doesn't take away the tv was broken, that there are no outlets by the mirror, that the vanity mirror didn't have a chair, that there is a charge for a roll away bed. At lease the food was good. The next day, we went out. Picked up our car from valet. When we returned about 2 hours later, we pulled into the valet. My wife and I were sitting in our car for over 5 minutes. I could see the line of cars getting longer in my rear view mirror. There was no one directing traffic. A car pulled all the way left and was able to get valet service faster. Unfortunately, I was too close to the car in front of me and I couldnt' go to the left hand lane. About 7 minutes had passed now. There was still no one directing traffic. I managed to pull left hoping I could get faster service. I sat in the car with the AC on and the valet runners kept going by me. I decided to go out to try to track one of the valet runners down to get assistance. At least 3 runners passed me up. Let me note that they did see me waiting but kept going. I decided to speak up and finally one lady turned around and helped me. This was ridiculous. No organization. No direction. 10 minutes waiting for valet in 110 degree heat! We ate at the Aria buffet for lunch with the complimentary buffet for 2 at around 4PM that day. The cashier was rude. I said I have comp buffet and would like to charge it to my room. She looked at me with strange stare and repeated what I just said. I said "yes". I would like to charge it to my room using the comp buffet. She asked for my room number and last name. I told her. She said, "Christopher Salazar?" I said, "yes". She didn't ask to see my ID, which I thought was odd. She didn't ask for my players card. The way she asked questions and the look on her face was very un-customer service like. We went out again that night (July 24). We came back around 5am again. Ordered room service. Again, room service was outstanding. Probably the best thing thoughtout this stay I have noticed. I checked out via the control4 panel at a little before 12PM. Checkout was easy, just like my last stay. However again, the Valet service was terrible. Waiting for about 40 minutes in the heat. The valet runners had to yell out the names of the people waiting for their cars. I told my wife maybe a loudspeaker system would make things more efficient. To sum things up, this is the WORST Vegas hotel experience I've had. I'm 30 years old. I've stayed at almost every MGM/Mirage property in Vegas. From Circus Circus when I was 8 years old. Later on Excalibur, Luxor, New York, New York, Mirage and Treasure Island when I was a child and teenager with my parents. To more recently Luxor, Bellagio, MGM Grand and Mandalay Bay in my adult years. I have never had a problem with valet, customer service. In general the problems I experienced this past weekend. In fact, I felt so strongly terrible about this weekend I decided to write this letter. I never complain (except to my wife.) I enjoy MGM/Mirage hotels and I was looking forward to spending time at MGM/Mirage more often, especially when my kids are a little bit older to enjoy the experience I had when I was a child. But, again, this one weekend may have changed my mind completely about the standards MGM/Mirage I thought carried. My income isn't very large but I do enjoy gambling. And I do enjoy Vegas. Im from Los Angeles so it is the perfect get away for me. Enjoy Vegas better than San Diego, San Francisco, Napa Valley, or Santa Barbara. My Players Club profile doesn't show I've been putting a lot of money into MGM Mirage because like I've mentioned many times, Venetian offers me complimentary rooms. The Wynn as well offered me complimetary rooms as recent as 2008. Not discounts or "casino rate" but actually complimetary. Of course, I would spend my hard earned money somewhere else where the customer feels welcomed and taken cared of. Im not looking for complimetary rooms. I just want the staff educated in customer service. Educate them to take care of their customers. Work on the valet service to provide better efficiency. I come to Vegas 2-4 times a year. Like I mentioned this is my second time this year with a strong possibilty coming a 3rd time in the fall. Customer service at the Aria from July 23, 2010 through July 25, 2010 was extremely poor. Im in the medical field so I know what customer service is about. I hope you strongly take this letter seriously. Thank you. Christopher Paul Salazar

Reviews.Title: “ARIA WAS A GREAT EXPERIENCE OVERALL”
Reviews.Author: Eastby
Reviews.Content: Aria….WOW!!! It's hard to capture the essence of a new hotel experience in one review, but here goes. Overall, I was very impressed. It was very evident that MGM Mirage took a great deal of time and effort to design the Aria Hotel and Casino, while keeping a clear eye on the future of Las Vegas. In many ways, it’s years ahead of the other hotels. In some ways, this helps; in other ways, this hurts. Aria is the centerpiece of the MGM Mirage City Center Project – an extremely ambitious plan to design a full-feature, high-end residence and resort complex in the heart of the Las Vegas Strip. Unfortunately, during construction, the U.S. economy experienced the worst downturn since the Great Depression, and MGM was forced to sell Treasure Island just to keep the CC project going. Along with Aria, City Center features the Vdara, Mandarin Oriental and Harmon Hotels; as well as the Veer Towers condominium complex. But Aria is the centerpiece: it was designed to bring tourists in, as well as prospective buyers to the CC condo residences (the sales of which, are not going well at all). All in all, Aria is a pretty amazing place. Since it’s the “center” of City Center, Aria is set back from the Strip quite a ways, which is a bit of an inconvenience for normal foot traffic visitors. You definitely get the feel that you’re “in the middle of something” rather than being “part of something” – at least in my humble view. Kind of like being one of the first houses in a new development that very few others have moved into yet: a little uncomfortable at first, but eventually (hopefully), it will all “fill out” in time. There’s a cool tram that connects Aria with Monte Carlo to the south and Bellagio to the north, which definitely saves on walking time. CHECK-IN: It took me about 20 minutes on a Saturday afternoon, which isn’t bad at all by Vegas standards. Very good overall. WARNING: This hotel was built for the convention market (which has never materialized as MGM originally envisioned), which is based on solo occupants/guests. As such, the vast majority of Aria’s rooms feature king beds. There are a minimal number of double queen rooms available. If you “reserved” a double queen room, they hotel staff will quickly remind you that a twin queen room is a “REQUEST” only – and purely subject to the availability on the day of check-in. In the 10 minutes that I was actually at the check-in desk, I heard of no less than three separate parties that were irate that the twin queen rooms that they “reserved” were not available. It was “rollaway bed world” for these guests (in a king room that can’t properly accommodate a rollaway bed in the first place), and that reality seems to have ignited most of the negative reviews of Aria. ADVICE: If you absolutely must have a twin queen room, book with a different hotel. Otherwise, you may be very disappointed when you are told it’s not available. STAFF/CUSTOMER SERVICE: The hotel staff was plentiful, and very attentive. Not sure why all the negative comments about poor staff service. They were “all over me” (in a good way) at check-in, and throughout my stay. One night while I was playing the slots, a hotel security person asked me “is that your dollar bill sitting next to the slot machine?” I told him that I was waiting for the cocktail waitress to return with my drink order, and he politely said “Very Good, Sir,” and moved on. I guess he was making sure I wasn’t throwing my money around (kind of ironic, since Aria’s sole purpose is to take my money, along with every other Vegas casino). Aria has staff everywhere you look at this place. The security guys looked like they are UFC/MMA athletes. Very polite, but totally “loaded and ready to roll” if you ever want to try any “funny stuff.” Kind of like an old-school Italian father with his precious virgin daughter; or a married new-home owner having his first Super Bowl Party with his bachelor slob buddies. Guest elevators were attentively watched by security personnel to make sure you presented a room key before they would let you in. Overall, I got the impression that MGM Mirage considers Aria their crown jewel, and they are guarding it very carefully. Have fun….but “watch yourself.” They are also very attentive to the overall look and neatness of the property. When “slot gaming,” as soon as I got up from a slot machine, the staff very quickly pushed the seat back in tight against the machine just as though I got up from the dinner table. Finally, although MGM would never say that they discourage smokers, ash trays are hard to find throughout the casino (which could be a good or bad thing, depending upon whether you light up). Either way, there is no smell of smoke at all throughout the casino, despite the fact that many patrons are “heating up.” There will never be a non-smoking casino in Vegas, but this is probably the best one to effectively remove smoke from the air. Not sure how they do it, but they do it. CASINO: Amazing layout. The hotel has a slight vanilla smell that you notice when you first arrive, but quickly fades as you get used to it. Unlike the extreme and excessive “perfumery” of the Venetian and Palazzo. You arrive at Aria, you smell the vanilla immediately, and then it kinds of disappears into a pleasant area of your cerebral cortex (which I’m sure MGM engineers worked for months to perfect). The overall “breathing atmosphere” is perfect. The design is “total contemporary elegance:” very modern décor with unique artwork, lighting, and wall treatments. The pronounced colors seem to be earth tones of brown, black, gold, silver, and burgundy. Some people consider it “too dark,” but I thought it was superbly designed and presented. The gaming tables were the usual fare. The slot machines, I must admit, are the loosest that I encountered in my Vegas trip. I tried a number of casinos during my stay (MGM Grand, Mandalay Bay, Monte Carlo, Bellagio, and Venetian), and I definitely made out best at Aria. Slot payouts are a more closely guarded secret in Vegas than the Coca Cola recipe is in Atlanta, but I think MGM Mirage is “loosening” their slots at Aria to get more people to come visit (just like the Maloof Brothers openly admit that they do to get you to get off the Strip and come to The Palms). Of course, MGM would never admit that. But consider the simple fact that MGM is offering $400/night rooms for $100 just to get people to come to Aria. That should tell you something. As soon as the economy turns, the room rates will go straight up. One other thing. A lot of people have said that there aren’t many penny machines, but that’s not true. Many Aria machines give you the chance to change the denomination from one cent to two cents to five cents. In addition, for the penny machines, you can actually change the actual electronic games on the same slot machine. I have never seen this at any other casino. I’m not talking about electronic card games that allow you to change from “Dueces Wild” to “Five Card Draw” to “Texas Hold ‘Em.” I’m talking about animated penny slot machines. You can go from “Arctic Wolf” to “Grand Monarch” to “Savannah” to “Cats” on the very same machine with the push of a button – and you can also change the betting denomination. The new game program loads, and all of the graphic artwork changes on the “headboard” and gameboard and betting keys to reflect the new game. You could literally play five different penny games on the same machine in the course of a half hour. I have never seen that before at any other casino, and I think that’s an amazing innovation. I also think the new machines at Aria have greatly simplified the “Free Play” and “Point Play” process for MG Players Club card holders. Very, very easy to input your PIN information and know exactly where you stand on your point balance. Much easier than the old pushbutton “Yes/No” numeric keypads on the older machines. Of course, the new machines have Bose speakers as well. Overall, the Aria casino is smaller than MGM (which one isn’t?), and less elegant than Bellagio (utterly classic, in its own league), but it nonetheless holds its own extremely well when compared to other Vegas casinos. It is one of my very favorites. POOL AREA: Very dichotomous review here. I would say that the Aria pools themselves are some of the “weakest” Vegas pools that I have experienced; but I would also say that the “pool area” is probably the best that I have experienced. There are three elliptical shaped pools that must have a maximum depth of three feet each. I couldn’t believe it when I got in it the water. Come on now. I’m not asking for a “deep end” of eight feet, but I could use at least 4 ½ feet. I had to get on my knees to get the water up to my shoulders, and I’m only 5 foot 10. They are superb pools for small kids (you could never drown in these things, despite hawk-like lifeguards watching your every move) -- but not for big kids that actually like to swim. VERY disappointing overall as far as the actual pools themselves are concerned. MGM Grand still reigns in the “pool wars” amongst MGM properties. “The Beach” at Mandalay Bay is an overrated cross between Spring Break and Disneyland. Though an inferior hotel, Monte Carlo’s pool offering is better than Aria. All that criticism aside, the “pool area” around the three Aria pools is utterly amazing. The palm trees are plentiful, as is the privacy, the availability of chaise lounges, the attentive and friendly pool bar staff, and the overall relaxing feel. It never, ever felt crowded or “circus-like” at this place. Shallow water meant no cannonballs, I guess. People came and went casually, the breezes came and went comfortably, and the music (good music) played relaxingly -- at just the right volume. Not a PARTY!!!….but a great time. You could read books or magazines with a cool drink for hours at this pool. The other thing that Aria totally nailed on the design of the pool area is that “there’s something for everyone” here as far as sun exposure is concerned. A long-time criticism of mine is that Vegas pools are too exposed to the desert sun. You could get slathered in 45 SPF, and if you’re from Wisconsin or Washington (as I am), you’re still going to get burned beyond belief if you’re exposed longer than an hour. Aria very smartly built their pools very closely to the west side of their huge hotel. So if you come in the morning (i.e. 0900-1200), you should be able to find plenty of shade if you want it since the shadow of the enormous hotel blocks the sun. NOTE TO VEGAS TOURISTS: Not everybody who goes to a pool wants to get burned up in the 110 degree desert sun. They want to relax and “feel the heat” -- without the melanoma. Aria is the perfect place to do just that. One thing that was quite peculiar, however, was that the pool complex was on the second floor “Promenade” level – ABOVE the casino -- along with the Elvis Theater, buffet, and the conference rooms. The more I think about it, the more that I believe this is why the pools are so shallow. The additional weight of “deep water” would probably be too much for the second floor structure to support, as most hotel pools are on the ground level. ROOMS: The rooms are the Aria’s ”testament to technology.” As many have reported, when you “wave” the room key at the lock (NOT insert it in any slot), the room welcomes you by opening the curtains, and playing background music on the TV, which also welcomes you personally to Aria by name on the TV screen. Many people have complained about the difficulty of using the “smart device” on the left nightstand that controls the room’s lighting, HVAC, TV, and curtains, but it’s really not that difficult -- and fairly intuitive. Once you practice a few minutes, you should get the hang of it. There are also buttons that act as light switches, so you can still go “conventional” if you would like. The TV is probably easier to use (at least turn on) using the smart pad. About the only thing I was never able to do is turn on the right nightstand lamp. I concluded (at the end of my stay) that it was probably due to a burned out bulb. Overall, the room is decent sized, and very comfortable. The bed is extremely comfortable -- but it might be a tad too soft for some people -- and there are pillows everywhere. The Aria does quite a trade in selling guests their hotel bed pillows (they’ll mail them to your residence). I had a king room, so I had no aforementioned difficulty getting a double queen room because I didn’t “reserve” (i.e. request) one. The bathroom is very nice, with the tub actually inside the shower enclosure, next to the shower stall. Very unique design, but it worked well. Pretty good water pressure as well, considering all the plumbing utilizes water saver devices. Never had any difficulty getting the room cleaned up. I had a handful of change on my dresser disappear one day, so the housekeeping staff obviously thought it was a tip. No problem. Although I didn’t intend it, I can see their reasoning, as money left out is usually considered a tip, and they did a great job. My wife tips the housekeeping staff, but I usually don’t, but I should probably start doing it (a couple bucks a day in Vegas is totally reasonable). The safe in the lower drawer of the nightstand is very large (big enough for a laptop), and works very well. Most importantly, I ALWAYS had a good night’s sleep, and there was never any “party noise” or excess commotion during my entire stay. SHOWS: I didn’t see the Cirque de Soleil “Viva Elvis” show, but I spoke with several guests who did see it, and they really enjoyed it. FOOD: I tried the lunch buffet, and it was good. Nothing spectacular, but as long as they keep the crab legs coming (which they did), I’m happy. The sushi, meat (leg of lamb was awesome), and desert selections were also very good. They have gelato instead of ice cream, and it’s delicious. I also didn’t eat out at any of the fancy restaurants, but the Jean Philippe Patisserie was good for a quick bite, and Chill was good for a sweet snack. As has been widely reported, prices are quite high for all food options. The days of cheap eats are long gone in Vegas, at least in nice hotels on the strip. If you want cheap fare, go next door to the Monte Carlo Food Court (or to MGM Grand), where they have a McDonald’s and Sbarro. CONCLUSION: Aria is a GREAT hotel, and I will definitely be going back. PROS: The hotel staff; the overall hotel “atmosphere;” the pool “lounge area;” and the casino look and layout (and fairly loose slots). CONS: Very limited double queen rooms; shallow pools; location set back from the strip; and room automation might be a little daunting for the “technologically challenged” guests.

Reviews.AuthorLocation: Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates
Reviews.Title: “We are so glad we chose this hotel”
Reviews.Author: ammoss
Reviews.Content: After reading so many mixed reviews about this hotel we were not sure what to expect but we can honestly say the hotel was great. Arrived around 7pm (admittedly it was a mid week night) and there was no line at check in so got served immediately. We paid cash for the room rather than use our credit card (read all the reviews about overcharging and queues to check out) there was no delay .our room was ready and all our requests had been met. We asked for a quiet room and was given an high floor and a room well away from the lifts. If you don't want a long walk ask for a room close to the elevators! The room was fine, the remote control for curtains, lights etc was no big deal at all to master and if its a problem just use the regular switches on the wall!! We experienced no problem with the housekeeping, the room was made up and well cleaned everyday for the 5 days we were there. We had a problem opening the safe (the people in the room before us had closed it with their code.....why do people do that??) but a quick phone call, answered promptly, the maintenance guy was there within 10 mins, he had to wait for security so changed the light bulb that was out while he was waiting. As for the bed......it really was the best bed we had ever slept in, so comfy......if i lived in the USA I would definitely order one!! Ate breakfast at the Patisserie on a morning.....great coffee too......and never a problem getting a table. Also ate at the Todd English PUB next door in City centre ......a fantastic choice of beers, good service and food at reasonable prices. Parked at the self parking and again no big deal , there is a walkway directly into the hotel so easy to manoeuvre cases etc. The hotel location was perfect and easy to access both the Bellaggio and Monte Carlo. Used the pool, nice but maybe chilled just a little too much for our liking and the service around the pool area was very efficient. All in we have no complaints at all about this hotel. The hotel is very modern and is not themed like a lot of the other Vegas hotels, if its the later you are looking for, this isn't the hotel for you, but if you want a bit of luxury and a more relaxed atmosphere I would definitely recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “The best in Las Vegas!!!”
Reviews.Author: mjg6541
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for my 30th,this place was amazing checked in was fast walked into the room and was shocked bathroom was huge. The remote is the best controls your whole room and the view from the rooms is perfect.The pool area is perfect it has three large pools plus a party pool liquid which was perfect great food and strong good drink. The best place in vegas.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Stay”
Reviews.Author: cubs_fan83
Reviews.Content: Before I begin, I know there have been plenty of negative reviews on here. Some comments being pretty unreasonable. I will say considering I am in Customer Service, if you treat the employees well, they treat you even better. That said, We stayed at Aria for 3 nights over the weekend. We were celebrating my Birthday friday night. Check-In was pretty easy considering we arrived at 9:30 am. The person who checked us in was very friendly and helpful. Our room wasn't ready yet so we were given line passes to the pool/buffet (this meant we could skip any lines and head right in). We were told to check back on our room in 2 hrs and they put a rush on the room for us. We ate breakfast at Cafe Vettro which was awesome. My husband said the Corned Beef Hash was one of the best he'd ever had. My Steak and Eggs were also great. We were greeted by everyone as we walked to our table and the waiter was very nice. We checked back on our room and were upgraded to a Panaramic View Corner Suite as this was the first available room. The room was gorgeous and easy to use. Floor to ceilings windows from the Master bedroom to the bathroom and through the entire livingroom. It had a great jacuzzi tub also surrounded by windows and a partial view of the strip from north to south. It also had many amenities that you don't typically get in other hotels, i.e. a razor, toothbrush/toothpaste, hairspray, and a large vanity kit. The room also had a minibar and a seperate fridge. We ate at the Buffet twice, once for dinner and then brunch saturday morning. Dinner friday night had complimentary Lobster and Wine for each table and Brunch had Bloody Marys and Mimosas. We tried the Buffet at the Wynn and were not very pleased. The selection wasn't as big and the employees were not very friendly. At Aria the pools were absolutely wonderful and relaxing. Never had a problem finding beds together and the noise levels from each pool never bothered the others which was cool. There were pools where all the kids played and pools where the adults relaxed. Breeze Cafe was awesome and again the service was great. I ordered a fruit plate and my husband ordered a BLT. We shared the BLT and the fruit plate was huge. We shared that as well and barely put a dent in it. The waiter asked if the fruit was okay and we told him we were simply full from the huge BLT and great fries. He then came back with the check and removed the fruit plate since we hardly touched it. He insisted and wished us a great stay. Again, great service. Lots of security around which always made us feel secure. I know people complained about security by the elevators but there were many times that we witnessed people trying to get in that didn't belong in our hotel and didn't have room keys to pass through ( they were trying to get up to rooms for parties). The slots weren't tight and neither was the video poker. Also, waitresses always came around to check on you and your drinks. Overall, the stay was fantastic. Again, everyone we encountered spoke with us and wished us a great stay. The only negative to this hotel is the fact the you spend alot of money. That's the downside with such great service. We tipped everyone well from the bellhops to the valet, waiters, waitresses, and room service/housekeepers. We felt the need to considering how gracious they were and how funny and genuinely concerned they were with your experience. I forgot to mention everyone knew it was my Birthday.
