I guess it was in the computer system but waiters/waitresses knew when I would charge things to our room and the housekeepers wished me Happy Birthday as well when they serviced our room. My husband and I were greatly pleased with that level of service. Check out was also easy as you do it through the T.V. Again, everything was exquisite. We would probably never stay here again as we try different hotels everytime we're in Vegas, but I would love to bring my parents here to experience a true 5 star hotel.

Reviews.Title: “OVERRATED”
Reviews.Author: Stomberlin
Reviews.Content: The hotel does not maintain posted check in check out times which means they really can't tell you when your room will be available on a busy weekend. Booking an upgrade through a travel site doesn't not guarantee you the upgrade, even if you pay more for the upgrade. The concierge is not knowledgeable about the property or surrounding area. The rooms, while trendy and cool, are computer based and subject to tech failure. There is not a single map of the property posted outside of your room - making it difficult to find your way around. The hotel is making a run at being a high end hotel on the strip - but is simply overrated. Gaming table minimums are high, rooms are overly complicated to use (after 5 days I still could not figure out how to turn on all the lights in the room), the staff does not provide a high level of service. If you want high end - head to the Bellagio - at least the staff there smiles.

Reviews.Title: “totally overwhelming,beautiful, and plenty of activities in hotel.”
Reviews.Author: NIcoleG56
Reviews.Content: There was a mall, arcade, resteraunts, three pools, casino, convention center, and much more. we styed on the 22nd floor and it was beautiful day and night. the room was all ran electronically wehen you open the door curtains autamatically open the kids loved it!!

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing in Luxury. Don't Party/Gamble here”
Reviews.Author: topherashley
Reviews.Content: Love the modern elegance of Aria. It truly is a beautiful hotel. It is also very big and off the strip, make sure you wear your walking shoes to go anywhere off property as you've got a 15-20 minute walk to the Strip or simply pony up cab fare. Jean Phillipe's is a great place for brunch or a snack, the pool bar had great food, the prices aren't bad if you book on hotwire or through some special. The rooms are amazing, have to be one of the best layouts in Vegas. We got a room overlooking the pool and out to Mandalay Bay. Technology is not hard to grasp, if you had trouble with the room control pad, you probably still have a cell phone that only receives calls. (and you probably can't text) Only true negative - This place is a tad bit boring. DO NOT, I repeat DO NOT GAMBLE at the hotel that is billions of dollars in debt. You will not win here. It is evidently a known fact by locals/cab drivers, etc that Aria has tight slots, tables, and dealers. If you win any money, get the hell out. Also, the clubs are lame and way too expensive for what they are. Overall I'd stay here again but with the knowledge that I would be at another property to party or gamble.

Reviews.Title: “It exceeded my expectations”
Reviews.Author: stm0041
Reviews.Content: After much reading about the various hotels on the Las Vegas Strip, I chose the Aria. I had received a package that included air fare from Dallas, 4 nights at the Aria with an upgrade to a City View Deluxe room, $100 in food credit, a few other unused discounts and airport to hotel transfers for a bit over $1,100. The hotel itself was absolutely beautiful. This hotel has a LEEDS Gold Level certification and the decor was incredible. Very modernistic in every detail. The accomodations were spotless! It is centrally located on the strip. I'll start with the good points. The lobby service was excellent although they did not have any non-smoking rooms when we arrived. The front desk was willing to move us the next morning but when we entered the room, it didn't smell like a smoking room (although the hallways did). We were fine on the floor (22nd). The room itself was spacious and had the most comfortable bed/pillows I have ever slept on. I was a bit wary about the electronics after reading other reviews of the Aria but found that they were easy to master. The thermostat, blinds, lights, television (flat screen) and music were all controlled by a single remote through the TV. The room had an excellent view of the "Strip". Double sinks in the bath and a large shower with a non-jacuzzi double bathtub. We were warned at the front desk that the mini bar in the room was weight sensitive and that if we touched/moved the items (way over-priced) it would be charged to our account. There are retail stores close to the hotel to purchase bottled water/snacks and avoid these costs. We read so many bad reviews about the buffet that we were a little intimidated about trying it. Guess that's why there is 32 flavors at Baskin Robbins. We found the buffet to be incredible. Prime rib, chilled King crab, roasted turkey, lamb, ham, chicken, seafood, salads, oriental, mexican and italian dishes everwhere plus cooked to order eggs/omelets (brunch) and pasta (lunch) PLUS a very spectacular desert area with Oreo Shooters ( to die for) and some of the best ice creams I have had. Found the service to be great. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Being my first trip to Vegas in many years, I wish I had set up a players account when I first entered the casino. The players account at the Aria is through MGM and ties many of the casinos together. Would have had some additional "perks" if we did. If I had the trip to "do over" I'd probably not take the transfers and would have taken a cab from the airport to the hotel. Let's face it, many of us do not make many trips to Vegas. A cab would deliver you to the front lobby. Our transfer bus dropped us at an underground spot. It took the "pizazz" out of the arrival. It was then a long walk to the hotel lobby to check in. There isn't any need for a car in Vegas unless you want to travel off the strip. We went for a day trip to Hoover Dam. That was well worth the drive. My advice is to book the rental car before you book into the hotel (Dollar) for the day you want it as there is a variance between what you would pay pre-booking and what you would pay at the hotel. In my case it was $52 vs, $69 per day. If you make the reservation for the last 24 hours you will be in Vegas, you can pick the car up at the hotel and drop it off at the airport for the same price. No need to wait for a scheduled pick up from the transfer companies to get you to the airport. The Aria is in the City Center between the Bellagio and Monte Carlo resorts. A tram will transport you between the three. Wi-Fi connection at the hotel is expensive at $15 per day. To check in for your outgoing flights is $5 at area kiosks. Computer time at the business center was $15 for a minimum of 15 minutes. BUT if you go down to where they rent the rental cars, I was able to connect to several free wi-fi connections for internet access on my I-phone. If I had it to "do over", the Aria would again be my choice for Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “A Hotel with an identity crisis”
Reviews.Author: PurdyOne
Reviews.Content: This hotel is beautiful, it just seems like it can't decide who it wants to cater to. We stayed for 3 nights in a sky suite. The room and view were amazing. The hotel just seemed kinda meh. Did it want to be young and hip...... or maybe cater to an older more well off crowd........ or did it want to be someplace relaxing. I found it lacking personality. The people we encountered were great, the food was well presented and the restaurant service was top notch. Cocktail service was quick and plentiful, we were hardly into our drinks before she was around again and the casino was fairly busy. Would I stay here again, maybe; don't get me wrong this hotel is beautiful and the service was excellent it just didn't have the "vegas" feel.

Reviews.Title: “Very modern,great customer service,but inconvenient location”
Reviews.Author: NNewbie07
Reviews.Content: We wanted to try one of the newest in Las Vegas and for the most part it was a great hotel. The decor is very updated and modern from the lobby to the casino to the rooms. The whole place was pumped with that new car smell. There is security everywhere-it felt very safe. The room was very hi-tech. Nice size, windows from ceiling to floor, big screen TV w/remote that controlled everything in the room-(lights,curtains,alarm,radio-it was cool!) A complimentary robe in the room was available and lots of closet and drawer space. Too bad the ice box was stocked w/stuff to purchase (no room for your own stuff) Warning: Don't touch anything in there or else they will charge you an arm and a leg. If you wanted to have another ice box in your room you could request one- for a price! The rooms were sound proof and so were the hallways. It was easy to go from your room to the casino. As for the casino- I thought it was wonderful. They even have a rare game that aren't in most casinos-"WAR!" The same game from my childhood but for REAL MONEY! They had lots of high stakes tables and by all the noise that I heard, someone must have been on a roll. Now for some bad news. It is a good idea if you are staying there to get your directions down or you WILL GET LOST. It is a hard hotel to find. Parking is very hard to find, but once you know how it all works-it gets easier. The hotel is surrounded by other buildings and you can't see the strip. So the view is not so good. The tram between hotels is GREAT! If you stay you can use it to go to the Bellagio and Monte Carlo. The ride is faster than walking and it is prompt. The buffet at the Aria is FANTASTIC! The dessert section was simple delish! The portions were just right-you could try everything and not feel full. The way it was designed should of been better because it felt like being in a cafeteria. It had a horseshoe design and no color. The staff at the hotel from check-in, casino, security,attendants at the pool and the restaurant were helpful, gracious and friendly. They have great customer service. This hotel is one I would recommend to friends and family.

Reviews.Title: “Vegas baby Vegas”
Reviews.Author: Bella306
Reviews.Content: I was in Vegas for my birthday in February... who knew it got cold in Vegas... Rug up - but besides the cold, I still had an awesome time. I definitely rate ARIA - it was brand new when I stayed there, so everything was pretty fresh. Had all the amenities that you need in the room including working the room by remote control.. yep.. from the bed... ARIA is right in the middle of everything on the strip - I have no complaints and highly recommend anyone to stay there. Next time i'm in Vegas - it will be the summer.

Reviews.Title: “Don't waste your time and money”
Reviews.Author: stb1026
Reviews.Content: Where to start... We booked this place because of a great deal and it looked beautiful. Reviews were all across the board, but it was new so we gave it the benefit of the doubt. I will get the positives out of the way, as there aren't many. - Hotel is beautiful, inside and out. - Smelled great, not too much of the Vegas cigarette stench. - Three pools were nice during the heat wave Vegas was experiencing. That's about it. I knew the place was going to be expensive, so I won't complain about drink prices or food or $15 blackjack tables. I knew what I was getting into. What I will complain about is the service. Check-in took forever as all reviews have stated, so we didn't get our room until about 6 hours after we arrived. Not a huge deal, as we got there early, but inconvenient. Worst part was we asked for a specific floor with our group because of a birthday, and they were great about it over the phone before the trip, but instead got a different room altogether on a different floor, complete opposite of what we asked about. This gem of a room had no working phone and the handle of the bathroom door fell off when we first used it. Had to go to the front desk to ask to get these fixed, and they never were. The room service attendant even made a comment about it Sunday night, called service again from a phone in the hallway and was told it couldn't be fixed until Monday. Thanks for the help. The door handle wasn't a huge deal, just really tacky. But the phone is a problem. What if there was an emergency? Well, there was, albeit in another room of our party. Said member spent all day sunday vomiting, to the point that we made the decision to take him to the hospital to get an IV (heat + not enough water + drinking too much the night before). So we called the concierge to have a wheelchair sent up so we could take our friend to the hospital, but spent 15 minutes on hold. So I went downstairs to get it myself only to be told that it would be 15 minutes before security could get one. At that point, friend was about to pass out and vomiting non-stop so I asked to call the medics. From there the situation was taken care of (and the friend was just fine) by the fine medical staff of Clark County. But when brought up to a manager how troubling it was that none of the hotel staff seemed to care about the situation, or didn't answer the phone or took their sweet time, it was implied to us that we called the wrong people. And that was it. I know that drinking too much and dehydration happen all the time in Vegas, but what if there was a life or death situation going on? Would they show this little concern for the well being of their patrons then? And what if that situation happened in my room, without the working phone? Nobody on the staff seemed to care at all, and that is troubling and anger-inducing. It was a frustrating weekend at this hotel. The few things that were great about the hotel were overshadowed by the bad things and the way handled any and all service. There is a lot of potential at Aria. There really is. But I will never go back to see if they realize it, and will never recommend that anyone else does either.

Reviews.Title: “It Couldv'e Been a 5 Star Hotel”
Reviews.Author: lilxlady27
Reviews.Content: Ok, so let me start off by saying my experience at Aria was wonderful. I really didn’t want to give it a 3 star..in fact, I wanted to give it a 5 star, but a couple of incidents occurred that dropped it down to a 4 star rating. As I was ready to write a review for this 4 star hotel, another incident occurred that dropped it down to a 3 star. So let’s begin my story… Check in: So me and the boyfriend arrived at Aria on July 16 – 18th at 9 in the morning. We wanted to get an early check in to avoid the long lines later and hopefully get our rooms. We weren’t even sure if they would even let us check in that early! We got in line and within 5 minutes we were able to get our Corner Suite, however, she gave us two option, take the room on the 4th floor which was ready, or wait for the room on the 21st floor for about an hour to be cleaned. I rather wait for a better view..and plus, we were there SUPER early, so can’t complain if the room was ready or not. We did the check in process so I wouldn’t have to do it later when I pick up my keys. She gave us a Panoramic Suite, which was awesome by the way. Check in was a breeze, she put a rush for our room to be cleaned. So we really appreciated that. Shout out to the best front desk girl RUBY! You rock girl! Thank you for making the first impression wonderful!!! To bad that’s her last week there. Room: Our Corner Suite was awesome!! Everything worked perfect. Bed was very comphy I love having a lot of pillows and that bed had plenty! LOVVVED the bathtub looking out to the city…loved the remote that controls everything..love how the curtains open up loved how the toilet had many cool features..hehe.. No complaints about anything in the room…UNTIL Saturday morning. So we woke up and decided to go out for breakfast. We always made sure to have our privacy light on because we didn’t want housekeeping in our room. So when we came back to our room, we noticed our cups outside our room..our tv was off (we had it on to make it seem like someone was in our room so housekeeping wouldn’t come in…but not like it mattered), our bed was made, the restroom was clean, etc. Normally, I wouldn’t complain about coming back to a clean room, but um..our privacy light was on..doesn’t that mean don’t come in? Luckily, most of our valuable was in the safe…I DOUBT she would’ve taken anything, but that’s besides the point..so I didn’t wanna be mean and take out 1 whole star…so I just took out ½ star. I understand mistake happens..but to future aria guest, just be careful. Casino: Lots of tables, lots of slots, lots of everything. It’s not as dark as some people say. At least in my opinion. At first we won money, then gave it all back and some!!! Overall, we had a good time at this casino..except for some minor issue which resulted in another negative ½ star. I was watching my bf play three card poker and we got carded, which is fine, we’re use to it. So he was trying to make small talk with the dealer and I guess she didn’t like it cause she would only answer him one word answers rudely and roll her big eyes at him. So he just left her alone. We didn’t get a good vibe from her..it felt like she hated her job. To top it off, she almost screwed him over. He beat her Ace High with a pair, and she still took his money!!! He said, “excuse me, why did you take my money? I beat u.” her response, “oh did I?” There was no apology whatsoever. Ugh, I understand accidents happen, but that’s our $60 u almost took! So a BIG SHOUT OUT to you KRISTY with big eyes and short curly hair! Please be more nice to your guest and pay more attention. To future players with her, watch your hands carefully. All in all, we had a great time. Food, pool, valet, everything was great. Check out was also quick. Happy with my time at the Aria. In comes Monday morning, I checked my bank account statement. Why did they charge me an extra $260? I called the front desk and they told me it was an “incidental charge”. Um, I never heard of that? She told me it’s for the usage of the gym, phone, internet, etc. So I asked her you guys charge that even though we didn’t use any of that? She told me if you didn’t use it, the bank will put it back into your bank account. Thanks for telling me in advance ARIA! What if I didn’t have enough money in my account?? Isn’t that something you should’ve told your guest? I don’t know if other people knew, but I certainly didn’t. I didn’t see it on their website, it wasn’t mentioned at checkout. Mentioning of that, why didn’t it show in my receipt you gave me during check out? She told me that it should show back into my account in a couple of days..so I’ll update this if I get it back or not. I’m not sure if I’d be back here, ill probably try Encore next time and compare my experience. Good luck future Aria guest!

Reviews.Title: “Problems Started at Registration”
Reviews.Author: grj0117
Reviews.Content: I was meeting a friend in Las Vegas to celebrate my birthday. Since we usually go to Las Vegas a couple of times a year, we thought we would give the lovely new Aria Hotel a try. We had made the reservations online through the hotel.....2 nights ...2 queen beds. Not a complicated request for most hotel, but the Aria seems to have a problem with that. We had paid in advance for the first night and had the receipt in hand, but there was not one room in the hotel which had 2 beds, or so we were told. We were given the option of a rollaway bed or we could use that courtesy phone in a distance to find lodging elsewhere. Since we were tired and really just wanted to relax, thus the reason for coming to Las Vegas, we opted for the rollaway bed. No one offered an apology for our inconvenience. We walked what seemed to be about 2 miles to our room. The fragrance which began in the Hotel Lobby permeates the entire hotel. That smell might work in the restrooms, but for god sake, not in the entire hotel. It's nauseating. The hallways are long, dark brown, narrow and poorly lighted. It was reminiscent of the really old Best Western from my childhood, but a much longer walk. Then we entered into "High-tech Curtain" land. I don't need or want my curtains computerized. If they must be computerized, make the computer work like a computer. I don't want to take classes to be able operate the curtains nor the lights and the television. And I certainly don't want to be sitting in the dark because of the preprogramming. The water closet in the bathroom is indeed, in a separate room, which sounds like it would work well for 2 friends traveling together, however the wall is made of glass. Now, if you are OK sitting on the toilet while your friend is brushing her teeth, then this would work for you, otherwise...NOT SO MUCH! There is a lovely soaking tub in the bathroom. But... in order to get into the tub, you have to walk through the shower stall. It is positioned back past the shower. Who thought that was a good idea? The hotel boast of their large guest rooms. I'm sure that square footage includes the bathroom and the glass water closet, plus the closets, dresser drawers and possibly the air ducts. There was not room for the lovely rollaway bed until my friend and I rearranged the furniture. The rollaway was left in the room, folded! No attempt was made to make it useable. We gambled in the hotel and had the same luck that we had at registration. So we decided to spend our money elsewhere. When it was time to check out, the wonderment continued. Supposedly that computer in your room works for checkout, not just to control your draperies, but ours didn't. We stood in line 30 minutes. But we were so glad to get out of this place, thirty minutes didn't seem so bad. But once it was actually our turn, they now deny that they have our advance deposit. Remember...we a receipt IN HAND! That was another 30 minutes and having to get fussy about talking to a manger! We had to pay a second time for that room. Now we are left with letting Visa fight the fight. On a positive note the housekeeping staff was very friendly and did a very nice job. The buffet which is served in a restaurant of the same name... "Buffet" was good...expensive, but good. It was not your $14.95 Las Vegas buffet. The customer service in this hotel is nonexistent, so if you want to spend your money and have a good time....Stay someplace else. This was a surprise to me since I have stayed in other MGM properties and have never experience this. MGM Resorts GET A NEW MANGER for this property, and teach customer service. I really don't have a suggestion for that color scheme and bathroom design until you have to redecorate and that might never happen if none of your customers return. Gayle Johnson Fort Collins, CO

Reviews.Title: “Great staff and location; beds, not so much”
Reviews.Author: sfjonathan
Reviews.Content: From the moment we arrived, we were treated politely and professionally. We enjoyed all interactions with the staff from the front desk to the bellmen. (The buffet was pretty good value too.) The only drawbacks were the beds. Each bed was overly soft and slanted. Rolling over could have landed you on the floor if you were too feisty. Everything else about the room was solid, including all the toy that controlled the drapes, TV, a/c. I'd stay there again but be firm about asking for a firm bed.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, not very hospitable”
Reviews.Author: KavitaNYC
Reviews.Content: The Aria is a beautiful hotel and is well situated on the strip. However, I have stayed at many luxury hotels before and the service here really needs to be better. It's a beautiful hotel but not very hospitable. $30 PER DAY to use the fitness center is ridiculous. I travel quite frequently and I have never stayed at a hotel that charges that much to use the fitness center. And by the way, I checked out the fitness center and it's nothing special that would justify something so ridiculous. There are refigerators in the rooms filled with minibar items but be careful not to even touch them or you will be charged. They have sensors under the items so they will know if you even picked up any items and you are automatically charged. Also, there are no in room coffee makers which I found extremely odd. I think it's a pretty basic request to have a coffee maker in your hotel room but the Aria doesn't think so...but they'll gladly send you up a kettle of hot water for $4 each morning ($28 for hot water for my 7 day stay). I would not stay at the Aria again because I don't like the feeling of being charged for EVERY little thing that is normally standard at any other luxury hotel (or even at bad hotels for that matter). For the money I paid I was expecting some hospitality which is something the Aria doesn't offer...or maybe there's an additional charge for hospitality. There are plenty of REAL luxury resorts on the strip and if I had to do it all over again I would have stayed elsewhere. I wouldn't call the Aria a bad hotel but it was a disappointment.

Reviews.Title: “Sterile place-great place for a convention”
Reviews.Author: vivavegas1965
Reviews.Content: When i got there they didnt have the room i booked with the the Vegas strip view and Shower and tub.They gave me the Vegas strip view but no tub and only 1 sink in bath which made it hard to put all wifes bath items in.shower was huge but didnt have a soap tray and place to put shampoo or soap.it had a seat for a older person to sit so you had to unfold that and put your soap and shampoo there but that was in the way of you standing under shower.the master switches for power was great. It was set up great for a person who is on business and is not looking for pleasure. the hotel and casino are huge,so much room that you think your walking around a convention center,casino was great in size.the tram is nice that goes to other casinos like Monte Carlo and Bellagio and they shopping . i would say if you play slots and are looking for penny slots this is the location,me personally i like 5 cent and higher slots.i would say its like a 20 to 1 ratio of penny slots to other higher slots. Thr hotel restaurants is very overly priced and have been same type of restaurnts where i live and there not this pricey.this was common theme heard among other guests that restaurants are nice but overly priced. The best restaurant was Besa very good food and recommend it. i wouldnt return to this hotel for leasure but for business yes i would.

Reviews.Title: “Aria is Better Than You Can Imagine!!”
Reviews.Author: Wowtotravel
Reviews.Content: Headed to Vegas for a few days of fun and r & r. From the minute I arrived, it was lovely. Kenny took our luggage and immediately explained that he loved his job and working here after explaining a few details about the resort. Check-in was flawless and luggage was delivered within 10 min. of calling downstairs. Room was fantastic and got an upper floor upgrade($15 per night) with great city views. Tub was large enough for 2, separate water closet, and great closet storage. Loved that the amenities(shampoo, conditioner, etc.) contain no sulfites, parabens, salt, petroleum products. Used the gym($30 per day seemed excessive) and it does include access to saunas, 3 temperature pools, showers, and outdoor co-ed area with jacuzzi and views of the Liquid pool(it's really obnoxious and loud when coming from serene spa area). Staff were attentive and not pushy about services. Appreciated the inclusion of water, headphones, toiletries, fruit, juices, coffee, sodas, and teas. It was a great way to spend a few days. Multiple day discounts are offered and the $30 per day fee is refunded if a spa service is booked on that day. Restaurants were exceptional (food, service, etc.). Prices were what one might expect at a resort of this caliber ($ 8-12 appetizers, $15-25 entrees, $8-25 for drinks). I did not have a bad meal. Portions were european perfect and the freshness of ingredients was fantastic!! I enjoyed the Cafe and Thai (outstanding). Hotel is close enough (10-15 min walk) to other resorts to take advantage of Starbucks or other more economical choices if needed. Overall, I would go back in a heartbeat. The vibe is elegant, serene, and very romantic. Perfect for a couples getaway as not too many kids running around. Clientele seemed to be, even in the heart of summer, created a much more sophisticated and relaxed atmosphere. A great adult getaway.

Reviews.Title: “Aria Las Vegas Hates Customers”
Reviews.Author: ChrisWarwick_NewYork
Reviews.Content: The Aria Las Vegas is the worst hotel I have ever stayed in. For the first 12 hours it was great. The second day, apparently we didn't pay enough to have our room cleaned. When I called to point this out, they argued with me, but "agreed" to send someone up to clean the room. It has been 4 hours and no one has shown up to take care of it. Very disappointing

Reviews.Title: “I am glad someone else selected the hotel”
Reviews.Author: hkparadise
Reviews.Content: Spent 5 days at Aria. Most reveiwers had it right. The staff were generally non-caring; the housekeeping (turn down service) and engineering requests (light bulbs out) were essentially ignored. After multiple calls the light bulb was replaced the morning we left. The young staff members were enthusiastic, mostly at the pools, but the bartenders were curt and not particularly adept. The heat outside was oppressive (about 110 degrees) so the pools, all three, were packed with shrieking children and dozing parents. The brunch was adequate but better at the Bellagio Hotel. Something changed since our last time in Vegas. No one was winning, no one. Maybe the recession forced them to change the odds in the hotel's favor? Stopped gambling entirely after two days. And it wasn't only our hotel either. The Lemon Grass restaurant was very good. Our server, Van, was outstanding! We stopped by on our night of arrival for the two of us and it was reasonably priced and the selections were great. So we invited a group of about 8 to join us later in the trip for another meal there. Van lived up to his newly made reputation and we all loved our dinners and wines. I don't think we will return to this property.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay”
Reviews.Author: ButterAlberta
Reviews.Content: A brand new hotel. Not themed as the other hotels are on the strip - unless you can say that modern is a theme. It IS modern. Bed rooms large bright and fresh - becasue it is new but also because of superior air circulation. Casino did not seem smoky becasue of this and therefore pleasant to be in. Bed amazingly soft and wonderful to sleep in! 5 star hotel and it tried to live up to 5 star. Window was one wall top to bottom - great view. Drapes drawn, music on, etc by the touch of a button and could program music and drapes to open as a wake up. Service was always helpful, polite and friendly. No long line ups anywhere. Attention to detail was not great - there was always something missing from the room - faceclothes one day , a robe the next. Always replaced so no big deal but just not quite up to 5 star standard for housekeeping. Plenty of places to eat but not great cuisine (we didn't try the high end restaurants). I found them expensive for what they were - but that seems to be the case wherever you are on the strip. Breakfast bufet extensive from roast lamb to scrambled eggs and everything in between. At $15 per person make sure you want to eat lots - we did brunch. No coffee in the room. Nice not to have that mess and I'm sure it's environmentally friendlier but really annoying not to be able to have a cup of coffee first thing in the morning without getting dressed and going to get one or paying way over t he top for room service. Internet very expensive. Beautiful swimming pools, not crowded. Crystal shopping centre next door and a good route to get onto the strip - very high end. One of the things to do away from the strip is the Atomic Testing Museum . Really really interesting, well presented and well worth a visit. We walked there from the strip - about 25 mins. ( a taxi would be 5 mins.). We usually used the Duece/Ace transit to get around. Worth it to get a 3 day ticket and then can use at anytime to go up and down the strip and to downtown and the Outlet Stores. We went downtown - again worth the visit both daytime and evening (with light show and outdoor live music). We liked the Golden Gate Hotel and casino - the oldest casino in Vegas - and used it as our place to have lunch/brunch. Good food and reasonable price in historic restaurant. .

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, Clean and Modern”
Reviews.Author: mikenchris
Reviews.Content: Spent July 4th weekend here in a corner room on the 33rd floor..I honestly can't understand any bad reviews of this hotel..It makes me wonder if I stayed in the same hotel as others who have written comments..This place is clean, modern, conveniently located, hotel restaurants (pricey) but good...The pools are fantatstic..No smell of smoke anywhere in the hotel including the casino..The corner room I had was huge and maintained very well...Don't be afraid to stay here..

Reviews.Title: “If I had the option to go again, I won't.”
Reviews.Author: xxdjtyperxx
Reviews.Content: Okay this my first review on this website but I'll be thorough. I'm an avid Vegas goer. I've seen and stayed at a few hotels and know the ropes. So I decided to give Aria a try. I went with my girlfriend during the week, with another couple and we all stayed at Aria. We took the shuttle from the airport, we were dropped off in the BACK. Like literally a REALLY sketchy basement looking entrance. I was paranoid as hell wondering wth the driver was taking us. But apparently the Front desk told me the shuttles drop you off in the back and the taxis drop you off in the front. The front desk was very nice and I requested for a strip view, in which she did give us one, but it my god the walk from the elevator to the hotel room was the longest walk ever. Upon arriving to the room, the music turns on and the curtains open up to show a cool view (the strip for us) and well first thing we noticed was a pull out bed right there. (We never asked for one nor requested). Easy fix, house keeping came and took it away no problem. Then we checked out the bathroom. Very nice, modern and contemporary. Shower and tub together. I soon look over at the soap dishes and find, 3 bars of soap (all Aria's). Weird thing was, one of them was out of the wrapper sitting out on the soap dish, the second one in its original plastic packaging, the third one was flat out in the shower right next to what apparently looked like a half used Aria shampoo bottle. MY question is, how the hell does housekeeping miss these things?! Do they hope that we'll reuse them?? Okay, no problem for me, I ignored it and threw them away, I figured no big deal, easy fix. I meet with the other couple and find out that upon entering their bathroom, there is a huge women's granny-panty right there hanging on the shower. I was like WTF! you can't be serious and he said he was. About location, this hotel is seriously the farthest from everyyythinggg. I could barely make it to Harrahs for a walk. There is a shortcut cutting through the mall or taking the monorail which STILL requires a ton of walking. Overall this hotel had the spirit of "All show, no go." It may look alot like a 5 star hotel, but the service, housekeeping, and overall general up-keeping of this hotel was that of a three star quality. (I've stayed at the Wynn, and Treasure Island, and Harrah's so I know the difference between 5-4-3 star hotels) This place will NEVER beat out the Wynn. They need to step up their game and have some incentives for staying here. I don't think I will ever return here unless I somehow got a free room or a dirt cheap rate that I cannot resist. Other than that I'd take my business elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, tech-friendly, comfortable, affordable, just not particularly special”
Reviews.Author: Mgz
Reviews.Content: I stayed for 2 nights at a promotional rate of $79, which included 2 buffets and 2-1 tickets to the Viva Elvis show (which I didn't attend). Although my business this week is at the Venetian, I wanted to check out this new property. Overall, this is a lovely, striking complex, part of the new City Center set of retail and lodging. I found staff helpful, though a little stiff on average. There are striking works of art, some extremely large (like the solid silver replica of the Colorado River over the front desk), and very interesting overall, so if you stay here, take a little time to walk around. There is a pamphlet to guide you through the art. My room on the 12th floor was spotless and well appointed. Major pluses: what I believe was a 54" HDTV, though they advertise 42". A large shower/tub area, desk and two large seats in bedroom, and a very comfortable bed, with a soft surface but firm enough for most. The hotel was designed with technology in mind. I love the input panel on the desk. The panel has connectiosn to the TV, including HDMI, VGA, USB, iPod/iPhone, S-Video, VGA and others. With the right cord, you can connect your laptop or iPod to the TV and sound system. Further, the curtains, lights, clock and TV can either be controlled via wall switches, the TV remote, or the bedside panel. I've seen reviews from those confused by this, but honestly, I can't understand the frustration, as it's pretty straightforward. Heck, there is even an "everything off" switch at the door. The casino is on par with other 4 and 5 star hotels in the area: lots of gaming, slots, video poker, etc, and about 2 dozen restaurants. Try Todd English's P.U.B. - relatively affordable, excellent, simple food, and a great beer selection, just across the entrance from the Aria. The pool area is nice, but uninspiring. About 4-5 large pools surrounded by lounges and umbrellas. There is cocktail service at the chairs and a walk-up bar, but know that you cannot drink in the pool. The only exception is at Liquid, a modestly sized, reservation-only pool club with a smallish pool, about 1/3 the size of the other pools. During my stay, it was pretty quiet outside, unlike, for example, Monte Carlo with it's disco parties. Whatever works for you, of course. I suppose most folks are justified in rating this as 5 star. If I could, I would've used 4 1/2. Again, it's a beautiful property with a lot going for it. However, it just didn't have that special energy or character that a few of the best hotels have. Venetian has it's larger rooms. Bellagio has it's stunningly gorgeous artwork and architecture throughout and fantastic pool. Even the dated Mirage has a welcoming casino floor with it's palms and such. Aria didn't have that for me. So, don't hesitate to stay here, just be aware that it may not have the character that makes top properties stand out so well.

Reviews.Title: “DIRTY ROOMS, TERRIBLE CHECK IN, DO NOT GO”
Reviews.Author: JohnieNNJ
Reviews.Content: The check in is so unorganized, it was survival of the fittest. After the hour check in at midnight coming from the east coast i immediately went to bed. When I woke up in the morning and got out of bed, I noted a few large pubic hairs in my bed. I KNEW immediately they were not mine!!! I got up as I felt disgusted and went to the bathroom, when I looked in the shower, there was women's hair all over the shower, the floor and the walls of the shower. I was so disgusted I called the front desk and asked to be moved- they told me they could not do that. But they transferred me to the housekeeping desk, as i was sitting on the couch explained to housekeeping what was going on, i looked down at the floor and saw toe nail clippings all over. I was so repulsed!!! They came up and cleaned the room for a few hours as I left. This was so unacceptable to me. As a health professional i was appalled at the condition of the room and how they did not move me or even credit anything toward me. I will really have to think twice about going back to this hotel (unless i get the red carpet treatment). I hope this is not the same experience for others as it was a horrible beginning of a weekend trip!!!

Reviews.Title: “Nice place. Still like THEhotel at Mandalay Bay better.”
Reviews.Author: JCashMoney
Reviews.Content: We received three comped nights from Aria and decided to check it out. Check in was a breeze at the invited guest counter. I gave the clerk a $20 and asked him if there were any upgrades available. He told us that we were in luck that there was a room on the 50th floor with a seating area. It turns out that it wasn't an upgraded room at all. Thanks for nothing. The rooms are very nice, albeit smaller than rooms at THEhotel at Mandalay Bay which is where we typically stay. I like the idea of a sitting room and seperate bedroom much better. I also missed having two bathrooms like at THEhotel. There was an issue with the control panel for the room not working. However, they had it fixed by the time we came back from dinner. I'm not sold on the view from Aria, as it's akin to staying in Manhattan. Even with a "strip view" room on the 50th floor you look out over what is truly a city; thus "City Center." The windows were dirty, with large handprints on them. The overhang above the window does have the brownish dirt that others have complained of. It's no doubt from when it rains and the dust drips down. Flat front hotels (read, virtually all others in Vegas) wouldn't have this problem, as there's nothing for the dirt to collect on. The pools are nice. However, nothing beats the Beach at Mandalay Bay. These aren't your typical 'party down' type pools, as they are much more laid back. This isn't necessarily a bad thing. There is an adults only pool club (Liquid) that looked like it was rockin' if that's your thing. We ate at the buffet on Friday night which included a lobster to split for two people and all you could drink wine. The buffet was good, however not as good as the Bellagio. Like the Bellagio though, they do charge you an 18% gratuity if you have a party larger than 8 and you want to sit together. That just might be the biggest rip off in Vegas, as it's a buffet! Our two buffet's were comped in the offer we received, so just paying the gratuity wasn't terrible. We also ate at Café Vettro which was good food, but expensive, and the Skybox Sports Bar and Grill, which also was good but expensive. Lastly, we ate at Jean Philippe Patisserie which has fantastic pasteries. The Cirque Viva Elvis show was good, but definitely not my favorite Cirque show. If you haven't seen any of the Cirque shows I'd reccomend seeing O at the Bellagio and Ka at the MGM before seeing Viva Elvis. Our comp offer included 2 for 1 Viva Elvis tickets in the VIP area. I would not pay $200 each for the tickets. However, with the 2 for 1 they were $200 for both. The VIP area is extremely nice, as the seats are more like couches and there's tons of leg room. However, our friends bought cheap tickets and ended up getting moved down there because there was space available. The bottom line, don't pay $200/ticket for the show. The casino is darker than most. However, it's nowhere near as dark as some have complained. I didn't necessarily like the layout of the casino floor as much as some other properties, as it wasn't as open feeling. It feels like everything is on top of each other. The gambling was good. However, my credit line was payable in 7 days as opposed to the 30 days I have on my line at Mandalay Bay. Why this is the case is anyone's guess, as the credit department for all MGM properties is run out of the Bellagio. Strange. Thankfully it didn't end up mattering, as we came out ahead on our gambling. When we stay at THEhotel the VIP office makes our club reservations for us, or gives us the cell phone number of one of the door men so we don't have to wait in club lines. This was not the case at Aria, as I was told that I would have to make reservations directly through the Light Nightclub group. I ended up contacting my host at the Palms and he comped us directly into Moon without waiting in line. I would have liked to have had the same benefit at Haze nightclub at Aria. I simply refuse to wait in a huge line for hours to get into a club. I did have an opportunity to use the spa at Aria, which was very nice. I didn't necessarily like the fact that there are portions of the spa that are co-ed. All told, the trip was a blast and Aria was nice. Would I stay there again if the rooms were comped? Absolutely. Would I pay to stay there verses staying at THEhotel? I'd stay at THEhotel first.

Reviews.Title: “Aria was a refreshing place to stay and wasn't corny or overly pretentious in design”
Reviews.Author: rubix5
Reviews.Content: This was my first time visiting Las Vegas and we couldn't have picked a better hotel to stay at. We were pleasantly surprised by the design and decor within the hotel and casino. The hotel was a modern, contemporary style that didn't seem it would be outdated in years to come. The designer did a beautiful job designing every last detail in the hotel. The rooms were comfortable and relaxing to stay in. We loved how technology was integrated into the lifestyle of staying at the hotel. The view was breathtaking. The location was set right in the middle of the strip, where you want to be when visiting Vegas. We ate several times at Cafe Vettro, which was opened 24/7 and within the hotel. The prices seemed a little pricey but the portions are well worth it as well as the taste and service. When we visit Las Vegas again, we will definitely stay at Aria again. Compared to the other hotels on the Strip, Aria was a place that you could stay at and not get tired of staying for more than 1-2 days. The other hotels were theme-based and fun to walk through and visit, but we enjoyed coming back to the hotel for a break from the 100+ degree heat.

Reviews.Title: “Contemporary Comfort!”
Reviews.Author: PDXFolks
Reviews.Content: We spent 4th of July weekend at the Aria and with the mixed reviews, weren't sure what to expect. But, since new hotel properties often have their glitches to work through, we decided to give it a try. I've stayed at most of the strip hotels, including Bellagio, Paris, Luxor, Mirage, Treasure Island and Monte Carlo. I must say, my husband and I were very pleased. We arrived rather late - around 9pm so there wasn't much of a line. The Front Desk Agent was very friendly and accomodating. We asked about a city view room and were informed that it would cost an additional $15 per night so we decided to skip it. She spent a generous amount of time locating a room with a nice view on an upper floor. We were pleased to see that the corridor was glass and overlooked the strip. Our room overlooked another tall, glass structure and wasn't what I'd consider to be an unpleasant view, although it wasn't awesome either. The Bellman arrived immediately and was beyond friendly and helpful! His first order of business was to show my husband how to use the in room technology features which I didn't pay attention to. He then observed that we had stopped at the liquor store and ran for some ice! I will also mention, the TV, light switches etc. may also be operated via traditional remote and wall switches as well. The room was nicely appointed and very spacious. We loved the floor to ceiling windows! It offered his and hers closets and lots of dresser drawers. The bathroom had double sinks as well as a private water closet. The combined shower and soak tub were a nice feature too! I liked the bed but it was a little soft. I must mention though, we own an extremely nice bed so I'm not one of those people who are blown away by hotel beds. The linens were lovely and soft. In terms of the technology, I can take or leave that sort of thing but it was neat. I must note, for those who prefer black out window treatments, these let a bit of light in through the top. The room is still restfully dark for napping but you definitely know it's daytime. We worked out in the gym and the $30 fee includes access to the spa as well. It's superb but it would be nice to pay a slighter fee to just exercise. The pools were great but a bit understaffed. Our first day out, we sat for nearly two hours before we were offered a drink. There's a huge cooler with complimentary cups and freezing water which was all we were after in the 100 degree sun anyway so we were okay. We ate at two of the restaurants and they were very good. The cafe right below the elevators offers beautful pastries, fresh fruit and coffee if you're on the run. The $7 fruit bowl was actually worth the price. They are very careful to check for room keys so I felt secure and safe. I noticed many comments on how the machines were tight but really, come on! This is Vegas and the majority of players don't come out in the black. We won and lost - didn't notice a difference between this casino and others. Overall, I'd call this a positive experience!

Reviews.Title: “BEST BIRTHDAY”
Reviews.Author: IrvineBeary
Reviews.Content: We booked a Southwest Airlines vacation package for three days & had a fantastic time. At check in, we upgraded to a corner room & this was the best view of the strip. The room was immaculate, more like a nice 4 room apartment in a quiet location on the corner. All of the electronics are handled through your TV, room temp, audio, visuals, drapes, sheers are all opened, closed, etc. through the easy remotes. Enjoy the fantastic views from each room & have a great time in your room before you head down to the pool, casino, the Elvis theater and the many, mnay ammenties offered at this 5 star resort. Valet parking is the best - Call ahead to the Valet & your car will be brought and ready for your departure. The Valet & Main Counter staff are the best in Las Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible customer service”
Reviews.Author: JohnathonTaylor
Reviews.Content: The hotel and casino are amazing but housekeeping and customer service leaves much to be desired. During my week stay at the Aria, the housekeepers repeatedly shuffled through my personal effects, went through my bags, discarded my personal property, and removed room items without replacing them (glasses, robes, linens, etc). When I called down to housekeeping I sat on hold for a significant amount of time before finally giving up. When calling down to the front desk, the wait was less and I was promised that a housekeeping manager would come up to speak with me. As of writing this, I've been waiting over 90 minutes for someone to take time to even talk to me about my dissatisfaction. As a frequent visitor to Las Vegas, I've never experienced such a substandard housekeeping experience. Over the years I've stayed in places ranging from the Excaliber to the Venetian and I've NEVER had someone move or remove my personal property from my room, and I've never experienced such disregard for my customer satisfaction. The view, the amenities, and the restaurants are excellent, next time I'll just stay next door at the Bellagio and maybe walk next door for my Crepes. The Aria isn't a Motel 6, I expect better when I'm paying hundreds of dollars per night to stay here. I am wholly dissatisfied.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, but very expensive!”
Reviews.Author: Thyan
Reviews.Content: Recently stayed at the Aria for business. Very modern hotel and beautiful decor. Rooms have been described by many other travelers, so I will not go into detail. Very comfortable bed. I will say that it is a very expensive hotel. No coffee maker in the room. Coffee in the lobby $8. Had a breakfast sandwich and a cup of tea and paid $16! Fitness center was an additional charge of $30 per day. Internet $12 per day. Margarita by the pool was $12 plus tip. VERY loud in the casino area at night. Be prepared to spend if you stay there.

Reviews.Title: “Tried it.......Will Pass on the Aria Next Time”
Reviews.Author: GallivanterDallas
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just got back from a stay at the Aria and must say that this "Aria" struck a sour chord with us and here's why: - After 7 trips to Vegas, the Aria holds the distinction of being the only hotel/casino to NOT have the non smoking King suite ready that we had reserved when we arrived. This after multiple calls to them to confirm that it would be ready days before we left Dallas. We were not the only ones either....the front desk was filled with UPSET people who were not getting the rooms and suites that they had reserved well in advance (one couple next to us had reserved months before). To be fair, the front desk staff were great, but the managers were terrible. By terrible I mean non responsive and down right sarcastic. I am a manager and deal with customer service all the time.....the front desk manager was a no show. So, we ended up with what they said was an "upgraded" dual queen suite which proved to be a total misnomer. - The room was disappointing. I have stayed in Hampton Inn suites that were as nice or nicer than this room and were much larger, last week in fact. The vaunted technology was incorrectly installed as the switches for the room lights were cross wired so you had to walk across the room to control the other side and visa versa. What we read was that the Aria was initially designed for the convention market and when that went south, they tried to retool for the leisure market and they are missing that mark in my estimation. - The mattresses were marshmallows. Soft is not the word. They are unsupportive and if you have any back issue whatsoever, you will wake up sore or worse. - I am used to things be expensive in Vegas, but the Aria takes it to another level. Two cups of coffee and two danishes....$25. Give me a break. - I know that the slots are tight on the strip, but we usually here at lease one someone win a decent pot over a 4-5 day period. This time, nothing. Not one. - We went to the pool area which was packed as one entire pool was not working and off limits. To be fair, here are the positives: - We stayed on the 27th floor and the view of City Center was really great. - The decor of the hotels and rooms was very modern and well done throughout. It certainly had the finish out of a high end resort. - The room linens were of the finest quality and they have all the toiletries you could need gratis except for a razor. - The combination of glassed in large shower with adjacent large soaking tub was really neat. Liked that a lot. - Although grossly overpriced, the food and drink at the restaraunts was good. - The staff, excluding the managers,were extremely helpful, polite and downright nice! They will go out of there way to assist you if you even have a hint of confusion on your face which was refreshing. - It was very conveniently located and much of the strip is withing walking distance. You can actually go straight to the Monte Carlo without going outside and enjoy shopping and a food court on the way. - Thankfully, the video check out worked smoothly, sparing me another trip to the front desk. Here is some input that is neither good nor bad in my opionion, just not our cup of tea. - The place is filled with what looks to be Paris Hilton & Kim Kardashian wanna be's. 20 and 30 somethings dressed to the hilt absolutely fill this place. - As such the restaraunts, bars and clubs cater to this age group and as 40 somethings, we felt a bit out of place, but one thing is for sure, the place is hopping with the hip and trendy. So there you have it...the straight word. Do not get sucked in by the website which is, obviously, very cool. When we return to Vegas, it will probably be back to the Venetian where a suite is actually a suite, which I CAN recommend to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome hotel and casino, I agree do not believe what you read.”
Reviews.Author: lvegasgirl
Reviews.Content: My husband and I got to Vegas on July 3rd, our driver from Aria was waiting for us in the luggage area. Went through a back gate and checked in at Sky Suites registration desk, probably took 3 - 4 minutes. Got to the room (not a suite) on the 22nd floor and the bellman was standing at the door with our luggage. Beautiful room, lucious bed! Everything can be turned on at the touch of a button, you do not have to use the remote control. There is a safe large enough for your laptop, located in the bottom drawer of the night stand. All the staff we encountered were professional and very friendly. Maid service was great. We play a lot of video poker at the bars and all the bartenders were so friendly and helpful. We loved this place. We were worried about the location, but it was no big deal to get anywhere. We will be back!

Reviews.Title: “Breathtaking!!!”
Reviews.Author: ucralumni2005
Reviews.Content: This place was amazing, when you walk in you instantly smell the nice vanilla type aroma. We stayed in a suite and it was amazing with breathtaking views of the strip. If you want to feel like you're living life in the fast lane, this is it. Stay here and you will feel like you're rich for a day. Love it!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent, Much Better Than Anticipated”
Reviews.Author: PSMikeD
Reviews.Content: Was a little skeptical of Aria after reading some of the reviews here, but was very pleasantly surprised by the place. Read a lot on here about poor customer service, but our experience was excellent overall - staff was consistently friendly and helpful. Pool area was great, not too crowded, and a good mix of people. Really like the rooms as well - the remote control feature was really slick (and im not a tech guy by any means) and the beds were crazy comfortable. Best on the strip. Probably only gripe here would be a general lack of relatively inexpensive dining options. Wasnt shocked by this, its a higher end property and you expect that in LV, but it would have been nice to have one or two places for an inexpensive, quick bite. Not a big deal though. The places we did eat at on site were excellent, especially American Fish. Overall, a great experience and a place I would return to.....

Reviews.Title: “Pretty Bow.... but!”
Reviews.Author: hotsummer70
Reviews.Content: This hotel is definitely a looker but leaves a lot to desire. The Good: • Since I am a techie, the room was definitely a plus. The technology that was present in the room is what you would find in high end homes. The décor is very modern, which also appeals to me and the room is very spacious. When you hit the “Good Night” button everything shuts down, lights, TV, curtains close…. “Good Night”! • The pool area is very nice. The Cabana area is definitely a nice touch, very spacious. • Jean Georges Steak House was good. The waiter was very attentive and offered to bring out different sauces for the table to sample on their steaks. The usable wall of wine that also doubled as décor is very nice. The Bad: • The key in the service industry is "Service" and it was lack luster at ARIA and since I have seen some posts in regards to the service at the hotel, I was not surprised. Upon arriving at the hotel there were not a lot of people waiting to be checked-in, as I have seen at other hotels in the past. The check in process was very slow. The person helping me check in was very pleasant but never the less the process was ‘”Slow”, which no traveler wants after traveling all day. • The room service was “Slow” as well which I experienced after leaving the front desk. Upon placing my order I was given the standard statement, “We will have your food to your room in 50min or less”. Well it took 1hr and 25mins. Both I and my wife feel asleep waiting on the food. The attendant was very apologetic about us having to wait and gave us a complementary tray of chocolate covered strawberries for the long wait. Now I haven’t did any type time study to determine if room service is faster or slower during certain times of night or day but we ordered our food in Vegas @ 1ish in the morning. I am quite sure that a lot of the guest where out doing what they do in Vegas, not ordering room service and then turning in for the night. So what I am saying is there is no excuse for this type of tardiness. • The restaurant Café Vettro continued the theme of poor ‘Service’. The restaurant had very few people when my party was seated to eat and continued to have very few during our stay. The wait after our order was taking was very lengthy and we had to ask for refills of drinks at the table. When our food finally arrived at the table the waiter was very apologetic about us having to wait and issued out our respective dishes, well all but one. My order was not one of the dishes issued out. The waiter told me that he had to go back and get mine. I was thinking that he would be right back because he didn’t have room on his tray to bring all of the orders, “Wrong”! After about 6 or 7 minutes of waiting for my order, I asked the waiter where was my order, which he stated that it would be right out and I stated that my order would be free for this foul up and wanted to see the manager. The manager did comp a couple of the parties’ food and apologized for the wait. When my food did arrive the French Fries that I ordered where cold and I had to request “HOT Fries”! Also one of the persons in our party ordered Lemon Aid and never received it. So to say the least this was not a pleasant dining experience.

Reviews.Title: “My girlfriends and I had a very enjoyable stay at this hotel!!!”
Reviews.Author: jsl_00
Reviews.Content: I went to Las Vegas over the fourth of July weekend with 3 of my girlfriends - we are 25/26 years old. Overall, I thought the hotel was great (We stayed at Caesar's in 2009). We arrived Thursday morning at 9am and checked in right away - we got exactly what we requested (non smoking room and 2 queen beds). We had a crappy view on the 7th floor but we didn't care at all - we were happy to be able to check in early and get 2 beds (given that we've read many reviews where they run out of rooms w/ two beds!). The rooms were very modern and clean. The bathroom is spacious and nice. I thought the rooms here were nicer than the ones at Caesars (we stayed in one of the new towers at CP in the year before which had smaller beds). The beds here are super comfy! There IS a safe in the room - we had difficulties finding it at first - it is in the nightstand drawer in between the beds. No ipod dock though which I thought was weird. We were also warned not to touch anything on the mini bar or in the fridge as it is all sensored and you will be charged for those items. At 6am one morning, the battery in our smoke detector was beeping non stop - we had to call front desk twice to have someone come up - they were apologetic and gave us a $50 voucher for any of the hotel restaurants and a service person came up immediately after the second phone call. The swimming pool area is large - we never had any issues finding loungers near the main pool. We ate at the buffet which was okay - seemed pricy at $35 per person. We also ate at the Steakhouse which was delicious. The hotel/casino smells amazing - a vanilla scent throughout. Some ppl maybe thought it was too strong but it was way better than the smell of cigarettes in all the other hotels we walked through. Overall, I would recommend this hotel. I probably would try something new the next time I was in Vegas, but this hotel is nice and the service was decent. In a hotel this size, you can't expect all your requests to be met immediately. The location is good as it is within walking distance to Bellagio and CP and there are back ways that the cabs take to the hotels further down the strip so that you're not stuck in traffic so long.

Reviews.Title: “I would never stay in this hotel again!”
Reviews.Author: gracielou510
Reviews.Content: This is the second time I have stayed in this hotel. The first time I came with a couple of girls for a bachelorette party the room was beautiful and the place was very comfortable. How ever the service was bad, we ordered room service and it came up after two hours and the food was cold. The next day our tiolet broke and it took them 4 hours to come and fix it, after so many calls, we had about nine room key because every time we would try to get into our room the keys did not work. When I'm coming to sleep at 4 Am the last thing I want to do is go to the front dest and have more keys made! This July I decided to give them another chance, I was thinking maybe when we visited the first time they were very new and have not gotten things together. On check in I didn't get the two beds I reserved b/c they told me that the rooms were all sold out and that it was not a guarantee anyone would get two beds b/c they do not charge extra for two beds, and that they couldn't do anything about it, untill some one checks out, which was two days after, the lady at the front desk did not have good customer service. I feel like this hotel should hire more employees that are hospitable and knowledgeable about the hotel

Reviews.Title: “Changed my mind”
Reviews.Author: orignals
Reviews.Content: I read many reviews here due to the fact of the hotel booking agent didn't seem to knowledgeable and could not answer my questions. At the same time, she was offering me something different then the promotion that was mailed out to me. And I asked her if there would be any special promotions I can qualify for a free stay she mention about a $50.00free play, when the special promotion I received was for $100.00. Once I mentioned that, she could not answer me back like if she was pulling a quick one on me. This is what made me double check what this hotel is all about. Not including all the write up's I found here. I made a decision to cancel my reservation due to an overall opinions here and first time service when booking the call. They did not even give me a confirmation number like the majority of the hotels I've stayed here in Las Vegas for the last 12 years. I got mixed vibes from there service team. I don't trust you, so why should I ruin my stay especially on my birthday weekend because your team lacks of training and customer service. Forget it..... I'm going back to Ballagio.... I will never refer or think about staying at your hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Not your typical Vegas hotel”
Reviews.Author: halycon-1
Reviews.Content: It has been 5 years since we went to Vegas. We're not gamblers but for our 20th anniversary, my wife decided to book us 3 nights at this new hotel. We drove from LA and upon arriving at the hotel, I noticed the entry was huge. To park at the valet, we parked away from the entry., carried our luggages and hauled it all the way to the check-in counter. This was not how I wanted to experience my first visit to this hotel, it is big therefore you can easily be ignored by the bell boys. Upon entering the lobby, I was surprised about the vastness of the hotel. It was well lighted, comfortable yet cold. I could tell they spent al lot of time on the lines and curves, amazing architecture. We arrived at 2:30 pm and we were told our room at the 52nd floor was not going to be ready until pm. They offered pass to the pool but our luggage was already with the bell captain. After 5 hours of driving, I just wanted to lay down and rest a bit. We decide to have a snack at Todd English Bistro and the noules mrieneres was excellent and so was the fair selection of beer. When we returned to the front desk, all she could tell me was that my room was not going to be ready until after 5 pm or maybe 6 pm. And she wasn't even apologetic about it. I was ready to move to another hotel until my wife reminded her it was our anniversary and she softened and gave us a city view at the 34th floor. By now, I will take the 2nd floor lobby just to lay down. The room - spacious, modern, powered curtains, clean bathrooms. Nice. The bed was soft and comfortable. The view was fine, note spectacular. Figuring out the electronics drove me, a techno geek to madness. How the heck do I close the curtains without turning all the lights. I feel sorry for the old couple figuring this room out. Where's the safe? Nada! None. What, a modern hotel with no safe? The casino - though I am not a gambler, I did enjoy the expanse of the gambling hall. I compared it with the surrounding hotels and depending on you preference, the Aria casino may be cavernous, liberating, or just lacking intimacy. After all, architecture is the theme. I am a photo hobbyist and I enjoyed the amount of time spent on the design of every corner of the complex. The pool - 3 large pools, one for kids. Quite area for adults. Nothing fancy, comfortable, but busy. I feel like there is always a conference here. My friend recommended the Palazzo for a quieter hotel and pool area.. The food - the buffet was very disappointing. Though there were lots of meat, I only eat fish and veggies. They did have lots of crab legs, some shrimp, miniscule sushi rolls, and lox was the only fish served. Their chinese area was blah! blah! blah!. Go to M Hotel for the best buffet for the price, the locals go there. Lots of restaurant choices but be ready to spend money. Nothing in this hotel is cheap. The show: Elvis...forget it. Wished we didn't watched it at all. What we liked: we enjoyed having a quite drink and night cap at the Mandarin Oriental. Having the monorail to Bellagio also was convenient. The Crystal complex mall was awesome if you want to buy exclusive stuff. Treasure hunting for the various art work around the City Center was fun. The management was willing to listen to our suggestions. Big question: would we return to his hotel. Yes. Is ti worth it, probably not. This is Vegas after all. If you want to experience New York, Italy or France, just fly there. I would. But if you just want a place to sleep in and feel comfortable, the room was good enough for me to come back. Just don't eat the buffet. Oh yeah, one downer.....you have to pay for internet access and $30 per day per person to use the gym. Oh well....what happens in Vegas...is that you have less money when you leave.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel in Vegas!”
Reviews.Author: kclop10
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at Aria over the 4th of July weekend for a little relaxation. This hotel is the best I've stayed at in Vegas and I've been there many times. The staff could NOT be more friendly. We were helped by 3 different employees from the cab to the front desk. Check-in was simple. The room is gorgeous with floor to ceiling windows, and everything in the room is remote controlled (curtains, climate control, lights, etc.) The bed was very comfortable too which I didn't expect. This truly is a 5 start hotel and we had a 5 star experience. The hotel and casino have so much energy and are always busy. Perfect for the younger crowd! I won't stay anywhere else in Vegas!

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, new hotel with ups & downs”
Reviews.Author: Ölli
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the Aria on Independane Day Weekend this year with a friend. It was my fourth Las Vegas visit within 10 years, last stays included Monte Carlo, Bellagio and THE Hotel @ Mandalay Bay. All being MGM signatures. It was my first visit with no major construction on the strip going on, which was great in itself. One year ago, the new CityCenter had not even opened. So here we are. First the basics:There are some things in LV casino resorts which - opposite to other revievers - don't freak me out any more: a) long walkways (almost ever to cross the casinos) from self parking (go with it, at least it is free - or use valet) b) crowded check-ins in particular on weekends (stay calm an relaxed, come past 3pm and earlier than 6pm) c) Fancy and overpriced shopping & eating @ on site locations (eat & shop elsewhere or invest in the buffets on site if one giant meal per day does it for you) d) Clean rooms just on first view (if you had some thousand room changes a day with messy guests - you clean could you be on a budget?) e) Unorganized Front Desk, almost no personal touch (new computer systems, loads of work, high number of staff -> nope, you cannot do much better on a budget, really) --- I would take the said issues as given; still Aria has some special ups and downs from my point of view based on this weekend stay: Downs: 1) I booked a room with "strip view" (=City View category) on a "high level" with "two queens" via a travel agency. None of that got transmitted to the hotel (which of course is NOT the hotels fault in any way). I got to 18th floor (50+ floors available) in a one king room with a partly view on the strip while mainly overseeing CityCenter entrance. View could be better but was fine, still I asked for a room change on the other issues which they promised to take care on "next day" due to overbooking. To make a long story short: See (e) - it never happened so we kept that room. No big fuzz on independence weekend. My point is: Just do not promise what you cannot hold! I do not like that. 2) The fancy in-room-giga-electronic-service-system is somewhat fancy but of no real use from my poit of view. It took more time to operate than it would help. 3) Pool hours & noise level: Pool hours is only 8am-8pm and the noise level by music is far too much Ups: 4) Pool area design. Beside what I stated in (3), the pool area is really nice. There are three pools (a little shallow water) and many shadowy places to hide away from direct sun. 5) Rooms: Rooms are spacy and modern designed. Room cleaning was okay, maybe even better than what I experienced at the Monte Carlo (shabby), Bellagio (Broken Glass under bed and hairs in shower) or THE Hotel (moths through climate system). Strange: They have a somewhat combined shower/bath unit (hard to explain, look hotel website floor plan). 6) Location: Probably best you can have at the literal city center on the strip from my perspective. --- All in all, I cannot give full points due to the "usual" stuff to experience in LV (see a-e). But anyway, if you get a good deal on the rooms it is really an upscale casino location in Las Vegas. I would definitely recommend. If you are looking for less people & noise, I recommend going to an no-gaming all-suite hotel like the Vdara on the CityCenter complex.

Reviews.Title: “Nicer than average casino (but if concerned about LEEDS, go all the way and make it smoke-free!)”
Reviews.Author: Quaris
Reviews.Content: Visited Aria on 3 different days. Enjoyed the casino. We had good drink service, and good solid drinks served. One of the best selections of slot machines. Casino is logically laid out, all in one long curved rectangle (unlike other casinos that are a maze and chopped up into sections). The casino has subdued lighting which is good. Lots of room. On my first visit I thought the casino was smoke-free. Someone had told me the hotel was smoke-free and assumed all of it was. My first impression was great as a result. Finally casino management gets it right and keeps it smoke-free! (or so I thought). Went back again, and smokers sat next to me. Then the next night it was cigar fest in there - and it just stank like a filthy downtown casino. Very disappointed. For a development that took such strides to meet LEEDS certification, one would think they were conscious about the environment, both macro and micro. The hotel exterior at night is impressive with the lighting. Water-wall sculpture equally impressive. The "Sweet Chill" pink dessert diner is very cool - but beyond that the hotel has minimal attraction. The Crystals has a great exterior and a retro-70's modern stark interior that you'll love or dislike. But it's the same old boring collection of high-end stores that every other hotel has. Zzzzzz... And just like those same stores at Bellagio or Wynn, they're empty of customers, while Miracle Mile shops are packed. How many Louis Vuitton stores does a 5 block strip need? It's a pain to walk along the west sidewalk of Las Vegas Blvd as you are forced to walk through the Crystals to get through to the next section of sidewalk. Aria management (if you read this): You've an attractive new space, why not make part of your casino non-smoking at set a new high standard for casinos! There's no need to allow smoke everywhere. Those same people who say they have to light up a cigarette every 10 minutes while playing had no problem going 3 hours without a cigarette while on their flight to Vegas. And they can simply walk outside if they need to. There's far more of us that would patronize your casino than those that you would lose (smokers are only 19% of the population!).

Reviews.Title: “not a 5 star hotel”
Reviews.Author: carey44
Reviews.Content: This hotel is not a 5 star hotel. Upon our arrival the check in was quick and easy. Our room was nice but nothing special for a 5 star rated hotel. We found a sock in our bed the first night and told the lady at the front desk who seemed to not care. The toilet would not stop flushing the next day so we phoned the front desk and was placed on hold for 15 minutes. They fixed the toilet. Also they was a stain on the toilet seat which did not look to pleasent. At check out the line was huge and took about 30 min to check out. Over all a not bad 3.5 to 4 star hotel. staff needs to be more friendly and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: Sweet10
Reviews.Content: Went to vegas with husband and another couple. I had suggested the Aria because it was new and looked great. We upgraded to a mini suite - not worth the money -- there is not a TV in the bed room, only in the bathroom and sitting room. We had problems with the lights --- only had 1 accent light that worked in the bedroom. And the lite bulb went out in the water closet the first day. It took 3 days to fix the lights -- even though the housekeeper had asked for someone to fix these on our second day. When it wasn't fixed after 24hrs I asked to speak to a manager and was told no one was available. The next day when it still wasn't fixed I went down and did speak to a manager who said she would have some fix the lights but could answer how long that would take as it depended where I was in queue. Really after 2 days I would hope I would be at the top of the queue. She did get it fixed that evening. She offered to comp our room upgrade but at checkout I had to remind them of that and they adjusted the bill. The hotel itself is lovely -- modern and edgy. The casino was fine. We ate at the pub and it was good pub food. We really enjoyed the Breeze cafe for breakfast but found it a little pricey - $60 for 2. Pools are nice but very crowded on a weekend. during the week, lots of chairs available.

Reviews.Title: “High tech, high price- Bad food, bad service, dirty room”
Reviews.Author: Born2BeRed2
Reviews.Content: I just read the previous bad reviews and it was like deja vu! The hotel does not offer shuttle service to the airport, so we had to get our own. They drop you off in an underground garage and since you don't know any better, you decide to walk to the front desk. Well, bring your pedometer- it took forever! I thought I was going to have a heart attack carrying 2 heavy bags (I'm only 5'2", 120#). Check-in was a mob scene, but ok. Then, it was another long haul to my room. Good luck getting into your room- there's no slot for the room key and after standing there for 5 minutes in a sweat with all my luggage, I finally figured out that you have to "wave" the key in front of the door in order for it to open (could they have told me that at check-in?)
