You can control everything from the curtains, music, to temperature from a bedside screen. We have had many nice hotel rooms in our travels and this one ranked up there with the best. Our suite at Aria was comparable to one we had several nights prior at the new Amangiri in southern Utah. The public areas are modern and beautiful. We had fun just enjoying the interior and exterior design. The location is excellent--right between what we think are the two major sectprs of the Strip and easy walking distance to both. The pool area is large and chaise lounges were readily available during our weekend stay. We had dinner at American Fish--which was so-so..but all in all, we would recommend Aria, especially if you can get a good deal on a corner suite!

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice but service is slow”
Reviews.Author: TK_DC
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the government rate so it was a very good deal. Someone commented on the Aria being a 5-Star hotel. It’s not. The rooms are nice - well decorated, spacious and comfy. High marks for the bed – very comfortable. The hi-tech room is a novelty; one remote controls lights, curtains, TV, and temperature – but it would be quicker and easier to do these the low-tech way. One note, the hi-tech controller next to the bed (also functions as a clock) is very bright. I really wanted to dim it down at night. Bath is great with deep tub, separate shower, and 2 sinks. The downside of the hotel is the timeliness of service. You cannot call the front desk, the bell stand, or anywhere else without going on hold for a few minutes – sometimes 5-10 minutes. Good thing the phone has a speaker phone so you can do things while you are waiting. Waiting for your bags will also take considerable time 30 – 40 minutes. Other than the timeliness, the service is great. Once you get someone, they are very attentive and professional. The housekeeping staff does a great job and always has a cheerful greeting. The other downside is that the elevators are also slow. They spent a boatload of effort and money designing and decorating, they should have sprung for a few more elevators. The conference rooms are good, but some have acoustics problems – too much echoing The hotel itself is very nice. I think they let the interior designers run wild. There is subtle, usually tasteful modern art and design features everywhere. The spa is really nice – if you can get it included in you room price it’s well worth a few visits. Would I stay again? Yes if I could get the government rate – and if I couldn’t get into the Bellagio, Venetian or other property at a similar rate. It’s a very nice place, but lower your expectations on the timeliness of service.

Reviews.Title: “What a hotel!”
Reviews.Author: A-and-J01
Reviews.Content: Before travelling i checked trip advisor weekly for up to date reviews on this hotel, my partner and i were a little worried about some of the poor reviews the Aria was getting, but after a 7 night stay i would personally dismiss all the negative review! Check in was quick and easy, we arrived from the UK in Las Vegas approx 8pm there were 6 check in desks open a few people waiting but still only took 10mins to check in. We were allocated a deluxe room on the 22nd floor facing the strip, when we opened the door all we could say was AMAZING Planet Hollywood was lit up and we had a great view of this area of the strip. I had read about people having problems using the touch pad to operate the lights, curtains etc but if you press "light on" and wait 2 seconds it works as theres a slight time delay. The bed was so comfortable very soft so not to everyones liking. It was great having a walk-in shower/bath and the 2 sink idea is great, loads of space for clothes etc. The room has a nice sized safe too. The location is great theres a tram to either Monte Carlo or Bellagio. The restaurants were a little pricey in the Aria but just walking over to the Miracle Mile shopping Mall we found a few averaged priced restaurants. 12pm Check out was great, we checked our bill on the room TV before we went to check out and because we agreed with the bill we could express check out in less than 2mins! were able to left our luggage securely until we needed to make our way to the airport. the only negitives we found were no tea/coffee making facilities in our room and not many 1cent slots to play on in the Aria. So all in all an amazing holiday in an amazing hotel in a very unique city! So there were loads of positives we found, and the only nega

Reviews.Title: “Modern and posh but disappointing customer service”
Reviews.Author: Hailey888
Reviews.Content: Rooms are modern and very posh however experience was ruined when customer service did not meet standards of a five star hotel. Hotel did not honor reservations for the type of room I requested with two queen beds. I was very disappointed when I arrived and was told that there were no rooms with two queen beds available, only one king. (Isn’t this the point of making reservations to ensure you get what you want?) This was a dilemma since there were 4 of us! I was told that even though you have a reservation for two queens, the hotel does not guarantee the type of room you get, only that you get a room. They offered to add a roll-away bed to our king room and to move us to a room with two queens the next day. Needless to say that during our 3 night stay, we never received a roll-away bed (cause they had no more) nor did we end up getting moved to another room with two queens (cause they had none available). Regardless of several calls to management to express our dissatisfaction, they were unhelpful.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful buliding - horrid customer service”
Reviews.Author: mkh1027
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria over Memorial Day weekend with family and friends to celebrate my parents 30th anniversary. When I booked the rooms in March, I was guranteed 2 king rooms and one double room which my husband and I were sharing with another couple. At check-in, I was told they were out of double rooms because they were "completely booked" and bed requests were first come, first serve. I explained we had 4 people, and had confirmed twice over the phone that our rooms were reserved. She offered to give us a roll away bed, but only 1 roll-away was allowed per room. When I asked where the other person was supposed to sleep, she simply said "I don't know." I asked to speak to the manager and she told me there was nothing the manager could do. I then demanded to speak to the manager to atleast file a complaint. Once I was finally able to speak to her (she was busy putting out fires in each check-in line), we magically were given the room we requested. The rooms were nice, and the beds were very comfortable, however the lack of customer service that was present at check-in, at the pool, and in the casino was not worth the nice rooms. The waitresses in the casino never came around with drinks, the food was expensive, and you couldn't get water at the pool unless you got it from a jug located at a few stations that were almost always empty. Overall, I would not reccommend the Aria, and will not be going back.

Reviews.Title: “Even better the second time around!”
Reviews.Author: bs2121
Reviews.Content: After an absolutely stellar first experience with Aria on a guys trip back in March, I convinced the wife to go back with me for a romantic getaway for a few days in June. (Of course, it didn't hurt that the casino gave us a generous comp package.) Lest you think this review is rose-colored because just about everything was free for us, I'll divulge that we suffered record losses at the tables during this trip....and still loved every damn minute at this resort. (minus the 6am air horns from the construction site across Harmon Ave.; more about that in a bit). Got upgraded to a panoramic corner suite with floor-to-ceiling windows and 180 degree views of the strip in both directions (even from the soaking tub!!)--IMO, would be worth every penny even if paying the rack rate. This time around, I confirmed many of the previous good impressions I had about Aria, made some new observations (good and not so good), and now feel prepared to accurately summarize and comment on some of the common themes emerging from other reviews on TA that I think might be helpful to those still on the fence about staying here. New observations: --Tried the buffet this time; overall pretty darn good. Impressed with the king crab legs, variety of well-cooked and tasty carved meats, and desserts. Neverbeen to a buffet that had desserts refined enough, in taste and presentation, to serve at a 4-star restaurant. Atmosphere wasn't anything to write home about, but a table overlooking the pools helps offset the swanky cafeteria feel. --Saw the Viva Elvis show with fairly low expectations since I've never been a big Elvis fan, but ended up really liking the production and gained a new appreciation for the King. It's not a typical CDS show, but the trampoline scene with the comic book heroes had plenty of "Holy Crap!" moments. Incorporation of at least ten different genres of dance that wifey counted, many of which weren't even around when Elvis was, made it more relatable to our younger perspective. --The pools were relaxing and offered plenty of shade and crowd dispersal since there are three separate pool areas. Didn't hit the meat-market Liquid Club area, but heard good reviews about that too from some young stallions at the craps tables. --Wifey said the spa was a joy and among the best she's been to in any city. --Construction still happening across the street on Harmon Ave. side of the hotel that creates substantial noise in the early morning hours (~6am). Probably the biggest negative during our stay, but staff was very understanding and apologetic; they said the work is supposed to be finished within a few months. Confirmed impressions: --Sage is one of the best new restaurants in Vegas. Superb creativity and execution of dishes, and primo service. Had the seared scallops this time--transcendent. --The wall of cascading water in front of the hotel is hypnotizing; creates a super cool zen-like feel amidst the chaos and glitz that lies just steps away on the Strip. --The beds are total heaven. Had a very hard time getting the wife to leave the bed during the day. --Still amazed by the fact that my clothes had ZERO smoky smell the day after spending the majority of the day and night in the casino, a tribute to their cutting edge ventilation system. Phenomenal green technology behind the scenes in this place! --On that note, the in-room touch control pad is a godsend. It's utterly brilliant to be able to change the room temperature, shut off the bathroom lights, close the curtain in the sitting room, pick some mood music, and put on the "privacy" light outside the door without ever having to get out of bed. --Can't say enough about the attention to aesthetic detail throughout the resort. The way they engage all of your senses is remarkable. Even noticed that different parts of the resort have different scents circulating (vanilla in casino, floral in spa, etc.). So much texture in materials used on walls, fixtures, and furniture. Music is hip and at just the right volume. Architecture stunning and edgy art installations everywhere. --Service continues to improve, but not yet on par with places like Bellagio, Palazzo, Wynn. Spoke to several managerial folks in different departments, and they all seemed well aware of the concerns being voiced and talked with surprising candor about the improvement plans that have been implemented. Summary of common TA criticisms: 1) "it's too far of a walk from the elevators to the room, or from the hotel to the Strip" --Well, I timed it to give some objective data to help you: 81 sec. from the elevators to our room at the very end of the hall; 5.5 min. (the long way, at a moderate walk) from hotel lobby to Las Vegas Blvd. Too far? Seriously people? Keep in mind that the slight extra distance to the Strip keeps some of the fanny-packed, rubber-necking tourists away and thus maintains the chic feel for the rest of us. 2) "the hotel decor is cold and sterile" --actually, I think it's quite the opposite; the interactive technology makes it quite inviting, and the richness of the materials, textures, and styles creates a lot of warmth and interest for all the senses. If anything, the resort is a triumph in good design. 3) "the service sucks because we booked a two-queen room and all they had at check-in were king rooms, and we had to wait hours for the room we wanted" --yes, it's true, there aren't enough two-queen rooms in the resort, and they clearly state that room type is not guaranteed at booking, so don't be so surprised to hear this when you check in. If you absolutely need two queens guaranteed in stone and immediately available on a busy weekend, probably not a great idea to stay here. 4) "it's just not for us, not the Vegas we know" --I'd guess the target audience who would appreciate Aria most would be the 25-40 y.o. young professional group and/or those with some affinity for modern design and technology. So if you don't fall into these groups, consider the possibility you're setting yourself up for disappointment by staying at ARia. Aria does not offer the same brand of luxury or Vegas feel that places like Bellagio, Palazzo, or Wynn do. IMO, it's better, but to each his own.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent stylish hotel in a great location - did I stay somewhere else from the bad reviews?”
Reviews.Author: douliou
Reviews.Content: This was our fourth trip to Vegas - during our first trip in Sept 08, we saw the beginnings of City Center, and with each trip, we saw its development progress - so when we were booking our trip for May 2010, we decided that it would be fitting to experience the finished article. We stayed at the Aria for 9 nights commencing 25 May - which ended up with Memorial Day weekend right in the middle - something we didn't realise until we arrived in the US. I'll break the review down into sections...... Check in: We arrived on a Tuesday night at about 9pm - unsurprisingly, there was no queue at check in. Unlike our previous experiences, the check in agent wasn't particularly chatty but she was professional and efficient. We asked about upgrades and we were advised that there were some available but they were not complimentary. So we asked how much a corner suite would be, and the agent said it would be $50 a night. As we were in Vegas to celebrate our anniversary, we thought why not? So we accepted, and within 10 mins, we had our key cards, a map of the property and directions to the 25th floor. So we didn't experience any of the nightmare delays at check in - more likely as a result of the time we checked in, but maybe perhaps the glitches have been smoothed out - ?? The room - Corner Suite: The extra $50 a night was so worth it - the room was 900-ish sq ft, separate living/dining area, extra half-bathroom, GIANT bathroom with twin sinks and separate bath tub which looked out onto the Strip through the floor-to-ceiling windows. The loo had a heated toilet seat and (get this!) a cleansing AND drying device - !!! The bed was really comfortable - there was a very soft mattress "topper" which lay on top of a firm mattress, so it's wasn't like sleeping in a meringue - it was super comfortable. Now - the touchscreen controls........lots of complaints on previous reviews. In our experience, we were able to use the touchscreen controls the second we picked up the unit without referring to the instructions. The icons I can remember included curtains, lighting, heating, TV, music and services which I think included putting on the privacy light, checking your room charges etc. The screen is resistive so works best when you tap firmly with a fingernail. Tap on curtains, there's a tab for each room and then a choice of right and left sheer or blackout curtains - tap your button of choice, and voila, the curtains did your bidding. I personally cannot see what is confusing about that. If you really hate that touch screen unit, there is actually no need to use it at all - all the curtains, lights, room temperature, TV etc can be controlled by clearly marked switches in each room as in any other bog standard low-tech hotel room! My only complaint was that the touchscreen unit was quite bright, so I had to lay it on its face when I wanted to sleep - even pressing dimming button didn't dim it enough for my liking. Housekeeping: For the most part, housekeeping was pretty good. The room was always cleaned to a high standard, even folding away our clothes or hanging them in the wardrobe. They were a bit spotty with replenishing the bathroom amenities - on one occasion, the removed ALL the bottles, even the full ones, and did not replace them. We had to ring housekeeping to bring us some more - which took about 20 mins with a prompting phonecall. There was one day when they didn't clean the room, but most likely it was because in we were in the room for the best part of the day recovering from a big night out. However, they did leave a message on our phone explaining that they tried to clean the room but the privacy light was on. They said to give them a call when we wanted the room serviced. So whenever we had a lie in (and we had a lot given that we were in Vegas!), we called housekeeping when we were ready to have the room serviced - and on every occasion it was. There was a turn-down service, but we were usually in the room getting ready for the evening when they came round so we weren't fussed about missing out on the chocolate on our pillow! Restaurants: We often had breakfast in Cafe Vettro which was always excellent - although a bit on the pricey side. The corn beef hash was the best I've ever had. Service was excellent 90% of the time, good for the remaining 10%. We had dinner in Blossom where experienced some of the best service in any restaurant we've ever been to. Food was delicious too. We had dinner at the Buffet twice - both times excellent. I only have the MGM buffet as a point of comparison - and then, it was for lunch so not a direct comparison. But I will say that the food on offer was fantastic - particularly the desserts, the chocolate pudding was to die for, and some of them were so pretty to look at, it was a shame to eat them! The Chinese food was divine - especially the sea bass in miso glaze, I had about 6 portions! Pool: I loved the pool scene here - there were 3 fair sized pools, plenty of loungers, always managed to find a pair together. One of the pools had more kids than the others but the other pools were always pretty peaceful. Good drinks service although pricey as with all Vegas pools - $8 for a beer. Casino: By far the most generous casino with the loosest slots! I did really well with the Sex and the City and the Monopoly slots - hit big each time I played them. The staff were great - one staff member went to get me a new copy of my player's card whilst I carried on playing, another saw us queuing at a bill breaker machine - she broke our bills for us. Location: Couple of complaints about the hotel being located far off the strip - we found that if you went out the North Valet entrance, walked past the art gallery and the few boutiques, you were on the Strip within 10 minutes walk from your room. We did use the tram but we found it was so much quicker and easier to walk - even when I was wearing sky high heels! Overall impression: We previously stayed at the Signature, the Palazzo and THEhotel, all stays of 7-9 nights, all superb hotels - in our experience, Aria topped them all. The superb room may have tipped the balance in its favour but the great facilities, the stylish decor, the lovely chocolatey/coconut aroma, the convenient central Strip location - it was definitely our best stay in Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “what's the problem”
Reviews.Author: antmeister
Reviews.Content: Just arrived home from my annual holiday to Vegas. I can't believe the negative reports for this hotel? Check in took 5 mins max on a busy Saturday night got the room i had booked 2 queens non smoking off strip no upgrades available hotel full. Floor 21 with a mountain view looking over Palms/Rio/Vdara pool etc lovely rooms and tech,did not hear any outside noises at all apart from the window cleaners one morning which did a great job, automatic curtains a dream open when you set for alarm wake up.Plenty of room for 3 adults, regarding the shower, water pressure was fine did not knock you over but i think they are trying to conserve some water by turning pressure down a tad.Good lighting in bathroom which you can dim down at night via tech so a safe night light not to bang your head on anything. Room cleaned every day apart from memorial day.The room was not that far from elevators neither were any others, no more than other hotels in vegas.The Hotel decor very modern but everybody knows that before booking, casino dark but you haven't got bright lights in your face like in Monte Carlo (No Jagermeister either) We had a steak at Jean Georges one night which was spot on as was the service,$130 for 2 steaks 3 sides 2 drinks which is not over the top for vegas. Buffet breakfast best value around $48 for 3 adults unlimited coffee juice which kept coming with helpful staff, cafe vetro $75 for 3 only a few breakfast offerings big mistake. Aria pools very simply laid out 3 laid out very similar plenty of beds even at 1 in the afternoon not on holiday Sunday though the whole hotel /pool was buzzing. Pools were warm and shallow so what better than deep and cold.The hotel location is set back a bit the best way we found to get around that is to go out the back of Aria to Vdara towards Bellagio walkway that way you come out by the Bellagio conseratory which is amazing not to be missed. The other way is to head for Monte Carlo up 1 escalator down another.Either way you can cross strip via walkway when you arrive on strip.Went to see Elvis show in hotel discounted tickets for guests show was brilliant a real toe tapper.Checkout was easy just walked up no queue 30 seconds all done a very polite Bellboy picked up cases within 5 mins and stored them for 5 hours until we were ready, retrieved our cases for our long flight home taxi was there in seconds (felt like we jumped the queue) Overall no problems with hotel, friendly staff especially Craig the security at the pool entrance get to know him he's a real gentleman (won't need to show your room card again)

Reviews.Title: “Bravo Aria!”
Reviews.Author: Richie248
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a four-night stay in a corner suite at Aria. After reading all the negative comments, I was a bit worried. I’m happy to report that my stay at Aria was one of the best stays in Vegas. Check-in was rapid, friendly and efficient. The room was absolutely gorgeous. Yes it is more reminiscent of a NYC hotel room, but there is no denying it’s smart and beautiful design. Some of the room highlights include the floor to ceiling windows, the soaking tub and THE BED. Most comfortable hotel bed ever. As far as the in-room technology goes, it is quite cutting edge. If you can work an iphone, you will have no problem using the various controls. I also took a peak at a standard room and they are just as lovely. The pool had a South Beach vibe and was clean, well kept and the service was great. The casino was also very beautiful and the casino staff was very friendly and professional. We never waited longer than 30 seconds for an elevator. Getting to the strip was easy and the tram through City Center and to Bellagio was convenient. Aria certainly has its act together and offers the Vegas visitor something different and more refined. If you want a volcano or pirate show, this resort isn’t for you. I like to leave the craziness of the strip when I enter my hotel and Aria is a great reprieve from the noise and blinding lights. Bravo Aria and see you in September.

Reviews.Title: “A wanna-be property that consistently fails to do the little bit more that would make it worthwhile.”
Reviews.Author: easystreets1
Reviews.Content: On the outside, Aria has appeal. It's at City Center and boasts an interesting architectural design, that like the rest of the property, falls just short - especially if you're paying weekend rates. By way of example, shuttles and limos from the airport arrive in an un-airconditioned space under the hotel with no help from a bell desk to be found. Be prepared for the typical Vegas maze through the entire length of the casino floor with all of your luggage in tow before you find the hotel lobby (you retreat 1/2 the distance back to the guest elevators after checking in). I know the game - I'll wander the maze to find food, theaters, shops, etc..., but please, not with my luggage after an extended wait in the sun at McCarrent Int'l Airport for a cab or limo (those who don't know, be prepared to wait up to an hour for a cab, shuttle, or limo during peak travel times). The buffet, creatively named "The Buffet" lays out an impressive spread, but given the investment in the basic dishes presented, the lack of minor touches and effort fail to make either the gourmet or regular dinner meal worthwhile. For example, a nicely grilled flank steak was on offer - great bark, nicely cooked, but not seasoned in any way and the taste of the meat was lost. Why did they bother? New Englad clam chowder was prepared with a roux that was not adequately mixed (flour texture and taste were dominant) and the clams and potatoes were sparse at best. Likewise with many of the other restaurants on property - great selection, but those that I sampled just fell short. If I'm going to order a $12 sandwich, I'm going to be let down when I've had better in any other major city for less. Why did they invest in a tandoori oven on the serving line if it's only going to be used for naan? The rooms look wonderful, have great views, and are spacious with nice amentities on hand - great lighting and entertainment controls. But then the desk chair I worked at was poor at best and the hotel needs to find where Marriott and Hyatt purchase their beds as this one missed the mark. As stated, the views are good, but not well insulated from sound - road noise and sirens were heard throughout the night and I stayed on an upper floor. The bathroom is very large with great tubs incorporated into the shower area - a great concept that loses it's muster because they didn't spend the extra $5 to get a worthwhile showerhead. If you're short, bring a stool as the commodes are rather tall. The hotel and casino have a wave-based pattern coupled to an almost minimalist design throughout that uses 70's colors - avacado green, browns, and other dark earth tones that attempt under-stated elegance but simply fall flat. The staff are inefficient - I stood in a line three deep for 20 minutes to check in and appeared to have a typical experience with flat, un-enthused staff. The dealers (I played some table games and poker) added no excitement or conversation. I did happen upon one cocktail waitress of the five that served me that had a great attitude and understood customer service. Her tips reflected such (and no, she wasn't flirty or the most attractive, just considerate, consistent, and worked hard at her job). A+ for building design as energy efficiency and smart building design features are noted throughout. However, please turn on the air conditioning in public spaces like guest room hallways, the lobby, and concourses near the pool. All-in-all, if you catch a rate less than $140/night on a weekday, it's well worth the money for the room, but not as a destination in and of itself. Save your money on the weekends. If you want all-inclusive real elegance, go to the Bellagio, real excitement, go to Planet Hollywood or the Rio, or a spa-retreat, make your way to Cesear's or Mandalay Bay. Better yet, give Tunica, Mississippi a try. And, as these sorts of reviews are often left by sour pusses who lost money or had some bad experience, I was here for a conference, gambled and left about even, and didn't get drunk and do stupid things. Hope this helps!

Reviews.Title: “Swarming with the Just Graduateds”
Reviews.Author: NHTina
Reviews.Content: Oh my goodness- has Vegas changed! My husband and I were last there in 2005 and had a lovely stay at Bellagio- This time came with two other couples to the new Aria- Big mistake. Awkward location off the Strip- there's a tram to Bellagio but lots of walking. Dark, cavernous casino. Cafe Vettro off the Lobby has a tilted floor- very disconcerting. Its a hotel that has chosen trendy design over function. Its going for a urban edge but when your knife doesn't sit on the plate because the plates are a weird shape, and the barn-like bathroom door is a pain to close, ...its just annoying.We ate at Cafe Vettro in the hotel and Serrano, the Tapas Restaurant. Both were acceptable but certainly not fabulous and VERY expensive. In particular, one felt quite ripped off at Serrano. The portions were incredibly small. And I know that tapas is small plates to share- I've eaten tapas in Spain. But this was a joke- quality wasn't bad- just portion size.The pool area was the worst. Zillions of kids- hideously loud music blaring from many loudspeakers- shallow pools with warm water and chairs touching chairs- And no rules about babies with diapers in the pool. YUK! The best thing was our housekeeper- so sweet and accomodating and the beds were very comfy- but this is not a place for adults over 35.

Reviews.Title: “A Dream Come True!”
Reviews.Author: sunnyday41
Reviews.Content: I just returned home from 5 days at the Aria Hotel and Casino. I had a minor problem with my room on arrival but found that the staff addressed it quickly and in a manner that said "we care about our guests". I found all the staff to be courteous, friendly, helpful and professional. My room was very well equipped and the view on LVA was spectacular. I totally enjoyed my trip and will return again soon.

Reviews.Title: “Very different for Vegas ...”
Reviews.Author: Leesw8
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria hotel for three nights in May - we'd booked on a good rate of $169 per night including $100 in resort credit. During the stay we noticed online that the rate had fallen on their site to $149 and at our request, the hotel dropped the rate charged to that figure. The hotel is very different for Vegas. During the day, CityCenter, of which Aria is part, looks like a very upscale corporate headquarters, but at night ... it's amazing. We had a room facing West (away from the Strip) on the 30th floor. It was very comfortable. We'd stayed before at Encore, MGM, Luxor, Ballys ... etc, and this was not the biggest room we'd had in Vegas. Staff were very helpful, and the pool area, one of the best in Vegas that we had been to.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, modern new addition to the strip”
Reviews.Author: Mkschles
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel for a steal online and were extremely pleased. The room is beautiful, the technology is easy to figure out and the bed was the softest I've ever slept in at a hotel. The hotel is between the Bellagio and the Monte Carlo. Access to the strip is easy. The casino is on the darker side but doesn't smell as smokey as most on the strip because of excellent ventilation. It is a very modern, hip hotel without the cheese and flashing lights of some Vegas hotels. While luxurious, it trends towards trendy rather than overtly fancy like the Wynn or Bellagio. Staff was helpful, check-in was painless. The on-site restaurants were quite good. Excellent stay!

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice”
Reviews.Author: DivaOH10
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Aria Hotel & Casino over Memorial Day Weekend. The hotel was lovely and located in a great spot on the strip. It is attached to the City Center, which has upscale shopping. I stayed in the Sky Suites which were very modern and the bathroom was spacious. Check-in process was a little slow. There were plenty of restaurants in the hotel (prices were not too bad) and the pool area was nice. If you are a gambler, you may want to go next door and gamble where the minimum bets are a little lower. I would definately stay at the Aria again.

Reviews.Title: “Ok room but not the Encore....”
Reviews.Author: dcco1945
Reviews.Content: Reserved a 2 br penhouse sky suite. The hotel provided transportation to and from the airport @ no additional fee which was nice. The room itself was just ok. I had to move from my origional room due to the a/c not working properly in my bedroom only to find out it was obviouly a problem throughout the hotel. My bedroom was as warm as 78 degrees with the drapes open durning the day and only cooled down to 73 degrees @ night with the drapes closed. There were no ipod docking stations in either bedroom. There were no electrical outlets near either nightstand beside the bed. I had the automated control system turn on all the lights and open all the drapes in the room twice (on its own) while I was asleep. Room service was good however service by the pool was non-existent. I think the Encore is much nicer.

Reviews.Title: “why hello to you too room!”
Reviews.Author: claradical
Reviews.Content: Aria had it's pros and Cons... but mostly pros. Now lets just start off by saying that i did not pay for the room so that greatly influences any opinion. Because of construction it was hard to find the valet. we parked at the north valet, which appearantly was the wrong one because they had to send a bell man and they brought us to the wrong lobby. The lobby and the layout is huge and confusing but i'm sure that has some sort of revenue strategy attached to it. At first the overpowering scent of vanilla was annoying but it masks the gross cigarette smell and after being anywhere else in Vegas it is a joy! the casino is dark and spooky and kinda makes you hesitant to gamble because of a resulted uneasy feeling. BUT after you get to the room, all those little picky opinions that dont really matter go out the window! the room greets you with slowly opening curtain and brightening lights along with mood music. There is plenty of room for snacks on the counters, outfits in the closets, makeup on the sink. OH- and leave the ihome @ home because the technology in the room is very well equipt. ps. the dryer is very powerful! The beds are SOFT.. too soft. it was trouble getting out and rolling over... seriously! The staff were great and down to earth. John was our bellman and he was great! We ate at some cafe for breakfast and it was yummy. The pool was eh. its nice and relaxing but 1) they have 4 food items on the menu. &2) you cant have drinks within 5 feet of the pool. wamp wamp. but good relaxing no bros and hos so i can't complain! I would go back.

Reviews.Title: “Would Definitely Stay Here Again!”
Reviews.Author: travelingcouple
Reviews.Content: This is a great hotel and I would highly recommend it. Beautiful clean room with spacious bathroom. Allow for extra time as you check in due to the popularity of this hotel. You couldn't ask for a better location and the staff is incredibly helpful. Go and check out for yourself. The best website to fnd the lowest fares for Aria is on hotwire.com. It's the only 5 star hotel on the south side of the strip so you kinow it's Aria!

Reviews.Title: “new, different, enormous”
Reviews.Author: moelmsch
Reviews.Content: This is a brand new hotel so everything is clean, sparkling and beautiful. I had a corner suite in the Aria Suites tower. It was a spectacular room with a great view. The bedroom was small but the view from the bedroom was breathtaking. The suite came with a powder room, nice bar with sink, small dining room area, living room with wonderful flat screen and Bose music system and finally a wonderful bath with view including a jacuzzi bath and separate shower. The electronic control panel to the television, music system and curtain controls was a little overwhelming but I eventually figured it out. One problem with the corner suites is that they are at the end of the tower so the walk from the elevator is very long. The hospitality lounge on the ground floor is very nice with newspapers, coffee, tea, juice, fresh fruit and pastries in the morning and beer, wine, and hard liquor in the afternoon along with cheese, crackers, figs, etc. Also, water, soda, juice, sparkling water and snacks all day long. The staff in the hotel was very helpful and friendly. Don't eat at the Barmasa Japanese restaurant in the hotel unless you like paying $26 for a mediocre tuna roll, no better than you can get at Costco! The drinks were overpriced and the service was lousy. We paid almost $100 for three cocktails, one tuna roll and tax and tip and headed for the Lemongrass restaurant on the other side of the hotel. What a pleasant surprise. Great service, reasonable prices and good food.

Reviews.Title: “I'm picky and I liked it.”
Reviews.Author: Whatever50076
Reviews.Content: We usually stay at Four Seasons or Bellagio (have tried other hotels in Vegas but always go back to the other 2). This time we (3 couples) decided to try Aria for the weekend of May 21. Pros: 1. Hotel is modern, stunningly gorgeous, energy efficient and hi tech (hubby loved that). Leather or faux leather walls, marble, stone, clean lines... 2. Staff is friendly and hard working (Amber, Angela @ front desk, Fernando and Ashley @ pool, Yodora @t spa/gym check-in and Ellsworth @ pool entrance). 3. The Breeze Cafe and Cafe Vettro were good choices for lunch (we had fish and salads). Good food at a fair price. 4. Jean Philippe Patisserie was to die for. (I believe its the same place as in Bellagio BUT a lot better because it has table and seats. No more schlepping chairs to enjoy those crepes). 5. A 2 minute walk to the tram. 6. 3 pools (not the speciality ones) that were heaven. Never had a problem finding a chair and BEST of ALL there was SHADE! Bellagio has few umbrellas for those of us who dont want to fry or spend big $ for cabana. Needed: 1. A card swiping machine is needed at the entrance to the pool and EVERY person who enters should be required to swipe. This is a high-end hotel which will go downhill very quickly unless some control is exerted. 2. I heard a number of women griping about the "decor". Although I loved it, I think it appeals more to men than women. Possibly some of the dark walls can be lightened without detracting from the energy efficiency?

Reviews.Title: “Not a true 5 star hotel, but great value hotel”
Reviews.Author: orion1111
Reviews.Content: Aria is not a true 5 star hotel. Pros: -Great value... Got 2 rooms for the memorial day weekend (Sat and Sun) at only $115 each night per room (via hotwire) -Stunning layout and architecture Cons: -Service, service, service...Took 30 min just to get to the check in counter. -Our request was simple: "Non-smoking rooms"... the front desk person had to check with the manager to see if that was possible, after 5 minutes of asking the manager he returned to inform us that "they are at 104% capacity" and that they have no more non-smoking rooms availible. My question is that if there were no more non-smoking rooms availible why even ask the manager in the first place. After spending another 30 min explaining that a person in our group had asthma and other medical condition, the front desk person replied to me "I have asthma too, I guess I shouldn't be here..." What kind of rude answer is that? We've made no preference request in terms of bedding, location or anything else for that matter, i was even willing to upgrade to a different type of room In the end, it was basically "take it or leave it" type of deal. He then told us to call back down stairs 6am the following morning to see if anything had open up. Appearantly this 5 star hotel's staff could not be bothered to call us if any non smoking room had opend up. -Readiness of the rooms: 2 light bulbs were missing in one of the two room, 1 light switch didn't work. A/C thermostat didn't work properly (fan won't start or stop at the set temperature), the touch screen Computer unit that controls the curtains and lights froze was hard to use (although very cool feature...had it worked properly). -Location: Too far from the actual stripe. Only the actual car entrance was on the stripe. Overall, a great value at $115/night, but service was rude and poor, the level of service is no where near those of Venetian, Wynn, Bellagio or even Mandalay Bay.

Reviews.Title: “Sky suites high tech”
Reviews.Author: bmford
Reviews.Content: Stayed at Aria for Memorial Day weekend. We had a Sky Suite with a seperate check in from the chaos of Aria's main hotel. The room wasn't ready when we got there, but we were starving and had spa appointments anyway, so no big deal. The check in woman took my cell and rang we when we could go in. The spa was great. Had a massage. The Japanese stone beds were great, in fact several people were sound asleep. The spa robes were the best quality, as were the towels and the high tech lockers. So anyway, the buffet was good, selection and quality of food was great, I'm just not a buffet eater. They room was incredible. We had a two room suite with a half bath. The TV's control everything in the room including the curtains, temperature, music, videos, and on, and on. You can even check the status of your flight on the TV, just like the screens at the airport. The TV's have channels like I've never seen, from Russia, Kuwait, China, Italy, France. No matter where you're from, you'll find a channel to your liking. The bed was heavenly. The room was spotless. The staff at Aria seem young, but very polished. They took our cell phone number and booked us last minute Elvis tickets. Called us to let us know. The show was great. Elvis lives!!! With the suite, we had complimentary limo transport to and from the airport. Heavenly!! Didn't have to wait in the crazy taxi line!! All in all, just a great weekend at a great hotel. Would go back!!

Reviews.Title: “This place is INSANE”
Reviews.Author: SDNX
Reviews.Content: Had a corner suite with strip view. Floor to ceiling windows on both sides. The push button controls to everything in this room are very cool. Opening/closing the blinds and changing the temperature and sound system from bed is nice. The jacuzzi tub had a nice view out of the windows and the suite amenities are awesome. The elevators are fast and the employees I dealt with were great. The pools are awesome and I will be back just to lay around. The hotel itself is amazing and we were pretty much walking around the property in awe and we have stayed and some cool places. The buffet brunch was excellent for the price. King crab legs, prime rib, leg of lamb....the list goes on. The line was short but was weird how they make you wait to go to a table for no real obvious reason. One thing i didn't like was that the floor to ceiling windows with the amazing view, were badly spotted with hard water and whe the light hit it, it was very noticeable. Not too sure how they can fix this. Long walk to the strip from the front doors but not bad. Will be back soon to this place

Reviews.Title: “Close, but no . . .”
Reviews.Author: mooneynut
Reviews.Content: ROOMS: I'm not a big fan of feather soft beds, so needless to say sleep wasn't as good as it might have been elsewhere. The room was large enough and very nice, a little dusty (makes me wonder how often they are actually cleaned), and mostly quiet. Air condition didn't work very well but kept the room tolerably cool. Electronics are more of a hassle than a help, they really need to ditch the control panel idea and just provide quality amenities that make guests stays easier and more comfortable, not amenities that make things more difficult than the should be. Oh, and robes are NOT what I'd call plush, more like that thin bedspread material your grandmother had when you were a kid. CASINO: Tough to get a feel for the casino layout, lots of stuff to walk around, small pieces of casino floor here and there separated by bars, rooms, etc. Plenty of gaming tables, decent stakes, average staff. Average sports book. Just like anywhere else, the lower the stakes, more than likely the slower the drink service. CHECK IN/CHECK OUT: Check in was quick and painless on a Friday afternoon, Check out was slow. Like any other place, it all depends on timing and the attitude of the desk clerk as to what your experience will be like. OVERALL: Nice location, and could be really nice place if they'd just make sure they get the basics (like cleaning and comfort) right first. Overheard a conversation at checkout where the desk clerk informed a guest that even removing items from the honor bar for inspection and then putting them back in will trigger a room charge.

Reviews.Title: “Love Vegas, not the Aria.”
Reviews.Author: KidinShorts
Reviews.Content: Last time I was in Vegas I stayed at the Bellagio. I was excited to return and stay in this new hotel. From trip advisor, I had read some of the bad reviews but was hopeful that those experiences wouldn't happen to me and further that those issues would have been resolved by now. We arrived early afternoon. The lines were nuts, it seemed to lack order. When it was our turn, about 20 minutes in line, we were told our room, a kingside bed on a non-smoking floor wasn't available, and to come back in an hour. We had our carry-on luggage and were hungry. No one offered to take our stuff so we could walk about the strip easily, so we sat in the lobby for about 40 minutes. When we went back to check in we were told that they didn't guarantee kingsize beds on nonsmoking floors. We were told that our room would be ready in 3 hours! Insane. We just wanted a place to put our stuff and to eat. When asked if they could do anything we were told we could take a smoking room, and we could move once the room we booked was available. We did. It was nice to be in a room, but it was obvious that it was haphazardly cleaned. The fridge wasn't full and shampoo was missing from the bathroom. Also, the name on Aria's in-room control panel was someone else's. Were we in someone else's room? Was someone else in the room I supposedly had booked? It took three phone calls, and one night of sleeping in the smoking room before our room was available. (The room and the floor reekend.) Further, it took us making the phone calls, Aria employees never called us to let us know the room was available. The rest of our stay was better. It seemed that the overall customer service was lacking from many of the employees we came across. On our last day a "pool waitress" actually took a few minutes to explain what she had to offer and where to go for other foods. It would have been nice if the first waitress we had on our first day poolside would have taken a moment to explain it. It was also on this last day that we were at the business center to print our flight confirmation. It was actually nice that they said we could have free use of the computer/printer for flight confirmation. Of course, we were then spoken to rather rudely when we opened up the internet browser and were killing a few minutes before our flight confirmation opened up. "I thought you were printing your flight confirmation. Internet usage is not free!" The hotel was nice, as in clean and new. The rooms were great, again, clean and new. The pools, three of them, and hot tubs were all nicely cared for and great to lounge by. The service overall lacked. And it lacked badly! That being said, there also were workers, like the last pool waitress we had, a young man named, "Ericson" who worked a snack shop like area in the casino, and a guy named, "Drew" who worked the taxi stand area, that all had great personalities and the level of professionally we expected. I enjoy Vegas, and will go back, but I will not be staying at the Aria. If you stay at the Aria, I hope you come across the last few people I mentioned, and have a far better experience.

Reviews.Title: “Not enough words to describe how much i LOVE this hotel...WOW!!!”
Reviews.Author: Chef94
Reviews.Content: First of all i travelled with my brother and good friend and from the moment we spotted Aria on our cab ride in, we all instantly fell in love. If you appreciate archetecture like i do, this hotel is a must see. We pulled up in the cab and the five star service began with one of the many bellboys outside opening our door and welcoming us to the hotel. Check in was quick and informative, the staff are very personable and helpful. At this point we were all blown away from the ambience of this amazing hotel, and there is a distinct smell about aria that i fell in love with. Our room was absolutely amazing and gives you an instant feeling like your royalty. The beds are super comfy, lots of room and the bathroom is very modern and well designed. The room is everything you can ask for. In our six days there the service that we experienced was stellar. Every staff member you met seemed like a friend and not a hotel employee. Theres only one word to describe the Aria pools, Amazing. they also have a V.I.P. pool and lounge called Liquid that is just simply mind blowing, service second to none. My only problem with this hotel was that i could have easily spent my whole trip on the resort, thats how much there is to see and do on the Aria resort. The hotel is huge. Then location is perfect, your in the city center so your righ in the midde of everything. I have nothing bad to say about this hotel, it is absolutely mind blowing. It was my first time in Vegas and i now know where i will be staying every time i visit vegas until im old and grey. Im looking forward to my next stay at this Beautiful resort.

Reviews.Title: “Forget it”
Reviews.Author: Stajo12
Reviews.Content: It sounded great, but wasn't. Mediocre food, mediocre rooms, terrible location. Dark and tired already. What a shame. The Elvis cirque show was better than I expected -- wish I'd taken a cab and stayed elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel with some faults!”
Reviews.Author: motovar
Reviews.Content: The hotel is truly beautiful and modern. The room was absolutely amazing with all the technology right at your fingertips. It was very clean and the staff are very nice. Only three faults I found (the last one not being too important). - Check in takes a little while. We spend at least 20 mins. from the moment we got in line to the minute they handed us our keys. Stunning lobby though and nice clerks! - One of the lights in our closet would not turn off, making the room somewhat bright at night. It wasn't after two days after our check in and four phone calls until they finally came and fixed it. - Lastly, it is sort of a pain to access the strip from the hotel or vice versa. Since Aria is towards the back of CityCenter, you either have to go to the Bellagio or walk out of CityCenter to the front of the strip to go to the other hotels. Not a big deal like I said earlier, but it is not as easy accessible as the other properties. All in all, I would stay at this hotel again. It was a great hotel minus the previous points mentioned. The delightful pools, appealing architecture and the contemporary feeling made it a memorable stay.

Reviews.Title: “Okay, I guess”
Reviews.Author: AnotherHoustonian
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to love this hotel. It has such a cool vibe and the staff really seems to be trying to be doing a great job, it just isn't working right. A few things to note.....check in took awhile, maybe thirty minutes. My spa appointment check in took 30 minutes. The checkout line looked like it was going to take thirty minutes. I was offered "express checkout" with a receipt emailed to me. I took advantage of the offer. However, I never received a receipt until my AA called for one. My room was not cleaned one day. I alerted the front desk. They offered to comp me one day. I really didn't want the comp, I wanted my room cleaned. However, it was 9 pm at night, and I also just really wanted to go to sleep. Another day, my room was cleaned but they forgot to give me fresh amenities. I was out of shampoo. They sent me up some, but it was annoying. I would have preferred simply to have shampoo as part of the room refresth. The Aria is a super cool property, but needs a good process improvement initative. This place definitely still has a few kinks. Give it a few more months, and I am confident they will have figured it out and it will rock. Until then, well.....um.......maybe just go take in one of their fabulous restuarants.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible Service”
Reviews.Author: dosh777
Reviews.Content: We came to Aria becasue it was new and wanted to try something different and they still do not have their act together with the service. Obviously the hotel is nice, it is brand new, but the service is also brand new. One day our room was not cleaned until 4:00 in the afternoon. I was called my friends name all weekend long, since he was the guy, but I was the one paying, and they have no takt! I hope that Aria gets their service together soon since we stayed there a second time a couple months later and it was still a complete mess. Nice hotel, horrible service. PS The Pool (LIGUID) is not worth the money you may pay for a bed or entrance. This is not the cream of the crop of VEGAS!

Reviews.Title: “Not our kind of place”
Reviews.Author: Islandmind
Reviews.Content: We've been to Vegas a couple dozen times and have stayed from the Excalibur to the Four Seasons. Lately we have made Bellagio or Paris our usual spot. This time we decided to try Aria for the first five nights of our trip. They had a spring special on suites, so we got a one-bedroom suite in the sky suites section. The limo driver was waiting for us when we arrived at the baggage claim, and was very patient when our luggage didn't come down the conveyor belt. Turns out it had arrived on an earlier fiight and was locked in the airline's baggage room. I can't say what the regular check-in at Aria is like, but the VIP entrance and desk was great. We arrived several hours before the published time and they accomodated us immediately. The decor of Aria is contemporary. We are more fabrics, wood and details rather than stainless steel and metal pipes, so it wasn't really our thing. The other negative is it is loud in this hotel. They actually have microphones scattered around the casino that detect the ambient noise level and turn up the music in response. It is inescapable. The only other significant negatives ares that it is a LONG way to the Strip; even more so than what we thought was a long way before, and the other buildings in City Center (of which there are many) block the views of what Vegas is all about. You see mostly blue glass towers from your room. The VIP section has a complimentary coffe, snack and breakfast bar available most of the day, with wine and noshes in the evening; that is a nice touch. One glitch we encountered was a problem with check-out logistics. The suite came with limo service to and from the airport. Since we were moving to the Mandarin Oriental (also within the City Center) afterward, I asked if we could in lieu of a trip to the airport our bags could be taken there. The front desk clerk said no problem, but when it actually came to the even the bell desk said they woudn't do it, and the Mandarin had to send somebody to retrieve them. I should have had Aria drive us around the block and deliver us to the Mandarin. Oh well, a minor thing in review. Their pool area is very nice with several options and slow but adequate service. The chaises are quite close together, so get cozy with the stranger next to you. In aggregate it was a decent stay, but I don't think we will be returning. For less money one can get a Bellagio Suite with better logistics and a more pleasing atmosphere. None of the restaurants at Aria appealed to us, and the property comes off as being a little cold. Because of the alternatives I will give it a not recommended. Oh, one other thing: the City Center spent $3.1 million for that ridiculous metal typewriter eraser *sculpture* in front. It's enough to keep you way knowing you are helping to pay for that. Hidious.

Reviews.Title: “Improving Service and Style!”
Reviews.Author: MortyCanada
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria in February, soon after it opened, so this is our second stay. We received an offer of three nights, two freee buffets and $100 playing credit, which is, to us, a good deal. Things would have to go really wrong before we would complain too much. We were able to use 'the invided guest' check-in and so by-passed the 'scrum' that is check-in for others. We often stay at the Venetian/Palazzo and find customer service there to be exceptional, with many reasonable upgrade offers to allow the customer to find desierec

Reviews.Title: “How could this place get a bad rap?”
Reviews.Author: Huggo69
Reviews.Content: Beautiful, Elegant, Classy and a buzzing energy at any hour. This place is all that and then some, if you enjoy "the show", this is a must stay place, lively and hopping all day and night! The room was roomy, we requested 2 adjoining rooms and they made sure to accomadate our request. The pool had 3 different pools, not counting Liquid, so there were plenty of seats and good spots, poolside. ONLY complaint is that you can't drink while in the pool, had to have your drink 4 feet away from the pool. Seriously, the place was a HIT!

Reviews.Title: “BEST HOTEL ON THE STRIP”
Reviews.Author: bxny1
Reviews.Content: Upon entering you greeted with a scented air in the lobby of the Hotel. Quick check in, All the Modern amenities, and decor any one can ask for a remote to control everything in your room plush king size bed. Located conveniently on the strip it was my weekend bachelor party close to every. The one negative no microwave other than that no complaints I mean think about Brand new luxury resort on the strip in Vegas reasonable price what is there to complain about!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great rooms, very modern.”
Reviews.Author: Neckbone13
Reviews.Content: Arrived in high hopes at a wonder lavish looking resort. It all started at check-in, took about 20 min. waiting in line (only 3 guest in front of us). Then it was my time, gave the Representative my name and confirmation number, looked us up on the computer and yes they had me registered, but not what I ask for. King, non smoking. He wanted to put us in a smoking room. We explained to him that wasn't acceptable. He was real nice, no complaint with him understanding, and he continued to look, and after a few minutes a non smoking room became available. Understand it's 8 PM. On our way to the room, walking along the corridor there were roll away beds, food carts and trays not picked up. Food all over the floor we had to walk through "the tomato and bread had been stepped on. Not exactly what we expected, and by the way, it was still there the next morning. We got to our room, opened the door, the lights came on and one of the nieces rooms I've ever seen. We were happy again until we opened the curtains. Nice view of the roof, parking garage and construction site. I though I was at work... If you play slots go somewhere else, there trying to pay for the place from slot players. Nice new machines, very nice, but one would expect to win something ever once in a while. Foods was great, but expensive. Staff very helpful, polite and nice. Over all Aria it's a beautiful resort, but it will take you several days to find your way around and visit all the great shops. Highly recommend the show "Viva Elvis", great....

Reviews.Title: “Modern hotel with good service”
Reviews.Author: ChitownCountry
Reviews.Content: After reading all of the mixed reviews of the Aria, I was not sure what I would experience. We pulled up to the Aria very easily on a Monday afternoon around 4:30pm. Check In only took around 10 minutes. I needed 2 rooms and asked if they could be close to each other. They gave us rooms next door to each other. The modern tech rooms took a while to get used to for a non teckie in one of the rooms. But the TV has a "normal" remote control, and there are switches on the wall for the curtains and lights. The control panel was very easy to navigate and the only glitch was that I could not get my folio in one of the rooms. The beds were very good, and the bathroom was great. The casino was fairly dark, but not as extreme as some mentioned in other reviews. I did not try any of the clubs at the hotel but they seemed to be filled with a late 20's and 30 year old crowd. The Buffet was very good for lunch, but for breakfast, go to Jean-Phlippe Patisserie for coffee and pastries. The breakfast at Cafe Vettro was average. Aria seems to be trying to figure out what customer base to attract. I feel they are looking for the late 20 - 40 year old crowd. I would give the Aria a return visit but I would not recommend it to the post 60 crowd.

Reviews.Title: “Nice clean new hotel”
Reviews.Author: SanPhil
Reviews.Content: We just got back from Las Vegas and stayed at the Aria. Lovely new hotel with fabulous modern rooms with warm brown tones and an integrated computerized in-room system. The computerized systems help with energy efficiency. The Aria touts that they are an energy effiicient, sustainable hotel. That being said I was surprised to see that all the toiletries were made in China - how sustainable/environmental is it to ship shampoo across the sea, in addition, what is really in the shampoo? I didn't touch those products. Other than that, I would stay at the Aria again and bring my own shampoo.

Reviews.Title: “A relief from the prevailing Vegas excess.”
Reviews.Author: AlwaysOnLocation
Reviews.Content: Spent three great days at the Aria Hotel. The minimalist architecture is punctuated with some impressive modern art. The whole CityCenter is a welcome oasis from the chaos of The Strip. Great location allows you to easily visit other hotels. Free monorail goes from Aria to both the Bellagio and the Monte Carlo. Everyone mentions the electronic controls for lights, curtains, TV, etc. in each room. It’s fun and it’s not difficult to figure out. Check-in is a bit challenging. Instead of lining up behind velvet ropes, an employee is there to direct you to one of the desk personnel. It doesn’t quite work. Like most Vegas hotels, you must walk through the casino to get to the elevators, a minor inconvenience. Elevators are grouped by floors and we never had to wait long. Our “upgraded” room wasn’t very large, but was well-appointed and had a nice view toward The Strip. Bathroom had two sinks and a large shower and bath compartment. Housekeeping did an excellent job. Didn’t hear noises from other rooms. Mini bar in the fridge is typical hotel rip-off - measured by weight so you can’t use it for anything else. Pool area has three outdoor pools and was very pleasant and relaxing. We had spa treatments that were very good. Lots of restaurants inside the hotel. We ate breakfast twice in Cafe Vettro - excellent food, service and decor. Had lunch at Julian Serrano - delicious food artfully served and not overly expensive. Ice cream at Sweet Chill (a “Clockwork Orange” inspired cafe near the spa) and breakfast another day at Silk Road in neighboring Vdera Hotel. I recommend them all. Cirque du Soleil has installed their newest show, “Viva Elvis” right inside Aria Hotel and it’s sensational - worth a trip to Las Vegas just for that alone. For a more exclusive experience, try the Vdera or Mandarin Oriental hotels at CityCenter - they don’t have casinos. But to get the feel of the new Las Vegas, Aria Hotel is outstanding.

Reviews.Title: “High tech wonder - Service not so great - I'll give it another try”
Reviews.Author: azbobcat
Reviews.Content: This place is beautiful and rooms are great. If you're technology challenged, this probably isn't the place for you. I loved the technology, my husband swore everytime he hit the wrong button and the curtains closed or opened at the wrong time, etc... Loved the bedding and bathroom...great sound proofing in room. The casino is great, the restaurants are very good. Buffet is wonderful. Overall service at check-in/check-out was very poor. Concierge line was nightmare - took forever in line. Incorrect charges posted to our bill, which they corrected. Pretty hip place, a great addition to Las Vegas. If they can get the service improved in areas it will go a long way. We'll give it another try.

Reviews.Title: “nice on the eyes but stuff does not work”
Reviews.Author: texas1999
Reviews.Content: Just got in from here..two bedroom penthouse sky suite... not worth the money. Things are pretty everyone was real nice room service prices in line and food better than most. However, 54 floor view obscured by buildings in front, walk to strip exceeds 5 min sky suite entry nice but we did not know where other things were. three tvs did not work, one phone always hung up when the vips services put you on hold, ordered extra towels and toiletries prior to arrival not there when we got them two hours later they took all of them. they did not replenish the toiletries no trash bags in cans, both spa tubs mysteriously turned on and we could not get them off one had to be kicked.. lights in kitchen and one bath were burnt out and at times when you went to turn on or off lights in one bath you could only get flashing lights.. had workmen in everyday. got a 300 credit on a 6 k bill. oh and we were locked out of our room the first two days due to faulty key pads had to go back down and be escorted up. no microwave or coffee maker in room. all parties had to go to lounge to get drinks one could not go for us all we kept getting in trouble for that, we had 4 in our party and we could not even take a plate of snacks from vip l to our room only on a small napkin. "only two waters per person who came down none for those who could not come down and plates are for lounge only" ahh like we were making a set to take home come on it was a mess obviously you can not do anything in vegas vip lounge was just a kitchen bar and sofa seating. check in area only 20 min wait. casino was cold not warm and inviting. they also forgot the limo back to the airport even though it was on our itinerary. could not get into the spa for two days and the misters in the cabana were not allowed waste of money at 400 room looked like it was a theme from IKEA Viva Elvis was great but we were in a time crunch and they would not send tickets up to the vip suite. if you go get a cheap rate and if you get a sky suite vip do not expect a view or to be treated much like a vip

Reviews.Title: “Superb new addition to the strip, and a fantastic scent!”
Reviews.Author: Edspar
Reviews.Content: Thoroughly enjoyed our stay at ARIA, and experienced almost no issues. The entire City Center complex is a marvel of architecture and design, and at every corner you find something new and fascinating. All wrapped up in the most wonderful scent. The rooms were very modern and comfortable, though the pillow top on the mattress was a bit much for our liking. Bellagio still has the best beds. The high-tech room is cool at first, but gets annoying after a short while, and takes some getting used to. The entire control panel seemed very slow and cumbersome, and simple things like an iPod dock (it requires a special cable from a company called "CONTROL4" to connect) seemed to elude them. Sometimes a light switch and simplicity are best. Good room for techies or gadget crowd. Staff was always friendly (almost overly so at check-in, with their weird hand gestures and all), and the entire place seemed well run and immaculate. Best buffet we've had in Vegas too boot. The Wynn used to take this crown, but if Aria can maintain the quality it's the one to beat. The Pool area was one of the best we've seen and had a lot of different zones and privacy. Well worth your stay! Try Aria - you'll likely love it!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent hotel with greatly improving customer service.”
Reviews.Author: JeromeNY
Reviews.Content: Aria is probably one of the best and most modern hotels on the Las Vegas strip. We booked a corner suite, got one with a poor view. We requested to be transferred but the hotel was fully-booked. Got $70 hotel credit, and was transferred to a room with a view on our last night. The representatives were mostly accommodating. The rooms were amazing. Got a great deal from Expedia. The walk to the strip wasn't too bad. The food choices in the hotel were good but expensive. In-room dining was just ok. That vanilla scent many talk about, I didn't really notice. The pool area was excellent. I would definitely stay in Aria again.

Reviews.Title: “Superb Hotel Ranks With The Best In Town”
Reviews.Author: Jtorsney
Reviews.Content: I just returned from an excellent stay at Aria. Check in was a breeze and my room was ready immediately. Unlike some hotels, finding the guest elevators did not require a GPS device. The rooms are standard size and seemed roughly equivalent to the rooms in Mandalay Bay's main tower. The furnshings are of a high standard and the rooms come equipped with remote controlled lights, curtains, shears, and a nice alarm feature that opens curtains, turns on tv, etc. at a prearranged time. Taking a few minutes to figure this out after check-in will avoid issues like accidentally turning off lights and curtains as I did. The rooms are located in extremely long curved towers. End rooms are quite a distance from elevators as they are at Wynn/Encore. Unlike many properties, the restaurants, Cirque theater, and pool entrance are split into two levels. I found nagivation a bit difficult, but I chalked this up to a lack of familiarity. The casino offers a wide variety of games and limits. Service was quite good across the board, and room service was surprisingly good. Based on premium properties where I have stayed, I would slot Aria in as follows: 1. Four Seasons 2. Wynn/Encore 3. Bellagio 4. Aria 5. the Hotel at Mandalay Bay 6. Mandalay Bay Rates are a bit higher than Bellagio, which I thought was okay since this is a new property. The tram between Aria/Crystals, Bellagio/Vdarra, and Monte Carlo runs like clockwork. I would stay here again without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: “exquisite!”
Reviews.Author: janfore
Reviews.Content: I booked a stay here PRIOR (for a change) to looking at reviews from previous guests. After I booked it, I did read reviews and was worried by the amount of negative ones about this new resort. What a wonderful relief to discover that this property is one of the absolute nicest resorts I have ever stayed at! ABSOLUTELY gorgeous! The decor is simply perfect if you are into modern architecture!!!! I was dumbfounded by the details! The staff and restaurants- all nop notch. The room was very comfortable and elegant. Things were very expensive, but that was expected. I would highly recommend (especially to people into design!)

Reviews.Title: “The Aria surpassed our expectations and we'd choose it again - helpful hints.”
Reviews.Author: Coastalpair
Reviews.Content: We've stayed at most of the top strip hotels in Las Vegas, including the top-rated Four Seasons. The Aria was good enough tthat we'd choose it again, if the rate were competetive. Positives: Great location and easy access to monorail; new and very clean; lovely room, allthough all the high-tech stuff was a bit of a pain; quiet; easy to find our way around the hotel and casino, despite the huge size; convenient access to room and very high speed elevators. The service was pleasant and check in and out was speedy. Negatives: Don't bother paying extra for a view - our friends didn't and we did, but our view was no better than theirs; most of the restaurants were expensive and not worth it. Hint - the JP Patisserie near the elevators is a great place to get sandwiches and salads, as well as fantastic pasteries and coffee - we should have had lunch there every day. The tapis restaurant was quite good. Our friends tried the lower-end restaurant, Vettro and didn't like the food, so we didn't go there. The buffet is so-so, but if you like to drink wine, the weekend deal which includes all the wine you can drink, is great. The casino was OK but we spent most of our time eating and playing elsewhere -- this isn't a problem because of the easy access to the other casinos. The Aria would be wise to improve the restaurant situation - how about some decent food at a moderate price? - and loosen up the slots a bit. That way, more of the customers would gamble there. To avoid lineups when checking out, check out at least an hour before the scheduled time and then leave your luggage with the conceirge. If you wait until everyone is leaving, naturally you'll be in a heavy lineup situation.

Reviews.Title: “Not a bad value if you are looking for a 2 star hotel!!”
Reviews.Author: sandee38
Reviews.Content: What a disappointment this hotel turned out to be. We booked our room one month in advance for a double queen room. When we checked in they only had one bed rooms left. No apologies at all from management. He was actually rude about it. Get to the room and had to wait one hour for the roll away bed. There were only two glass cups in the room and none in the bathroom. When we ordered room service, we requested extra cups and told that we couldn't ask for more than 6 without being charged. The glass ware that they sent up were sooooo dirty and spotted with hard water stains. I have never been to any restaurants or hotels that had dirtier glass ware. This place is on a scale of 1-10 is a 3. Don't waste your time and money here. We will not ever come back! This hotel is okay if you are expecting service and cleaniness of a 2 star hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Our issue was with our privacy button”
Reviews.Author: who642
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria for 4 nights because of my husband having a conference there. We liked the hotel. Someone complained about the low lighting...we actually liked that and thought it was a different feel than some of the other casinos. As far as the technology, it was not difficult at all. We did love the look of the room too but the walls are thin when people are walking back from the casino at 4 in the morning. To walk on the strip could take 20 - 30 minutes just to go a few hotels up. The tram does help some. We really had no issue with service and thought the opposite of some other reviews in the fact that everyone was nice. Our issue came on our last night. My husband was in the casino while I was showering. The privacy button was illuminated however someone kept knocking at the door and I kept yelling from the shower to go away. They then proceeded to walk in our room even though our privacy button was lit. After I screamed, he did leave. It was an IT tech trying to fix something in our room that did need to be fixed. I contacted the front desk and they did not seem to care. IT then called me and again they did not seem to care. I emailed and voice mailed the guest services manager and 3 weeks later, still waiting on a response. I did also contact the front desk one more time and asked to speak to a manager after a man said he could tell I was frustrated...I was more shaken. The manager said no one should even have knocked on the door with the privacy button on. Basically, I did like the hotel...I didn't like how they handled this issue and wish this issue never happened to begin with.

Reviews.Title: “Not perfect, but very nice. And in the middle of everything!”
Reviews.Author: jobager
Reviews.Content: Spacious, clean and (of course) new rooms. The shower/bathtube combination is perfect, never seen this before. The wake up program is also something special :-) The location is ideal - once you´ve left the City Center property, you´re really in the middle of everything. No quick checkout option, had to queue at the reception (and it took me longer than to check in, even without any room charge). Don´t know why, because in the hotel brochure they say there´s a quick checkout. After I´ve stayed at the Luxor and the Venetian on previous trips I would rate the Aria in the middle of them. The missing theme is what makes the Aria too anonymus in my opinion - it´s just a good, new hotel which could be in every city around the world but hey, we´re in Vegas, I want something different! My next stay will be in one of the theme hotels again - but you can´t go wrong if you book a stay at the Aria.

Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon Aria in Vegas”
Reviews.Author: Velvetburn
Reviews.Content: I loved the Aria, it was absolutely breathtaking to look at (almost overwhelming). It was a Crystal Palace, with amazing views from most of the hotel. First of all the valet parking is very professional and efficient. The check-in took a while, but they let us check in super early. The lady at the desk upgraded us because we were on our honeymoon. It was nice to see the security guys in front of the guestroom elevators. They were pretty friendly, and even struck up a conversation if things weren't super busy. I liked that the employees were diverse in age and nationality. Pro: Quick checkout, just a phone call away! Near CVS and Walgreens Food was good, but some restaurants(Like the Buffet) were pricey. Also when it comes to a buffet, keeping it simple in layout and food works best. For those that are not all in the gambling scene, the casino is not "in your face". Cons: Bed was a little too soft(just a little) I didn't like the mini-bar(where are we supposed to put our food?) Got "fee'd up". Fifteen dollars a day for internet :( Thiry dollars to use the gym(What da hey!!?) One hundred thirty a day held for "incidentials" :( Really cut into our fun money! All in all I had a good experience. I liked the decor for the most part; however, a little dark. Our room had a decent view(room 20020), but one of the buildings blocked the view of the strip. The food at the Pub was off the chain! The pool and the spa are to die for. Valarie(?) did such a good job on my nails! The staff was personable and nice...without being fake. We will be back next year!

Reviews.Title: “By far, the worst service ever!”
Reviews.Author: amsters8
Reviews.Content: I cannot believe all the positive reviews! I'll try to make it quick. My friends and I checked in at 5:30pm on a Friday night (2 nights only). They said no more 2 beds available. Really?! It's only 2 1/2 hours after check-in time, and you're ready out of those?! They offered us a comp roll way bed and said they'd send it right up. 45 mins later, no bed. Called the front desk and was put on hold for at least 10 mins! I've never been put on hold when I call the front desk or at least never more than a minute or so. Needless to say, the bed took over 6 hours to come, and we had to call 3 times for the bed while being put on hold for 10 mins each time! Other side notes: (1) used shaver in the bathroom trash can, (2) light bulb by the bed were out and they never came to fix it (3) concierge put us on the guest list for Haze, but when we got there, we were not on the list (4) we couldn't charge our meal to the room b/c it had an X on it; turned out the check-in desk attendant didn't put down our credit card for incidentals. But, she did charge the 2nd night to the room so why wouldn't you put it down? It was just a hassle to have to go to the front desk and get that taken care of. Lastly (5) they did finally change us to a room with 2 beds on Saturday. During this process, they locked us out of our original room. Hello?!
