Room elements including drapes, tv, temperature etc. are controlled by a tethered small lcd touch-screen panel box that is about the size of an old dial telephone console. This universal control unit is confusing to use and is a waste of time to have to figure out when you are on vacation. I still do not know how I feel about the bath tub being located inside of a walk in shower essentially creating a giant wet chamber. BTW, if you like to sing in the shower, you will never sound better! I guarantee that. All of that being said there was much good. The nite-life crowd is very young (18-22) and noisy. The rooms were elegant with giant flat screens TV's and cabinetry. Some room walls are painted brown and some are painted tan. Ask for the tan. It feels much more open and light. Nice to play all new slot machines that seemed generous. The table games, especially craps were plentiful and crowded. Best part was the SPA. Facilities were top notch and the services were very reasonably priced. Actually, the SPA was the best deal in the whole place.

Reviews.Title: “Decadent and they will continue to be amazing...”
Reviews.Author: Nannybear58
Reviews.Content: Food is pricey but it is Las Vegas after all...room was incredible! Programmable to open the curtains, give me a wake up call and spectacular view. The girls in The View bar were awesome, especially Nicole, Mookie and Thea. The staff in the Sirio Restaurante and food was excellent!! Cafe Vettro needs a little bit of work yet. Staff was excellent but bit of a wait and be advised they don't butter your toast! The Buffett is not bad but staff don't get chance to really wait on you quickly. If you want excellent service visit the more fining dining experieinces but that makes sense. The hotel is huge so make sure you are in shape for walking!! Concierge staff is awesome - Natasha and Kelsey were brilliant! House keeping staff were great as were all the staff in the Elements store. All in all we had a fabulous time. Did it cost? Yes, but I got what I paid for!

Reviews.Title: “Comfy Beds”
Reviews.Author: fishfamilyCalgary
Reviews.Content: After reading some of the reviews I was skeptical about staying here. This hotel is a fine choice. They are still working out bugs but that is no different than any other place. Food was very good but found it to be expensive. The orange juice in the Cafe was $7.50 - kind of shocking when the bill arrived. The beds are extremely comfortable and casino has a good variety of slot machines. Pool area is very nicely done but the hours were only 9-4 right now. Once summer hits they extend hours. There are three pools. Didn't like the fact that WiFi was not free!

Reviews.Title: “Terrible...2 stars hotel from service to rooms"”
Reviews.Author: MaybachMadison
Reviews.Content: This is a brand new hotel in the new center city. Was greatly disappointed. Had a Tower Suite. Nothing worked from the iPod player to the whirlpool to the TVs. The hotel staff was of no help either. Also, you can hear the noise from the other rooms ie crying babies.

Reviews.Title: “Beauty is only skin deep”
Reviews.Author: jimmyp65
Reviews.Content: The Hotel LOOKS beautiful but--- The reservations were made two months in advance, when we got there the room was not ready at 1:30, 3:30, 4:30 and at 5:30 we had to reregister. they gave us a smoking room because they were out of non smoking rooms. We were invited guests! The clerks were inattentative, curt and non-caring. The room was beautiful, however older people need to plug in heating pads, medical devices etc and there are no plugs by the beds. It took 3 calls to get an extension cord. No place to hang up the hand towels and face cloths in the beautiful bathroom and the shelves were a 1/2 in thick in dust. The casino was very loud at all times, much louder than others. This is not a complaint about losing, because we won big.

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievably amazing”
Reviews.Author: ahhhhtotravel
Reviews.Content: After watching a special on TV a month before our trip, we arrived in Vegas and stayed 3 days at another hotel. On the 3rd day, we had to check out the craze of the new City Center and the Crystals. After a cocktail in the City Bar at Aria, my husband disappeared and returned with reservations and said we are checking in here "tomorrow." After reading the review before our trip, I was discouraged to book our stay because of the newness of the properties - that will teach me to not believe everything you read. If you are reading this and still skepctical, I surely understand. The Aria far exceeded our wildest expectations. We were upgraded to a suite at check-in - the staff (Amber) at the check-in counter was extremely helpful - we only wish we had longer to enjoy all the amenities - we extended our stay another night because it was so fabulous - everything we encountered at the hotel was absolutely incredible - our views of the snow-covered mountains were awesome. Of course, every NEW propety has "kinks" to work out and knowing that before, you should have an automatic understanding that issues may arise. Thankfully, we did NOT run into any issues as we did with our first (a very well and highly recommended) hotel. We have been home for one week - and I'm ready to head back to Aria. Thank you ALL at Aria - you were wonderful!!!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Good and needs work”
Reviews.Author: frostfan1
Reviews.Content: What was excellent? The bed. Wife and I slept very well. Shower/bath combo was unique and wife enjoyed a bath. Wife liked spa but they didn't have everything that's advertised on their web page. What was good? Buffets were good but at $23.95 for Sunday brunch seems high. Italian restaurant upstairs was good not great but I did like Lobster Risotto. Others thought their food was salty. Bread was OK, not unforgettable. Casino is good but didn't seem real lively. Sports Book and adjoining bar and grill were good. What wasn't good. They ran out of non-smoking rooms at check-in and we had to change rooms the next morning after sleeping in a smoking room. Another friend changed rooms twice. Large remote is annoying. They need longer wires so you can use from both sides of bed.

Reviews.Title: “Awe inspiring”
Reviews.Author: richter_justin
Reviews.Content: Fantastic hotel. This was my 4th trip to Vegas, but it was my girlfriends first time. Both of our jaws dropped when we first drove up to the front. The hotel is HUGE! Modern, sleek, warm and inviting. The wood accents and the metal work everywhere made for a very cool place, especially for a 'geek' like myself. I fell in love with the remote in the room. Nowhere near as hard to control as other people on here have stated, you push the button for what you want to control, press the back button to go back. The only disappointing thing about the room control was that it wasn't on 'my side' of the bed, but I got over that minor detail because I am an adult and can cope with such small things. :) We absolutely loved the matress, like sleeping on a cloud sounds cliche, until you have slept on this bed. I have never slept that well on vacation, anywhere. The only thing that kept it from a 100% positive review was the shower head wasn't all that great for pressure. Aside from that, I couldn't think of anything that I had a problem with. The pool wasn't open yet, but most hotels pools are closed at this time of year anyway, so nothing to really complain about there. We were there for 5 days and 4 nights. We thought we had explored a fair amount of it the first day before we went out on the strip, but we found a huge section of the hotel we didn't see prior to on the 3rd day. So we still didn't see all of our own hotel. Just massive, but in a good way. And in a very Vegas way. If you are looking for a place to stay that is high end, and you actually prefer to stay in a place that doesn't have clowns and silly themes, this is definitley the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel...still working out the kinks.”
Reviews.Author: JohnnyMac13
Reviews.Content: I enjoyed the futuristic look of the hotel and the location is perfect. City Center is going to be a really great place once all of the hotels work out the initial kinks. I drove their with my four kids ages 18, 15, 12 and 10 in an over-sized vehicle, which I was forced to park off of the property. Customer services was good, but not great.

Reviews.Title: “I don't think we would come back”
Reviews.Author: ipreferwynns
Reviews.Content: We were very excited to be invited guests at this new hotel/casino. Our first experience was the less than stellar greeting we received when we accidently came to the sky suites entrance instead of the strip entrance. (A concierge had emailed this tip on using this entrance instead of the strip entrance.) The bellman didn't greet us, but berated our driver for bringing us to the wrong entrance. After he was done with the driver, it was our turn. He told us we were at the wrong entrance. I tried to explain that someone from Aria had told us to come in this entrance. The bellman (while my husband was pulling our luggage from the trunk of the car) told me that whomever told me that was wrong and a liar. He then pointed in the direction of the lobby and told us we had to go over there. No hello, welcome to aria, can I assist you, nothing. Upon check in, we received a room that was at least one quarter of a mile from the elevator. We dragged our luggage to our room and went down to the casino to play. The next morning, we left the room at 7:30 in the morning. When we got back at 5:00, the room had not been touched by housekeeping. The roomcleaner in the hall explained that she couldn't clean our room because she worked until five pm and would get in trouble if she stayed overtime. I called housekeeping and was told by the employee who answered the phone that they had a lot of rooms and if one room is dirty other rooms wouldn't get cleaned!? We did call Karen Ulna (Director of Guest Services) to ask her about the level of service we should expect at Aria. She was very apologetic and did give us a Food and Beverage Credit to make up for the lack of customer service we had been shown. My impression was that every disgruntiled union employee from other hotels in Vegas had come to work at Aria. Skip the buffet - food was so - so and had a very 70's cafeteria feel to it. We ended up calling the entire place Spacely Sprockets - very modern, didn't really care for that style of decor. Would definitly go to Encore, Wynn or Belagio again and again, prefer the customer service and the lushness of the entire experience

Reviews.Title: “Nightmare from beginning to end!”
Reviews.Author: Larryscary
Reviews.Content: I could go on and on about the horrible experience we had, but I will sum it up. 1. No bellman service at check..or so we thought, later to find out that they were standing around and watching us unload the car. 2. Check in line was about 45 minutes. 3. We upgraded to a suite which happened to be on a smoking floor. After numerous attempts to have them freshen up the room, they never did and we were stuck in a room that seemed like it was a 20 year old room that has been smoked in. Which leads me to my next point.. 3. There was no ventilation in the room. 4. From the minute we checked in, our tv didn't work and the clocks were wrong...we called maintenace 3-4 times and they claimed to fix it...sure enough they never worked the whole weekend. 5. Staff was rude and the service was horrible. 6. While playing at a high limit table, we tried to flag down a cocktail waitress for 45 minutes and she Never came. 7. Valet took about 40 minutes from the minute we got there, nothing went smooth and just about every single person we talked to had something negative to say about thi hotel. Do yourself a favor and DONT stay at the Aria!!

Reviews.Title: “Aria is a "nightmare"”
Reviews.Author: garywest
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Aria for four days in February and the trip was a certified nightmare from start to finish. Their entire in room system (everything) is build on a "computerized" system which is dysfunction at best and extremely unreliable. In fact, the first two rooms which I was taken to when I checked in were not operational---an hour and a half later they found me a room that was partially working. I still had to go up to the TV and work it manually from controls on the TV because they audio video system did not work. They had forgot to order their cell towers, so there was little if any cell coverage in the entire property. Once I was caught in an elevator for over 30 minutes on the 50th floor. It shook violently and I feared for my life. The employees told me this happens frequently. Although all other pools in the city were open, the Aria staff gave me a "BS" story why their's wasn't--very bad idea. There were days where housekeeping did not even clean entire parts of the suite---unbelievable. I stayed in and $800 per night suite which was very small---about 60% the size of a comparably priced suite at the Wynn or Bellagio. The decor was very "hard edged, cold and sterile". The furniture was literally hard---as in rock hard. The arms of the couch in the living room were made of a material that was as hard as a desk top---you could not rest your arm on it without your arm hurting. The lighting in the bathroom was so bad I could not even shave well, there would be no way a lady could do make up etc. I talked to over 50 other guests who had the same impression I did---they hated the place and will never go back. I talked to several cab drivers and they all told me that people leaving the property to go home volunteered they would never stay there again. Bottom line---I would NOT stay there if the room was free, and I predict this property will be in bankruptcy with a year.

Reviews.Title: “5 nights at Aria”
Reviews.Author: Holli999
Reviews.Content: My wife and I go to Las Vegas a few times a year. We like trying different places, so we were very excited to finally get to stay at Aria. Check in was a little slow, I tried the $20 trick to see if we could get a room upgrade. No luck and the woman kept my $20! Oh well, worth a shot. We has a standard king on the 36th floor. I really liked that the door unlocks by just placing your key near the sensor. I left my card in my wallet and it still worked. When you open the door, the curtains open and lights come on. It takes a couple minutes to figure out all the cool technology. You can control the lights, temperature, curtains and just about everything else right on the TV remote. The decor is very modern. Lots of clean lines and dark browns and blues. The TV hangs on the wall and is quite large.. maybe 42". The bed was amazing!! Very soft, very luxurious. There is a safe inside one of the nightstand drawers to keep cash and valuables. The chiller is very well stocked. No room for anything you might want to add in there. We called down to ask about bringing up a mini-fridge for us to use and they said it would be $25/day! No thanks. The bathroom was very nice, large walk in shower with adjustable spray. Only complaint here is that the vanity has only one sink and not much room on the granite for other items. The casino again is very modern. It's much darker than most casinos. Makes everything seem more serious. We did have a nice time playing craps, roulette and blackjack. The dealers were very professional and friendly. I spent quite a bit of time in the poker room. It is awesome. Very comfy adjustable seats, great dealers, fast drinks and good atmosphere. We ate at Jean Phillipe, Lemongrass, and Sirio. Food was great at all of them. We enjoyed the atmosphere and decor of Lemongrass the most. There is a tram that runs from Monte Carlo to Bellagio. There is a stop in the middle at Crystals. It's faster to walk from your room to the Monte Carlo tram than if you want to go to Bellagio. It's just right out the door by the poker room. The location of Aria is too far to make use of the Monorail, so if you want to visit The Venetian or Wynn, do yourself a favor and take a cab. My wife gives the spa high marks for her facial. We didn't get to spend much time in Crystals, but it is beautiful. The shopping is super high end.. not much in our price range. We prefer going to The Forum at Ceasars for shopping. Overall CityCenter and Aria were amazing. We got a really good rate of $109/night through my playersclub card. I'm sure we will stay there again in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Overall... Good Experience”
Reviews.Author: glanelig
Reviews.Content: We had a great time staying at this hotel. We stayed in one of the corner suites that overlooks the strip. The room was great and so was the view. I did have a few issues... The bed was way too soft. It was good to relax in and watch tv, but sleeping in it was a mission for me. I was tossing and turning most of the night. Due to the casino floor being so large it would take a long time to get a drink. I would have to wait about 30-45 minutes to get my drink from the beverage server. The view was great but the windows were dirty. I tried to take pictures but you can see all the dirty spots from the windows. Other than that our stay was pleasant. This was our first trip away without our kids. So maybe my sleep issues were caused by stress. We will more than likely return to this property in the future. The pool was not open while we were there... but it was no big deal because we didn't plan on using it. Too cold in February.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel”
Reviews.Author: daxtn
Reviews.Content: I very like this hotel. Best travel.Great Breakfast. The new concept in room control. Big room, very clean and check in and check out ok.

Reviews.Title: “Our stay was good”
Reviews.Author: gashouse47
Reviews.Content: By now you should know this is a modern themed hotel. They used a lot of darks colors for their walls which doesn’t give it a bright and shining look. I can say that we felt like it was a clean, comfortable working hotel. I will mention that check in was fairly quick at 2:30 pm and check out was just as quick at 6:45 am. Valet service only seemed to take 3 to 5 minutes. I thought that was good. I’m afraid I can’t speak to the food at the Aria because we are on the frugal side and we always ventured elsewhere to eat. I would recommend the Monte Carlo for breakfast. And it’s just a short walk, all on the inside, from the Aria. Now for the not so good, was that I couldn’t figure out how to turn the TV off without doing the “Blackout Room”. The touch screen remote was not scary though I did leave the wife in the dark once in the bathroom. I heard about it pretty quick though. That is more on me than the remote screen. I believe she was doing make-up or curling her hair at that moment. We did survive it though. If we go back I would stay for that price again. So if you like the Bellagio then stay there, personally I like the Venetian but we just couldn’t pass up the deal on the Aria this time. $671 for 4 nights, 2 adults with non-stop air through Southwest.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: socalluv2travel2010
Reviews.Content: We are frequent travelers to the Las Vegas area and wanted to try the new hotel, we were not disappointed! From check-in to check out we were taken care of to the last detail. We were in town for a National cheer competition for our daughter and had very odd hours, we checked into the hotel around 3pm and our room was not ready, we were offered another room, however, we were traveling with friends and wanted to be on the same floor with them, so we opted to wait. It was worth it, the rooms were spacious, the view gorgeous, beds and pillows so luxurious you will not want to get out of them! The hotel itself offers so many different places to eat, browse, shop, play, you will not get bored. Go and see for yourself, we are heading back as soon as we can.....oh forgot the casino...loved it! Not to smokey! They had a smell of vanilla - spice maybe, whatever it was it was great, we really enjoyed ourselves. No charge for valet parking every day, that was nice, very easy to get our car and we were in and out several time a day due to the competition being at another hotel. Staff were helpful at every turn. Can't wait to go back! Tip: Make a reservation for BESO restaurant connected to hotel-so good!

Reviews.Title: “My new mid-strip favorite!”
Reviews.Author: ejangles
Reviews.Content: I just came back from a stay at the Aria, Saturday through Wednesday. It's a magnificent hotel with fairly luxurious rooms. The service was great and the staff was very courteous. I see what people mean when they say it doesn't feel Vegas-y - it's contemporary and not themed at all. However, I think it's still very Vegas-y in its excesses, which is what I enjoy about Vegas. It certainly did feel a little bit like they cut some corners in making the place. The walls were a bit thin - I could hear conversations next door if they stood close to the shared wall and if they were talking loudly. The water tap for the left sink in the bathroom was also off-center slightly, which caused the water to splash out - we opted to share the right-side sink. The in-room technology was also rather buggy. We were all guys and gals in our 20s who use technology quite a bit in our daily lives (we had a computer science major with us, even), but the panel was a pain to use. The main problem was that the system is underpowered - there's a noticeable lag after each command, and if you make multiple inputs while it's processing your last command, the lags stack up. Very annoying. The good news is that it's easy enough to not use the touch panel and use the regular remote instead. Those complaints aside, the room was fantastic. The room decorations were very contemporary, which I liked, and there was plenty of space at 520 sq ft. The bathroom was awesome - I've stayed at a few other properties on the strip, including the Venetian and Palazzo, and I think the Aria bathroom was the best I've seen (other than the off-center water tap I mentioned above). It's smaller than the Venetian/Palazzo bathroom and doesn't have an in-bathroom TV, but the tub/shower was amazing. Again, to compare with the Venetian/Palazzo, the room was obviously smaller, but otherwise I actually liked it a lot better - the bed was nicer, the decoration was much smarter. I also liked the twice-a-day housekeeping service - it was nice to be able to go out for the morning/afternoon, come back to a fresh room, then go out again for the evening and return to a fresh room again. The casino was a little darker than some of the other casinos but not very much so. I think this is a matter of aesthetics - if you like the ultramodern contemporary look and feel of the place, I think you will enjoy the casino's ambiance as well. I did not gamble much at the Aria because it was a little pricey for my group. One thing I'll note as well is that a few of their slots changed games/$ through our stay - I noticed a Crystal Forest penny slot in one area one night, but when we came back it was different game. I'm hoping they're just trying to work out the layout of the slots, because it'd be pretty annoying if they are going to be constantly changing games. There is a noticeable smell in the casino, but it was fairly pleasant and low key, unlike the Venetian where I felt like I was being drowned in flowers. I really enjoyed the mid-strip location of the Aria. This part is fairly self explanatory and I don't need to tell you Vegas vets why the location is great, but I'd note that the tram that goes from Monte Carlo through Aria to Bellagio was actually very useful - we used it every day, both when we went north and when we went south. Overall, Aria is one of my new favorite properties on the strip. I love how it looks, I love the rooms, and I love the location. In terms of ranking, I am having a hard time deciding whether I like it better or worse than Palazzo - I really like the aesthetic of Aria and the location, but Palazzo has the edge on the rooms and the gambling (well, not at the Palazzo, but at the Venetian). I didn't eat or shop at Aria, and I didn't use the pool (wasn't open yet), and I didn't visit any of the other CityCenter properties, so I've got no comment on those topics.

Reviews.Title: “There are better values to be found in the crowded Vegas hotel market”
Reviews.Author: carab78
Reviews.Content: We recently spent three nights at the Aria Hotel for a retreat I was attending further up the strip. The hotel itself is nothing special in comparison to other hotels in the mid-Strip area. The room we booked was the standard non-City View room. It was fine but nothing spectacular and we had a "mountain view" which means we faced the freeway and the Palms condos, which was not an issue for us. On our second night our "techinically advanced" room stopped working. We couldn't turn the lights on or off and we couldn't close the curtains. We called the desk to ask for assistance, waited for half an hour, called again and finally got the front desk to send up a technician to look at the system. He said it couldn't be fixed that night and we would have to move rooms. He called the front desk and requested us to be moved. We were told a bellboy would come to our room with a set of keys for the new room. We waited. And waited. And waited. I called again and they said they were working on it and he would be there soon. And we waited some more. I called a third time and a desk person said they would meet us at the new room. At this point we had been dealing with the old room being "broken" and the attempt to get into a new room for an hour and a half. We finally got into our "upgraded" City View room after midnight. City View, unless you pay for a real suite, means you face the condos right in front of the hotel and get a view of the Monte Carlo, through dirty windows. We complained to management the next day about the customer service, which was our real concern, and all we received was a food credit. We've stayed in many hotels in Vegas, most in the MGM-Mirage group, and have basically been happy with all of them. This doesn't even come close. You are better off spending a few extra dollars a night and staying at the Bellagio or try your luck further up the strip.

Reviews.Title: “The Aria Hotel is not in the same league as the Bellagio, Wynn, or the Venetian”
Reviews.Author: monopoly12
Reviews.Content: We have been to Vegas many times and have stayed in many of the best hotels. This time we selected Aria because we wanted to try the new 5 star hotel. It was a disappointment from the time we arrived. The curbside service was nonexistent. There were no automatic doors at the entry making it difficult to get the luggage inside. The first look inside the lobby is cold and stark not at all what you would expect for a 5 star hotel. The rooms were attractively decorated and a comfortable size but the beds were really soft with no support!! The bathroom was very nice. The new all electronic key pads for turning off the lights or opening the sheers and curtains were completely ridiculous. You could spend several minutes just trying to get the lights on or off. The swimming pool was not even open. Definitely not in the same league as the Bellagio, Wynn, Venetian or even the Mirage.

Reviews.Title: “Best resort in Vegas”
Reviews.Author: VegasFan27
Reviews.Content: I would say I'm a Vegas expert having made about 5 trips per year for the last 22 years. Before this trip I had always told everyone that no place in Vegas could compare with the Venetian but the Aria beats even that property. The basic rooms are not quite as large as the Venetian's but still much larger than a standard room anywhere else. The technology is first class and easy to use. The Casino is very chic but inviting with a very open airy feel. The elevators are the best I've ever used in Vegas..never more than a 1 minute wait and never packed since each floor grouping has 8 lifts and the floor groups are smaller than most other properties. Staff was truely a pleasure and must love their jobs..The buffet ,which is something I rarely do (kind of a food snob), was out of this world...on the weekends it's a champange brunch..full of crab legs, shrimp, rack of lamb, prime rib and all the breakfast goodies..even though it's a buffet the waiter was always around for drink refills and clearing the table. If you drive to Vegas use the North Valet off Harmon...it was a busy weekend but very few people know there is a valet on that side which also puts you very close to the elevators when checking out.. Hands down best hotel/resort in Vegas

Reviews.Title: “A pleasant time.”
Reviews.Author: VWDavisJr
Reviews.Content: Stayed 3 nights, Feb 19 -22. We arrived just as Obama was leaving. This was our first trip to Vegas so I can't compare to other hotels in the area. However, my wife and I enjoyed our stay very much. No major problems encountered. Check in and Check out was painless, but this could have been our timing. The hotel is very nice, clean, and enormous. Lots of browns and earth tones. The technology in the room was simple to use, though we did unintentionally turn off everything in the room several times by hitting the wrong button and the desk lamp had a blown bulb which we reported but was never changed. There is a north entrance off of Harmon that is good for going and coming as the cab stand is right outside the door. Whereas at the front entrance the cab stand is a short walk away. There is no check in/out counter at the north entrance so use the front when initially arriving. Electric doors at both entrances, but require that you hit a button for the door to open. We ate at Sage (nominated for a Beard award), Bar Masa (Japanese Cuisine), Chill (Ice cream, sandwiches, and coffee), and Jean Philippe patisserie (deserts, sandwiches, salads, coffee) and another smaller coffee shop over by the tram called the coffee bean or grind something like that (deserts, sandwiches, coffee). Great food and service at all places mentioned. On the first day we tried the buffet and though the selection was modest the food just didn't taste very well, except the deserts, but excellent service by our waiter. We did room service each morning for breakfast and were pleased with both the food and service. You must try Sage and Bar Masa for dinner, well worth the money. Would avoid buffet however. One of the swimming pools and 3 hot tub pools opened while we were there (Sat). They are very nice and heated to ensure comfort. Laid about there for several hours with temps in the 60's quite comfortably. Nice cabanas too. Our room was on the 19th floor, south west side facing Mandalay Bay and the mountains and we had no problems using our Verizon cell phones (Driods) or the 3G laptop connect card. Therefore we did not use the hotel internet service. As previously noted by others the floor to ceiling windows were really dirty on the outside, but that didn't detract much from the awesome views. The Crystal City Mall was nice but we didn't buy anything there. There are some nice shops in the Aria itself. There is a really nice store/gift shop at the north entrance that has about anything you could need along with souvenirs etc. There is a CVS just a short 5 min walk up the street as well. They don't have many towels in the room (2 sets) and if you put on the privacy light at night, and skip turn down service, this can be a pain. The staff and dealers were very friendly. We put a hurting on them at the craps and blackjack tables and made enough back to all but cover the cost of the trip. Played slots and video poker a few times but didn't win anything with those. Nice sports book and poker room also. We used the tram to go over to the Bellagio to see the fountains. We took a cab to the Venetian to see the Blue Man Group where I had booked tickets from Vegas.com and we had great center stage seats. I recommend the show if you never seen it--It is really cool. We passed on the Elvis show at the Aria so I can't comment on that. Go and stay at the Aria, you will have a fine time. Everything cost big so take lots of money, your gonna need it, unless of course lady luck smiles on you. Good Luck at the Tables!

Reviews.Title: “Would Not Recommend the Aria to my Friends”
Reviews.Author: JayMoore74
Reviews.Content: The Good The rooms are nice, with plenty of HDTV channels to watch. City Center is architecturally amazing. The Bad First of all, the main entrance wreaked of raw sewage almost the whole weekend. If you cannot work a cell phone, you cannot stay at the Aria because you will not be able to figure out how use the touch screen command center in the room. There were shards of glass throughout the room from previous guests that we kept stepping on. The toilet in the room would run constantly after flushing it, and when we called to get it fixed nobody ever came to fix it. The casino was HOT, temperature wise, I would say 75 degrees, not very comfortable. The dealers were not fun, happy, or attractive. Overall, not worth the price.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: ljmotta
Reviews.Content: Hotel is new and very confortable, modern, rooms are gorgeus and have awesome views, specially at night, to Las Vegas Boulevard (The Strip). Casino is huge, well-decorated and has a great atmosphere. Very entertainment!

Reviews.Title: “Worst Hotel Experience in 20 Years of Vegas”
Reviews.Author: LABizTraveler
Reviews.Content: I guess they teach the staff at Aria to just smile no matter what the guests complain about as I wasn't the only one who spent more time at the front desk with problems than elsewhere on the property while the Aria people just smiled and did nothing. Not only did I spent an inordinate amount waiting in line to check in and for every other issue but the room I was first given was open and not cleaned (at 7pm) and then I had to use my cell phone to get someone at the front desk since I was on hold through the room phone for 30 mins. When I finally got to a clean room, the keys didn't work and again later than night. The technology that the hotel boasts seems to require a card carrying Mensa member to figure out and no matter what the problem, they treat everyone the same and just smile without listening. The rooms are horribly designed as well...few outlets, a shower/tub combo that if you slip leaves you with a concussion and lying in a tub hopefully to be found by housekeeping (who likes to leave their cleaning sprays in the bathroom for handy usage the next day btw), automatic curtains that have a mind of their own and "new" flat screensTVs that seem to act like plasmas with a burned out tube with varying flickering lighting on yoru favorite channels. Oh, and did I mention the billing system on the TV for check out didn't work and I had to go stand in line again at the front desk to check out only to be told I already did and I missed my flight? Oh Oh, AND they charge you to call from the room to the front desk or t o make reservations through the phone with their own internal system...they said it was a glitch but to charge me $1 to call an internal extension....that put me over the edge! I had 20 clients and colleagues in town and none of us had a good experience.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Jenny041
Reviews.Content: This was our first visit to Vegas so had no idea what to expect. We were booked into the Hotel Aria by the travel agent. It is brand new and opened in Dec 09. The hotel is really spacious and clean. Very luxurious feel to it with lots of textures everywhere. We stayed in a Deluxe room which is their basic room and it was enormous. Very comfortable bed and pillows. Gorgeous bathroom with a shower and tub to die for - fresh toiletries daily! Great in-room technology on a touch screen by the bed which controlled everything in the room. Very sumptuous. Nice central location on the strip. Lots of restaurants inside, huge casino, ice cream bar, coffee shop and pattisserie. We ate in the thai restaurant, Lemongrass which was nice and also the Veterro which was good also. Also had the breakfast buffet a couple of times which had a great selection for a reasonable price. The only meal we didn't enjoy was the dinner buffet. Beautiful pools outside also! All in all this is the nicest most luxurious hotel I have ever stayed in and we did not want to leave!

Reviews.Title: “Chic and modern hotel & casino”
Reviews.Author: RambleOnRI
Reviews.Content: I stayed here with my sister for two nights over Valentine's weekend. After a stay at another hotel for two nights and days spent roaming through all of the Vegas casinos before checking in here, this place was a breath of fresh air. The lobby, casinos and bars are very clean and modern. A lot of dark wood tones and cool decor & fabrics. I do concur with other reviewers that check-in took a while. I wated in line at the concierge while my sis waited to check-in. concierge was very friendly and got us a dinner ressie at a prime time on Valentine's Day. The room was awesome. Once again very clean and modern. All of the electronics (which pretty much control everything in the room!) took a little getting used to. Amazing views of the strip. My only complaint about the room is that the bathroom set up is a little weird. It's all marble and has a crazy echo. The shower and tub are in one "room" with a glass door, and the toilet in a separate room with a frosted glass door, there are two sinks but hardly any room on the counter. Other than that room decor was very cool. This is THE MOST COMFORTABLE bed I have ever slept in at a hotel! Went to Julian Serrano on the first floor of the hotel/casino and had amazing sangria and tapas. Liked that the casino was very clean (did not smell of smoke yet!) but the tables were pricey. Pretty short walk to the strip. Easy walking to high end shops. Rather long line for a cab. All in all a good stay! One more thing- pool was not open yet but looks like it is going to be great when it does...this will be a big draw for this hotel I think!

Reviews.Title: “Sophisticated Hotel”
Reviews.Author: travel_sweeties
Reviews.Content: Spent a night at the Aria in Las Vegas and it did not fail to impress. State of the art hotel...all controls are computerized. The bed is one of the softest we've ever slept on. Staff are nice and accomodating.

Reviews.Title: “Definitely not a 5 star hotel - very poor service.”
Reviews.Author: kvesq
Reviews.Content: Pros: 1. new 2. central location on the strip 3. high tech room 4. eco-friendly construction 5. nice bathroom (nice tub & two sinks), eco friendly low flow shower heads and toilet. 6. food was very good in all the restaurants 7. nice view from our room 8. they allowed us to check out one hour later w/o problems Cons: 1. Housekeeping stinks - a staff member knocked and walked into our room two times while our privacy light was on, they did not replace our towels properly (the sign said they would not take away towels that were not on the floor to save water but they did it anyway and forgot to replace them all leaving us short face towels or hand towels on occasion), glasses/ toiletries were not properly replenished; & finally they threw souvenir glasses away but let our other fast food cups sit in the same spot for two days (not that we wanted to keep the souvenirs but some ppl like those souvenir cups mine was a yard long Eiffel tower!), 2. not completely eco friendly w/ all the technology, no recycling, did not really seem to enforce vip parking for low emission/fuel efficient vehicles in the parking garage &, too many phones (3 one of which was cordless & we were not even in a large suite!) 3. no coffee maker 4. refrigerator was filled w/ mini bar items & no room for your own items 5. $35 per day per person to use the fitness facilities 6. although the view was nice, the windows were very dirty so it was distracting - a little nicer to have the sheer drapes mask the dirty windows 7. when the room adjacent to us was occupied we could hear them talking 8. bed is too soft 9. always a wait on the phone to talk to front desk 10. checking into the hotel was not that easy - nobody to help w/ bag and the doors did not automatically open & you have to navigate through the large casino to get to the check in area and then the guest elevators (we had to ask for directions to get to the elevators rather than automatically being directed to them by the person who checked us in)

Reviews.Title: “Angry, frustrated, and looking into a lawsuit against this hotel!!”
Reviews.Author: Mzmink
Reviews.Content: We have stayed with Aria's sister property, Bellagio before, and dropped over $100,000 our last trip there last year. So we decided on a whim to try out the newest hotel on the strip: Aria. Words fail to describe just how bad our experience was. Everything went wrong straight away; from the limo service to the hotel to the check in experience. The suite was nothing spectacular...but that's not really the point of my review. More importantly, it's that I was actually yelled at by one of their staff members. This was while I was searching for the ladies room, and didn't understand exactly where it was...it was confusing due to the fact that it's joined all within the same entry as the men's room and the companion restroom. I have multiple sclerosis, which is a disease of the central nervous system; this can cause me to have great confusion at times. Which lead to the employee of this hotel to YELL REPEATABLY at me, and to even go so far as to point me out to OTHER GUESTS, and make a very snide comment about me. My husband immediately went to speak with the hotel management about this employee, and they were allegedly "flabbergasted" at the employee's behavior. But then the management never bothered to do much more than to apologize to my husband for me. They never made a point to walk over to me to apologize to me personally. Furthermore, there is absolutely nowhere to sit in the casino, unless you spend money in a restaurant or at a slot machine. Doing these things is fine...but what about when you just want to take a break, and want to sit and relax without spending money for a few moments??? Sure, there is some granite benches (very few) located in the main lobby. But that's it. If you have a disability such as I do, you are just out of luck. It's a complete seperation of healthy people and people with disabilities. After thinking the experience over, my husband and I are strongly looking into a lawsuit against this hotel. We feel that no one should ever be yelled at by a hotel employee...especially not us, considering we have spent between Bellagio and Aria dollars well into the 6 figure range. Besides, it's important that this hotel management recognizes the importance of it's employees being instructed by their human resources department some sensativity training in regards to the Americans With Disabilities Act.

Reviews.Title: “Bad location, dirty rooms, long walk,cool technology”
Reviews.Author: MistyRim2001
Reviews.Content: We decided to stay at the Aria because it looked very nice and we figured it would be a different experience. From the begining it was different. It took over 30 mins to check in (doesn't included standing in line). It also took over an hour to get our luggage from the bell desk (spent 35 mins on hold). The room was neat to walk into because of technology reasons. When we got to the room the trash was not dumped and being in a smoking room seems like ash trays would have been there but there wasn't any. Finding the room was a hassle. Took 10 mins to get to the room from the elevator. Once we finally got our luggage and got ready to go out to the strip, it took over an hour to get out there. We did get $50 dollar comp for the mishabs so we ate at the buffet. It had a large selection but the food wasn't worth the price...thank God we used our comp. We decided to check out after one night and had a blast down on fremont street. This hotel is more for the people who want to spend time in the room or around the hotel. Since I'm young I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who wants to drink on the strip. However my mother checked out and said she wouldn't recommend either.

Reviews.Title: “Aria is Excellent!”
Reviews.Author: Steaker73
Reviews.Content: I just spent Valentine's weekend at the new Aria Hotel and Casino. I have been keenly watching the construction of this facility for a few years now and I am glad to say that this hotel lived up to the hype. Beautiful state of the art rooms, wonderful decor throughout the entire hotel and excellent service. We had an amazing Valentine's dinner at Sirio's in Aria. Best Italian Food Experience Ever!!!! My girlfriend had the gnocchi and I had the lasagna for entrees. I'm not much of a wine connoisseur but their wine list was huge. We were going to go with the 1986 Italian Red for $17,500 but decided on the Cabernet by the glass for $20. :) Also ate at the Buffet at Aria and Skybox Sports Bar and Grill. Casino was great. Dealers and Pit Bosses were very friendly. Waitresses were serving you very promptly when gambling. I did well at the tables so before we went out on the town for Valentine's, I treated myself to a Sportsman's Grooming Shave with Brian at the Spa. He has created a great old school barber shop right in the middle of this modern hotel. Highly recommend the shave boys! If I had to have one knock on Aria it was this: We paid to upgrade our room for one with a better view. I was shocked to find that the outside of the windows were filthy. It was impossible to take a decent picture with the windows in this conditions. But I'll chalk it up to construction dust. Hopefully they will remedy this situation. Great experience at Aria and I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Expect to be Impressed”
Reviews.Author: theresa1970
Reviews.Content: My bf and I stayed here last week, and we were definetly impressed. Check in was a little long but worth it. Upon entering your room the curtains open, the tv comes on with relaxing music, and the lights come on. Talk about technology. Everything about the room was impressive. The bathroom was awesome as well with a tub and seperate shower. This was the cleanest room I have ever experienced. There are alot of snooty people in here. The slots are also for the high spenders. I did not noticed too many people gambling here. I lost a few hundred in about five minutes on the slots. That is not fun for me. I went over to Excalibur and a great time for hours and hours. I highly recommed this hotel if you are looking for luxury, but gambling is not desired for me here. The staff is also snooty I did not find one friendly staff member. I felt like they were robots. It also seems like they have a preference to hiring asains.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing!-Completely missed their mark”
Reviews.Author: Kat0412
Reviews.Content: Similar to another review I saw, I've never written a review but I was so disappointed by Aria that I felt THIS compelled to warn others to choose elsewhere. Admittedly, some of the points pertain more strongly to women and men. This will be short and sweet. And I'll start with the most disappointing points first. 1. Phone reception sucks unless you have Sprint (at least someone with Sprint told me that this). You will have minimal IF ANY reception in the hotel The first floor or near windows are seemingly better for reception. 2. I could hear ALL my neighbors' conversations in their rooms. 3. The pickup for valet is FAR away from the reception. 4. The bathtub is behind the shower in ONE unit. 5. The water pressue in the shower is low. 6. No counter space in the bathroom, no vanity area and no alternate "vanity" area in the living area to allow someone to get ready outside the bathroom. 7 Insufficient plugs. Only two on the desk and two in the bathroom 8. The ambience is NOT calming and the interior decoration is like they tried to cram every "great" idea in at once. 9. Bad Customer Service - We did not get the room we reserved and they refused to comp us for taking a staying in a room we did not want (wanted 2 queen beds but had to take one with only one king). 10. Bad Customer Service - We requested a late checkout the night before and then when we called again the next morning to confirm they said that under no circumstances could we have a late checkout but then after arguing further., then "found" the note in the system. 11 Bad Customer Service - When our room service was brought to our room, the server proceeded to tell of us other menu items not listed in the menu...we were unable to change our order by that time. 12. The clubs and lounges were less than exciting...

Reviews.Title: “Will stay again..”
Reviews.Author: Scottiehere
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 4 night business trip staying at the Aria. I was a little worried as i had booked before I had read alot of the bad reviews on here so i was expecting the worst when i arrived but I was happily proven wrong. Check in was 10min (and it was busy) I was given a room on the 23rd floor and getting to and from my room was not time consuming (the lifts were outstandingly efficient) Room was beautiful, beds VERY soft which i like. If anything the only issue was the control pad, which up until the last day worked fine but there were a couple of little tech issues eg while trying to select the tv to watch the curtains opened?? I'm sure this could just a programming or calibration issue with the touch pad. The design and layout of the hotel is quite awe inspiring with lots of choices in restaurants, though be prepared, they are quite pricey. The buffet has a good choice if you're on a budget and has a nice selection of cuisines. Lemongrass (Thai restaurant) I dined at twice finding this the most reasonably priced and the food was ok though nothing to write home about. Staff throughout the hotel were all extremely polite and helpful. Overall an enjoyable stay and I will stay again as its central location is very convenient when attending conferences in various locations across the city, but, i would not recommend for the price conscious visitor unless you are prepared to eat and drink elsewhere in Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “World-class experience in a state-of-art facility”
Reviews.Author: JaxSteve
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I just spent 5 days/4 nights at the ARIA. Our experience was more than magical. Check- in was smooth and efficient with the clerk helping us finding a great room with a mountain (west) view. The room was extremely large at 520sqft. The electronics worked fine including the HDTV and auto curtains. Beds very comfortable. We had lunch at Café Vettro and were immediately seated and then offered the services of an efficient waitress. The steak sandwich and cheese steak sandwich were above average. One morning my girlfriend enjoyed the spa for a few hours and reported an excellent experience. Over 80,000 sqft with 65 rooms this place is world class. The gaming floor is so beautiful with dark lighting, earth tones, state of the art serve- based slots, and great cocktail waitress service. This was our casino of choice during our stay. We even saw the Elvis which we highly recommend. Overall we enjoyed a world-class experience. And do not forget to enjoy the FOCUS waterfall outside the main entrance.

Reviews.Title: “So Disappointed!!!”
Reviews.Author: lachel97
Reviews.Content: AS OF FEB 15-19....2010 After reading all of the reviews we still chose to try out this recently built hotel.....WHY BOTHER!!!! Prior to arriving to this hotel, we upgraded our room to the One Bedroom Sky Suites, WHAT AT JOKE! One of the amenities to booking this hotel was a stretch limo to and from the airport, and VIP status with "No" line waits..ha! When my spouse and I first arrived at the Aria of course we had to wait about 10mins before we got our room keys.....but before that we got hit immediately with SOME HIDDEN FEES! We had already upgraded the room days before for an extra $1000, so they wanted my credit card AGAIN....to "Hold" an additional $560 for incidental charges for the room, and they stated that it would be refunded after checkout. After all the extra drama and stress at the front desk, my spouse and I finally got to the room, what a sight to see....the room was beautiful.... (KEEP READING)...everything is completely operated but the touch of a remote which got really aggravating after awhile due to the fact that the curtains would open by themselves and the lights would turn on by itself as well...the only thing that we were pleased about was the bed was sooooo unbelievably comfortable!!! That's the only thing that this luxury hotel had to offer, we ordered from In Room Dining a few times, the food was tasteless. Whomever built this hotel really didn't think this one through, the hotel itself is huge so get ready for "ALOT" of Walking,we were very disappointed with the staff and just this hotel period, everything was so over-priced....Oh and a friendly reminder if there is a wet bar in your room, and you don't plan to take advantage of it...DO NOT TOUCH IT!!....They claim that if the items are not in place meaning that you remove it...its automatically CHARGED to your room...although they told us, that if we took an item out, in 45sec it would be charged to the room...So Look and Don't Touch My Advice would be to avoid this hotel all together, it maybe appealing to the eye....but its Damage to your pockets and or your Bank Account.After a long week once we finally checked out here it goes again....more hidden fees and surprises, well the extra $560 that we had to put up for the incidental charges , wouldn't be refunded for 24-48hrs...and they charged us $200 a day for the upgraded room, when days before I had already spent $1000 for the upgrade, so they charged us TWICE!!!! Let's Just Say Im Still Waiting for the Funds to be put back in my account, and NOONE could give me a good explanation on why we were overcharged twice...Unless you have money to burn....Don't Waste Your Time, Or Your Money Staying Here.....The staff clearly needs more training. If you chose to stay here sleep here, and game at the other hotels, and casinos on the strip! WASTE OF TIME.....HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE

Reviews.Title: “Do not eat at the Cafe Vettro II”
Reviews.Author: No_junkmail
Reviews.Content: Went to eat at the Cafe Vettro after getting in to the hotel around 11 P.M. Sat at the table for 15 minutes after being seated without a person even acknowledging we existed. Finally just got up and left. I wish I had read the reviews on this place before I wasted my time. The hotel is nice, but nothing to write home about. It's just new...for now. With the service staff they have working at the hotel, I don't know how long people will keeping to the place.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Visit to Aria”
Reviews.Author: wetzmill
Reviews.Content: We were thrilled with the new Aria Hotel. The service, room and workers were fantastic. Check in was 5 minutes. Room was fantastic. All workers were at Aria were A1..... Electronics in room were very easy to operate. Restaurants were pricey but very nice and good food. Casino is easy to navigate, plenty of slots and table games. Wish they paid out a bit more.... Check out was easy and no add ones for final billing. We will stay at Arria next time in Vegas. Fantastic visit. Thank You !!! AAAAAA++++++++

Reviews.Title: “WHAT A FANTASTIC NEW ADDITION TO LAS VEGAS”
Reviews.Author: Ludmilla1
Reviews.Content: Our ARIA Review January 2009 After reading everything I could on Facebook about ARIA. I pestered the heck out of Walter in the Concierge desk. He started about a month before ARIA opened and was very helpful about handicap facilities and all the room amenities. We arrived on Saturday afternoon, at the invited guest’s desk and were given the handicap room I had asked for. However, when we Got to the room we discovered that it did not have a sunken tub, so we called down and asked to be moved to a regular deluxe king room. This only took 10 minutes and we were settled in. The room is much larger than a standard hotel room, room to walk around, look out the floor to ceiling windows and everything is electronic. The flat screen HD TV was great, and everything was accessible from it. The lighting, the drapes, the guest services to check your bill, a station with a TV guide type of style, movies galore, wake up, radio, you name it. For someone in her 60’s it took me a few hours to become comfortable with it, but after that it was a snap. There is a refrig, stocked to the hilt, don’t touch or you bought it. In the hallway, there are double closets and the softest robes you will ever put on. The bathroom has double sinks and plenty of space for your “stuff” The toilet is in a separate room, with glass you can not see thru. The shower is huge with a large seat in the back of it. After the shower, you can step into the sunken tub and soak your tension away. It was lovely. The towels are extremely large and very, very soft. There is a hair dryer already plugged in on one of the shelves of the vanity. All the products are just great, even their soap with logo is in a shape that fits your hand perfectly. Shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, lotion, mouth wash were all supplied, along with a lovely kit in the middle drawer, with cue tips, cotton balls, sewing kit, shower cap, etc. Now I did read in advance that there were no outlets near the beds as everything is electronic. So I left my C-Pap machine at home, there is a very large clock on the night stand, as well as phone and also a phone in the toilet area. There were 2 chairs to watch TV with a small table in between them and also a desk and chair under the TV. We soon ventured down to the casino floor, very airy, NO smoke smell; Walter told me that there are sensors to absorb the smoke under the slot machines. I never had a problem breathing, and I usually do. There are thousands of machines, mostly the newer style, I wished for more triple reel slots, but I hear they are coming. There is a new 4 screen Sex in the City, a penny machine and for $2.00 you can play all 4 reels at one time and we did quite well with that machine. Because we play a lot of MGM places, we took the brand new monorail over to the Bellagio and had a great time. The year of the Dragon is set up in the Conservatory and very well done. Tram was fast, easy to find, and if you can’t there is always someone around that will kindly escort you directly to it. We ate the wonderful Steak House and had great steaks with fresh cut fries and Brussels sprouts that were sautéed in a pan. They were wonderful. They have 4 kinds of sauces for your steak, but I asked the waiter for some garlic butter and had it within 4 minutes. Also, a place you should not miss eating is at the sports bar. The best sweet potatoes fries I have ever tasted. We also ordered hand cut fries topped with garlic and Parmesan cheese. The sliders were first rate. ARIA is a first class hotel with every amenity you could ask for and more. I Highly recommend that you check this hotel out on your next stay in Las Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “has so much potential by its looks”
Reviews.Author: NYSinger1
Reviews.Content: I travel to Las Vegas a few times a year. I usually stay at an MGM property. I love modern art, so wanted to stay at City Center to get good feel for the artwork they have. The place looks beautiful.....that's where the fun ends. The check in staff were not very courteous or gracious. The room looks night, but everything feels very cheaply done. For a 5* hotel, it is definitely missing the mark. There was still masking tape on the outside of my very dirty window. There was also hair in the shower drain. My favorite part is how horrible the ventilation system is. I learned this because it seemed as if every night I came to my room, it smelled like pot. The spa was mediocre. The gym is very nice. I would recommend you visit the city center, and not stay at the Aria. The Hotel @ Mandalay Bay is far superior.

Reviews.Title: “Luxury Hotel”
Reviews.Author: triptraveler18
Reviews.Content: Definitely a place to return. The pools were not opened yet, but didn't expect them to be. Could've used Bellagio's but they don't really publicize it. The rooms were great. Lots to view; it is part of City Center which is huge. Did eat at the buffet; nice but Bellagio's is outstanding (and I don't particularly like buffets, but would go back to Bellagio's). Checkout - should've done it on the TV but glad we stood in the very s - l - o - w line as the checkout agent found phone calls on my bill that were not mine and promptly removed them. Internet access is an additional fee. Fitness center is an additional fee. You can leave the hotel and find free internet pretty easily.

Reviews.Title: “Not a 5-star...yet.”
Reviews.Author: ChefPeterG
Reviews.Content: Much to admire about this hotel, but many problems that should have been worked out prior to opening. Upon arrival, only one clerk working check-in on Friday of Valentine's weekend (lengthened by President's Day on Monday). Once about 20 people were in the queue, they added a couple more clerks, but then committed the cardinal sin: individual lines heading to separate clerks. Better to have one feeder line so you don't get stuck in the slow line. This is basic people-herding, and I'm surprised they didn't implement it. Check-in was an exercise in putting off their upsell, which I did not appreciate. Clerk did not have our reservation information, even though I'd made the reservation online two weeks prior. Stopped at concierge desk and would have been better off making our own reservations: system was painfully slow and the clerk couldn't find the boxing event we'd asked about even though we later (and instantly) found it in their weekly events brochure. Room was very nice: technology all over, dark and quiet, and the bed was dangerously comfortable. Very clean and we had excellent room service. I too was charged $20 for tech service from the mini-bar even though I hadn't used anything. Bathroom is spacious and clean, but the lack of electric outlets is a problem. The hotel itself shows well, but 5-stars are usually brimming with world-class artwork. Maybe I missed it. Food overall was surprisingly lacking, with one excellent exception. Serio Restaurant is overpriced and under-everything else. Gordon Ramsay would go hoarse in that kitchen. Calamari was greasy and chewy and when I pointed it out, all I got was a "thanks for the feedback, but we're still working on our menu." Hello? How about, "sorry, sir, I'll take that off your bill and dessert is on the house." Standard reply at any better restaurant. I didn't pay to provide them feedback on a bad meal. Ravioli trio equally bad, and salads left much to be desired. As bad as Serio was, we found Sage outstanding in almost every way. Food was outrageous! Foie Gras brulee is not to be missed and was well worth the $10 surcharge. Wagyu beef was divine, as were the diver scallops and crab. Service was prompt, friendly and attentive without being overbearing. Only hiccup the entire evening was the late arrival of the bread, which bumped into the first course. But we had moved tables, so I guess it's forgiveable. We had an excellent time in the casino and found most of the dealers engaging and friendly, with a couple notable exceptions (we didn't stay long with the grouches). We tip really well, so that may explain why we made money AND got good service. Drinks were top shelf (Glenlivet, Hennessey, etc), arrived fast, and poured generously. The ventilation system is definitely underpowered, though, and the temperature was generally a tad too warm. Check-out was smooth, but Aria should add a complementary shuttle bus to the airport and move the taxi pick-up location closer to the main lobby. I've stayed at other 5-star hotels and the Aria is not in the same league. I'd give it 3 1/2, maybe 4 stars, but there's much to be worked out. For the same money, next time we'll stay in one of the other, more well-established, better run hotels.

Reviews.Title: “Impressive”
Reviews.Author: wyoungaz
Reviews.Content: Like everyone else, I had read the poor reviews for this new hotel. I was really worried and expected very little. I found it to be one of the nicest hotels I have ever stayed at. The exterior entrance with the shooting fountains, falling water on the walls and the really cool architechure was amazing. Inside the hotel was beautiful. It was hard to figure out how to get around but that applies to almost all the Las vegas casinos. The casino was not dark but almost soothing. There was no lingering smoke smell that some older casinos have. I was very impressed with the sports book. It had a lounge attached that just showed sporting events. It was very comfortable and fun as the servers were always there asking if we wanted a drink. The staff went out of their way to be friendly and helpful. Check-in was fast enough even though we had to wait quite a while for our room to be assigned. The room was great, and had plenty of room. The computerized board that ran all the items in the room was fun to play with and nice to have right beside our bed. The shower was great and roomy with an effective showerhead. The bed was sooo comfortable but I could see how some people would get a sore back from how soft it is. The Aria is a little far from the Strip but Las Vegas is about walking. Its location is fantastic. We only ate in the Sports Grill and the service and food was above average. The prices were decent for lunch. What an impressive structure. I hope the prices don't go too high to prevent us coming back to stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty Good-Happy With Stay”
Reviews.Author: sdny
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the Aria and after reading the reviews I was a bit worried. We checked in on a Saturday at around 4pm and it went pretty quick for us (2 groups in front of us and maybe 10-15 minutes later we were in our room). We asked for a king room a few doors away from the elevator based on previous reviews about the long walk to rooms on the end. They accomodated and even gave us a strip view room on the 9th floor. Would have liked to been up higher but the room had a great view anyways. I really liked the style of the hotel and all the brown didn't bother me...actually I think some of it is purple but it looks brown becuase it is kinda dark. Security at elevators didn't bother me and I felt better that they were there. I found them pleasant not rude as others have stated. Couple comments on the technology...I too found the technology to be cool and easy to use with the exception of a couple things that I'll point out...I couldn't figure out how to turn the TV off from the master remote panel...I could just be dense and there were some unlabled buttons on the bottom that maybe would have done it...but luckily they also give you a TV remote and the few times I needed to turn off the TV I just did it with that remote. The other thing with the TV was the cound...it is very low and its hard to hear a differnece as you turn it up on the master panel...but the panel is working you just have to keep tapping the up volume button a LOT to start hearing the difference. I also wanted to comment on some of the reviews related to rooms not being serviced. I think that in some instances this may have been the reult of the technology in the room as well. There is a panel next to the door twhere you can trigger the privacy signal or a service signal. Our first night as we went to sleep we put the "privacy" signal on...the next day we left and never flicked it off...we didn't realize it was even on when we left and as a result we returned to our room at 5PM and found our room was not made up AND I noticed we had left the privacy signal on. So when we left for dinner and gambling later in the eve we switched it over to Service but by then i think it was too late and when we got back at late in the evening it still wasn't serviced...we didn't care all that much as we still had two clean towels...then about half hour after we returned there was a knock on the door and they were there to service the room...we just told them we wanted towles and the obliged and left. They didn't wake us up. Next days we got our "signals" right and the room was serviced as we would expect. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants so can't comment on that....we did enjoy and use the tram to Bellagio and the walkway and tram to Monte Carlo where we enjoyed the blackjack atmosphere. Also as other have mentioned the beds and linens are amazingly comfortable. Overall I think they are working on the bugs and are making progress and I enjoyed the stay...I'm not sure if I would return here or stay at other properties at similar prices. I guess it depends on the rate you get. We got the room for about $170/Nght on the weekend and less during the week.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!!!”
Reviews.Author: SVVS
Reviews.Content: Very large, relaxing, nice and clean hotel with high techno; not that hard to use, even my 4 years old girl know how to play with it. It did need to walk a bit before you hit the Strip, but very well located... connected to: Bellagio and Monte-Carlo hotel. But i will say the room is a bit dark, it is hard to pack things up on our last night. Definitely i will come again, without any hesitation!!!

Reviews.Title: “5 Star needs to be lowered to 1 star”
Reviews.Author: joeybowtie
Reviews.Content: The worst "5 star" ever. I have stayed in almost every hotel in Vegas and numerous 5 or 4 stars around the world. I was excited to stay at the new Aria. NEVER again. I work from the room on the Internet. I had to fly to Vegas for a meeting but I can still work from my room. I was allowed to check in at 10am..nice. Let me tell you the good things about this hotel...NONE...there are none. There was no Internet access for 2 days. No explanation except soon. Staff did not know what was going on. When I would call down to check updates....no matter who answered they did not know it was down. Kept telling me to log in...The way the hotels are laid out in City Center you can't use your cell phone to hold a conversation. Many people I talked to said the same thing with different carriers. I could live with the Internet problem as I could teather my cell to my computer. No cell reception or very poor. They isolate you so you can't get across the street (since I had time on my hands) They want to hold you hostage to the $25 2 egg breakfast. The Four Seasons breakfast is not that much. Trust me THAT is no Four Seasons. Lets see..the ice machine was not working. The rooms have this hi tech system. You walk in and the lights come on and the drapes open automatically. They also close for no reason leaving you in pitch black darkness. The lights above my bed kept flickering. The shower, tho very beautiful would not get past warm. The Internet came back up at 8 pm and had to work until 2 am to catch up. It would go down almost every hour and have to log in again. Long walk to return a call too. This is picky but nobody knew where the shoe shine stand was. (always get shoes shined before meeting) One guy hidden in the mens room. Too bad if ladies need a shine I guess. This is the scary part. The very next day I started working on my laptop and left everything out. Legal documents, hard copy and on screen. My prescriptions laid out to take after eating. The RED privacy light was on. I went downstairs to eat, gone 45 min. I come back up and now the RED privacy light is out. I open the door to find the bed had been made but things looked out of place. There was a bottle of hotel hand lotion on its side with no cap on the glass table by the window. I did not move it or use it from the bathroom. I go into the bathroom and there are 2 hand towels neatly folded on each sink. One was filthy. The other small bottles were all knocked over too. Someone had been in my room. Outside by the next room is a maid and the supervisor with a clipboard. I asked why they were in my room and WHO was in my room. They do not know etc. Someone came into the room with the maid or after the maid and moved things around leaving an open bottle of lotion next to the window. I called the manager and explained to him..I got an I am sorry sir....that is it. Ok I got a really cheap deal on this but still it is a security issue and he was of no help. Knock on door and it is the housekeeping supervisor I showed her the state of the room. Why is this here? Why would they replace with dirty towels? I told her I was checking out. When I checked out the bill had a $20 Internet cable that they told me to try to see if the wired Internet worked. It was on the desk when I left. They charged me for Internet access that they did not have and most of all...there were 2 local phone calls made from my room. Proof that someone else was in that room. I checked out and moved to another hotel. Last thing...you check out dragging your bags on wheels to get a cab and are told to walk all the way around the circle drive to the cab stand...I mean like 2 city blocks. I asked the guy at the cab stand and he started ragging on this place too...I told them this was nuts. Nuts is an understatement. Dangerous, unsafe and no...there was no refund for the next 3 nights stay. Lesson learned..do not stay here at least not until they change things. I know I will never go back so it doe not matter.

Reviews.Title: “Nice & new, but still some wrinkles to work out”
Reviews.Author: oolivia
Reviews.Content: We spent the President's Day/Valentine's Day long weekend at the Aria resort where we also celebrated my husband's birthday with another couple. We were simultaneously impressed and disappointed, and overall felt that, given the degree of competition amongst fabulous hotels in LV these days, we probably will not return here for another stay. Here is a summary of our experience: Pros: Gorgeous architecture and good proximity to things, which will be even better when the rest of the City Center opens up. Our room was quiet and the bed was very soft and comfy. Cool automation in the room for lighting, curtains, tv/music, housekeeping, etc. Cons: Casino air ventilation not as good as some of the other resorts (obvious cigarette smoke smell). Sketchy service at restaurants and lounges (specifically, American Fish and View Bar). Mediocre food at higher-than-mediocre prices (specifically, American Fish and the hotel Cafe Vettro). Irritating spa experience which was anything but relaxing, let me elaborate: groups of people were herded together by the hostess into the "holding pen" for the spa treatments, wet towels lay strewn all over the floors and the showers were dirty (used bandages on the shower floor, shaving creme not wiped off the shelves, etc.), had to wait for them to find my size of slippers (and ask again when they forgot), employees seemed flustered and stressed (not exactly the mood you are seeking when visiting a spa). The excuse that I was given was that it was a particularly busy weekend due to Valentine's Day, yet when my husband visited the facilities two days later he also found wet towels strewn all over the place and the employees just standing around chatting and watching tv instead of tidying up. Also, it seems reasonable that a spa could anticipate more visitors on a Valentine's Day long weekend and either increase staffing or limit spa bookings so that the experience can be more enjoyable. It was clearly understaffed on the day that I visited the spa, but given my husband's observations on the less busy days, that's not the only problem with that place. I walked away from the experience with a bad taste, wishing I had just bypassed the spa altogether. Unfortunately, the more memorable times of our weekend were spent outside the Aria resort, so we're not likely to return anytime soon. But it is worth visiting to admire the beautiful architecture!

Reviews.Title: “The new Aria in Vegas - All the bells and whistles...but......”
Reviews.Author: dhyland
Reviews.Content: Location - Pros - Just off the strip across from PH. Cons - the walk between the strip and the hotel entrance and then to the guest elevators is not short. Casino - Pros - none. Cons - BORING! The dealers all acted as if they were dead or not interested to be there. Skip the casino. Room - Pros - State of the art. Loved the all room remote and auto window/tv on. Cons - Bathroom and power outlets. The bathroom shower is artsy and not functional. Not much water. Like being in a slight rain shower. Outlets - Hidden. Look behind the tissues in the bathroom and made into the end fo the desk in the room. Overall - Nice hotel but not worth the walk - unless you really like to walk. We got a good deal - so price was not an issue (169/night). I would have been just as happy at Venetian or similar. ***** DO NOT ship anything to the hotel ahead of arrival. You get the pleasure of paying $10/item to get them back.... anything for a buck, heh?

Reviews.Title: “Aria Hotel: You Won't Be Singing Their Praises!”
Reviews.Author: samsen
Reviews.Content: We had planned a romantic Valentine's stay and had high expectations. What we encountered was a glass palace, with no heart - the "Aria Hotel staff INDIFFERENCE." The public areas and rooms are dimly lit. You need a PhD to operate high tech TV, lights, curtains in each room...many guests complaining to reception. What happened to the basic light switch? I am handicapped and needed a wheelchair. The Aria Hotel were completely insensitive to my needs and from Bell Desk to Valet I was inconvenienced in every way. When confronting managers, no apology was given! With one of the highest unemployment rates of any state, you would think they could find staff that cared! Expect to be charged a fee everywhere: Spa $30 and Concierge $30. We paid $30 for someone to make a phone call - RIDICULOUS! Do not recommend - 3 stars, not 5!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent!!!!”
Reviews.Author: zoomnik
Reviews.Content: Would definetely stay there again. Very well located. Extra clean. Spacious rooms. Everything is electronic in the hotel. Many restaurants. Connected to: Bellagio and Monte-Carlo. Very large hotel. Close to airport, about 15$ each way. You could stay at the ARIA, without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: “Way better than expected - Stayed Feb 9 - 12”
Reviews.Author: bondman1000
Reviews.Content: Read the reviews for the last 6 weeks and was honestly worried. We had a great time, and the hotel exceeded our expectations by far with only one minor glitch. We've stayed at Bellagio, Encore, and The Hotel on previous trips, and would put Aria on par with these resorts. Housekeeping was the only problem. Had to call every day to have the room cleaned, however, upon checkout I informed the clerk, and they rebated us $56 which I thought was the right thing to do. First off, check-in was very easy, however there were very few people in line. The whole process took 10 minutes, and we were given our choice of room (high floor, mountain view), and did not have to wait for it to be ready. I could see how check-in could be spicy if it was busy, given the lack of a central line... Think grocery store or Costco (am I in the quickest line? paranoia) Lobby and all the common areas were awesome. The hotel is beautiful (especially if you like an updated contemporary look - think W Hotels). I think it is very well laid out, and it was quite easy to get around. The casino was darker and brown with some natural lighting (a first in Vegas!!), but we enjoyed the different look.
