( which is pretty silly if you ask me) The rooms are very nice. As you have heard many times before, the beds are FANTASTIC. they got that right. But the rooms are smaller than I would expect for any place claiming to be 5 stars. I dont think they will ever get a AAA 5 diamond award. I would put this at a solid 4 stars 4 diamond place. better than most but not as nice as others. The remote control is ( despite what others have said) very easy to understand and operate. If you want to watch TV touch "watch TV" if you wnat to open or close curtains touch "curtains" ETC... The technology is cool and reasonably easy to use. Motorized curtains are cool but they do not make or break the room. Yes water pressure is low... but this is the law in vegas now. You dont get high pressure anywhere any more. and this is a "Green" Hotel so expect conservation all over the place. The layout of the shower/tub is a little odd. But they are very nice and the tub is big. Location is great. It's not that bad of a walk to the street. its right between Bellagio and Monte Carlo. We only ate at Cafe Vitro ( the standard cafe) for breakfast. it was good but way overpriced. Breakfast for 2 with coffee came to 40.00. It's worse than Bellagio prices. And yes the drinks at any of the bars are very expensive. count on at least 15.00 for standard mixed drinks. Alot more for premuim drinks. We did not eat anywhere else at this hotel. The casino is dark as all have said. It's a OK casino as casino's go. High limits on weekends. Dealers were for the most part very nice. The Poker Room is VERY NICE. if you are a poker player, this is a great place to play. the seats are super comfortable. Games are mostly 1-3 and 2-5 NL. with some 3-6 limit and an advertised 20-40 HORSE game on Wednesday nights. They have a GREAT tournament every day at 1:00PM 8000 in chips 30min rounds . buy in is 120.00. I loved it... mostly because I won the one I was in. We took in one of the preview performances of "Viva Elvis" it is not your regular Crique show. There is alot of dancing and singing. Not alot of the stunniong acrobatics I am accustomed too with Cirque. The music was great and the energy was high. It does still need work but I think once it opens for real it will be prety good. Just go to enjoy the Elvis and not the Cirque. Checkout was fast and easy. No complaints there. Overall you should expect a very nice hotel in a very nice loaction. Yes I would stay here again but I would not pay full price. I got a great rate for this stay. If I was asked to pay the same price as bellagio, Wynn, Palazzo or Venitian I would choose one of the others. As long as its a decent deal I would stay here again in a minute. I think star ratings are very suspect and subjective. so 5 stars... 4 stars... we all have our standards. I normally stay at 4 and 5 star hotels. I have stayed at Wynn, Bellagio and Palazzo. This place is very different from those and very nice in its own way. I will not say its better or worse. Those who gave this place realy bad reviews I am sure had a very frustrating experience. I dont think those reviews are indicative of what this hotel is like now. They have fixed alot of issues and are working to fix the rest. They are trying, and in time this will be a world class hotel. I guess my only complaints would be to bring the food and drink pricing in line with the rest of vegas. Your high prices will just push people away. If you got a good rate, take it and stay here. you will not be sorry. I am happy to answer any questions I have not addressed here. Drop me a line.

Reviews.Title: “Defintely not a 5 Star hotel”
Reviews.Author: JtripMn
Reviews.Content: Booked thru Expedia booked King room, non-smoking. Aria hotel web site said >4000 rooms but when we checked in on a Sunday night we were told they were booked and only room left was on 6th floor. The room was beautiful but it was very disappointing that the hotel room was not cleaned well, dirty kleenex from previous guest on the floor, not vacuumed well, no soap in bathroom. The hotel staff was slow. apathetic, and lacked attention to detail - very poor customer service. Requested that Front Desk follow up on multiple issues with Hotel Manager- checking into room took > 1.5 hours and room was not satisfactory, definitely NOT a 5 star hotel, definitely NOT 5 star customer service.

Reviews.Title: “Big and Beautiful, but Service and Price were Poor”
Reviews.Author: BRoerig
Reviews.Content: We stayed for two night on Jan 15-16 for reasonable prices, but were disappointed for a few reasons: 1) Our room was three from the end of the hall, and the walk was very long to the elevator. They should have built it with two banks so the walk isn't so far; 2) We ate at Skybox To Go (Chicken Tenders, Wings, Fries and 2 bottles of water) for $40, and were told to come back in 20 minutes. It took 59 minutes to get our meal (based on our receipt time stamp) and despite twice asking about our meal, we were told it was coming. People who arrived 30 minutes after we came (I checked the time stamp on their receipt) and ordered similar food received theirs but ours was lost in the system (they prepare and bag the food in the back where you can't see them). The food was good, but an hour for finger food? No thanks! I asked for a supervisor but no one was available. 3) Ate at one of the fancy sit-down restaurants that server "tapas" (appetizers) and we had fresh calamari, a 5 oz or so piece of meat and one other tapas, plus two drinks (vodkas) for $80. Overpriced. 4) The view from the room looking at the strip actually looks at the other City Center skyscrapers and the parking circle/wide road leading up to the Aria and one small fountain. And it's set WAYYY back from the Strip, so it's a very boring view. 5) You have to walk thru the shower to get to the tub, which is nothing special and there is no view (except of the bathroom). Now the positive: 1) It's new. 2) You can get tickets (we got our to "O") at the Elvis theatre desk, so we didn't have to walk forever to get to the tram (free) that takes you to Bellagio or Monte Carlo. Based on other issues (hard to call the front desk, could not get the valet desk to pick up the phone in a reasonable amount of time), it appears they are cutting staff to pay for that huge bill to build it. The maids were very nice and thorough...but they don't have enough people to serve their guests. This was MKL weekend, so they knew they would be busy. Didn't seem to be a full house, but it wasn't empty either. After two days, we moved to Bellagio (pre-planned) and that was a very welcoming place to go (about my 15th visit there). Until they fix the staffing issue, I would not recommend Aria at this time.

Reviews.Title: “Can't believe the negative reviews”
Reviews.Author: macgyver99
Reviews.Content: My wife and I are from Saskatchewan, Canada and booked the Aria online. After reading alot of negative reviews we almost changed our reservation to another hotel at the last moment, but we are so happy we didn't! The hotel, complex, casino, architecture is amazing. Really beautifully designed, very contemporary. We arrived, very friendly check-in took maybe 5 minutes, easy to get to the elevators thru the casino, and we booked a corner suite at the very end of the hotel and it was maybe a 1 minute walk from the elevator, not 10 minutes like some have said. The room was great, loved the computerized system for the lights, temperature, curtains. Awesome. Now my parents who are 70 might have some trouble figuring it out, but we never had any issues. Our suite had the coolest bathroom, heated toilet seat, huge shower, tv jet tub, really nice. Beds were super comfy. We gambled some the first night and were promptly asked if we wanted drinks by the waitress, she came around often, very friendly. The casino lights are dim, but not a cave like some complaints. I loved the mood and atmosphere it created. Ate dinner at the Italian restaurant (can't remember the name)...very good, also had breakfast at the cafe which was a dissapointment, we still prefer the Paris restaurant. But the architecture of everything was amazing. Everyone was very friendly, great service and we would definently come back and miss it already!

Reviews.Title: “Few Kinks to work out but is still a Great place to stay!”
Reviews.Author: trav69
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 3 nights from Jan 15th - 18th. This was my 15th time to Vegas so I have stayed pretty much everywhere. Wanted to try something new and different and it is new and different in a great way! I had read many negative reviews here for weeks before leaving and was a little concerned. For me check in was a breeze, maybe 2 people in front of me, I asked for a mountain view and to be on a high floor not far from the elevator and got it all. The room is very modern and nice. The beds are the most comfortable I have ever been on and I personally own a $3k mattress at home. The high tech controls for the lights etc.. take a few minutes to get used to but are very cool. We did have a problem with the curtains fully closing and this did for some reason take 12 hours to fix. We could have changed rooms to avoid the wait but did not and was compensated $50 off our bill at check out for the problem. Our room was cleaned every day with fresh towels and bath products and had a turn down service in the evening. I had no problem with outlets for my cell phone and for the iron. We were on the 25th floor and did not hear any noise outside, it was very quiet and peaceful to sleep. We did not eat at any of the restaurants in the hotel as I had reservations each night at some of my favorite spots from past trips to Vegas. The sports book is awsome with some of the clearest and largest plasma screens I have ever seen. The staff were so friendly, they must be trained to stop and say hello every time someone walks by them. Aria is at the back of the City Center but still and excellent location that you can walk to Bellagio or Planet Hollywood in an easy 10min. They are a 4000 room hotel and have only been open a month, so give them some time to work out the kinks, I would recommend staying here if you like a 5 star hotel at a great rate. I will be back!

Reviews.Title: “Almost all great - still some kinks to work out”
Reviews.Author: WTonkin
Reviews.Content: I was a little apprehensive about Aria because of some of the negative reviews and issues I've seen brought up here, but I was determined to stick it out. Turns out I made the right call. I'll bullet point some if the issues that have come up and my responses. 1. In room technology - was awesome. Moving from one TV channel to another was a tad slower than normal, but the ability to control lighting, drapes, wake up/sleep timer etc, all through either the TV or the night stand top device was cool - didn't try to bring any of my media stuff in through the TV - but the option to is cool. Self Parking- the self parking is a bit aggravating as they have a lot of extra space between parking spots at least on the first few levels. Seems like a lot of wasted space to me. Valet Parking - highly recommended for convenience. I do recommend you give them a call 10-15 before you need your vehicle though. They have a LOT of people staying there are valet parking - plan and call ahead and you will avoid frustration. Staff - everyone I worked with was really helpful - no problem with unmotivated staff, etc. Restaurants - only ate at Sage - it was lights out. Had the Sweetbreads for an appy and Roasted Loin of Iberico Pork - was phenomenal - service was excellent as well and the chef sent an amuse-bouche to start the meal and a tasty sipping chocolate shot to cap the meal that were awesome. If offered tap water or bottled - I always take tap - trying to be environmentally responsible - the tap water was terrible though - had to ask for replacement bottled water The Bacon Baguette was really tasty as well. Only real issue I had was the morning of checkout. Had an issue with the toilet clogging/failing to flush right before I checked out. Wasn't around to see what the response time from Maintenance was. Would I stay again? Definitely.

Reviews.Title: “Smoke and mirrors”
Reviews.Author: Inara11
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I were very excited to be staying at the Aria for our Vegas trip. We took a shuttle from the airport as we had heard cabs were expensive and that brought us to this underground "hide the shuttles" area under the hotel that smelled of rotting fish. We had to take 2 or 3 escalators up to the actual hotel. Once we got there, it was really nicely decorated and they had some vanilla sent pumping through the circulation system which was nice, I guess. We then had to wait THIRTY MINUTES to check in. It was chaos. There was no organization except some guy standing with a clipboard trying to look important. They also had a terrible time trying to explain that they will hold $130 of your money on your credit card a night in case you use anything in your room. When asked why they couldn't just charge us for what we used instead of holding our money, they said their way was easier. Ridiculous. The clerk was unhelpful and really rude when I told her how she was saying "charge you $130" when she meant "hold $130" didn't mean the same thing. Anyway, our room was very nice and the tech was okay. We found that most of the programmable things in the room didn't work most of the time. Also the windows were DISGUSTING. There was dust and paint on the inside and out. You would think they would have cleaned the windows after construction was complete but it doesn't look that way at all. Overall, we found the hotel very pretentious and that it was trying too hard.

Reviews.Title: “Very pleasant - poor reviews undeserved”
Reviews.Author: bostonboy77
Reviews.Content: Disclaimer: I am a pretty regular guy, but I like nicer, luxury sorts of accommodations more than the regular guy. That said, I am not someone who comes to Vegas quarterly, like a lot of people who write these reviews. Having stayed at the Bellagio in the past, I was lured by a great rate at Aria and wanted to try something different. I have been pleased. The rooms are well appointed, and I agree with many postings that the beds are fantastic. This is not a themey sort of joint like every other hotel, and the rooms reflect a modern (if marginally bland) simplicity. I think the bathroom was also great; spacious with a great layout (the shower and soaking tub are enclosed together, separate from the vanity, and then the toliet is also in a third separate enclosure). Aria is totally billed-as-advertised re: the technology thing. You can control the whole room from the bathroom light to the curtains from the bedside table. Not really my thing but I knew what to expect. Restaurants are good and at appropriate price point. We were there for 3 nights, so we didn't have a chance to try that many places, but what we ate was good. Not the best-meal-of-my-life good, but good. A few random things that were annoying: Very poor AT&T reception, iPhone users beware. Also, a paucity of electrical outlets in the room, and those available were poorly placed, like right next to the door of the room. Also, the gym is in the Spa, and requires a $30 *daily* admission fee, which is a little steep for some weights and a treadmill. IF YOU LIKE THE BELLAGIO OR VENETIAN because the whole opulent theme thing appeals to you (and I think the Bellagio is great), know that Aria is not like that, but still very nice. You will not be disappointed. Maybe at the outset, this place was befallen by quirky service and unexpected engineering problems. I mean, it is a 4000 bed hotel. During our stay, we did not experience anything like this. Th

Reviews.Title: “It Just Doesn't Work... And They Just Don't Care”
Reviews.Author: mcc222
Reviews.Content: Our experience at Aria was an epic failure. The "check in line" was a mob of people pushing their way to the front, made worse by employees taking upwards of 45 minutes to check in each room! After 4 weeks of being open, the check-in desk employees were still sneaking under the desk to consult their handbooks. The high-tech room key system didn't work for us, as 4 different sets of keys failed to magnetize, leaving us sitting in the hall outside of our room as we waited 45 minutes for someone to come up and rescue us. It might have been quicker to stand in the check-in line again, given that even the replacement keys they sent up for us didn't work, as well. We were traveling with colleagues who had to change rooms multiple times, thanks to overwhelming odors, dirty rooms, double bookings, and broken a/c. One fellow traveler had so many room problems (including being given the key to a room that ALREADY HAD GUESTS IN IT!) that the Aria management finally gave up and moved him over to a room at the Bellagio. Other travelers noted dirty bathrooms, dirty sheets and pillows, and toiletries left over from previous guests. We were told by sources in the city (cab drivers, other hotel employees) that the average training for hotel employees is 4 weeks, and to save money Aria employees were only trained for 1.5 weeks. That would explain the concierge who couldn't tell us where a restaurant WITHIN THE HOTEL was located. We asked for a map, located it on the Promenade level one floor up, and asked "Is there a quick way up to the 2nd floor? An escalator, perhaps?" She also didn't know, and said she had no idea how to get to the 2nd floor. We gave up and went back to the guest room elevators. The one bright spot was our dinner at Sage. Delicious, luxurious, a great experience. Stay somewhere else but come to Sage for dinner. I would absolutely not go back to Aria or recommend it. Any new hotel will have some kinks to work out, but we didn't find the hotel staff or management nearly solicitous enough about the overwhelming, obnoxious, visit-ruining problems. With more than a dozen problems and half a dozen 30 minute waits for things, we only received one "I apologize."

Reviews.Title: “Redefines Vegas”
Reviews.Author: TheCats
Reviews.Content: Loved the entire City Center complex and when it's done it will redefine Vegas and move it to the modern age as Bellagio did in it's time. Soaring spaces, wonderful art work, fantastic design and texture to everything - modern and clean looking - like the 21st century rather than trying to be something your not like Wynn, or Bellagio or many of the other casino hotels, even though I still love some of those places as well. At night - it is even more spectacular. We ate at Sage....awesome food, service, decor....and we go to Vegas a lot - so have many to compare it to. If you want to spend the money - stay here - it's very nice.

Reviews.Title: “I had a great stay!”
Reviews.Author: liglig1
Reviews.Content: I was very nervous about spending my hard earned money at this hotel after reading the reviews. However, it was money well spent. The Aria is beautiful and not too minimalist. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is not far from the strip at all - it is literally between the Bellagio and Monte Carlo. It is dimly lit compared to other hotels/casinos but that did not bother me. The room was great and I found the technology to be user-friendly. Sportsbook was awesome. Breakfast at The Buffet was well worth $14.99. I have seen numerous Cirque du Soleil shows and Viva Elvis is one of the best, if not THE best.

Reviews.Title: “The future is here - whether you like it or not!”
Reviews.Author: everyshadeofblue
Reviews.Content: Aria and the entire City Center complex is stunning and a remarkable achievement. The last thing Las Vegas needed was another high end hotel (3 of them!) but such is life in a new economic reality. Got a killer deal on a room at Aria through MGM Mirage Player's club and wanted to check it out. This hotel breaks new ground with technology and feels very futuristic...almost like something from the Jetsons. Everything is controlled through a main bedside touch screen or through the very nice flat screen TV. There are manual overrides for just about everything but they can get you into trouble. I found the technology to be a bit annoying and by hitting certain buttons you turn off everything in the room and it takes a while to get it back on. Don't hit the "goodnight" button next to the bed or you'll turn off everything and I hit something on the control screen more than once that had the same effect. Very annoying but still cool "gee-whiz" technology. I can't imagine an elderly person liking this! I'm young and was annoyed. The room itself is nice with very comfortable beds. Rooms are smaller than I would have imagined but perfectly fine and have a cozy feel to them. In my opinion, the bathroom is the sorest spot. I did not like it at all. First, it echoes like you are in a symphony hall. It gets really annoying! The sink space is also limited and the water pressure for the sinks is only so-so. There's no bathroom exhaust fan either. The shower/tub design was odd to me and I did not like it. I prefer a separate shower and tub. I kept getting the tub wet by taking a shower. Showerhead is marginal...nothing special. With such a massive project, there are things that were overlooked and need to be addressed. For example, the bathroom door in the room slides and has a latch for locking, however, nobody ever drilled a hole for the latch so there was no way to lock the door. Also, the sliding door felt flimsy like it could fall off at any moment. A creepy complaint were the lights over the bed...they would make noises...almost like a popping sound. It was unnerving at times. I don't know what caused it... maybe the room was haunted? The casino at Aria caters to higher rollers and is a little dull. Restaurants are pricey but I found good value and delicious food at Skybox. Bar Moderno is also fantastic and has a great Purple Haze beer and is in a prime location for people watching. Another strange aspect of Aria is the self-parking garage. For some odd reason they have huge distances between parking spots and it is very deceptive. People are trying to park in "non-existant" spots and I could feel the frustration. It's almost too bizarre to explain.... what were they thinking??????? Overall, I enjoyed my stay at Aria but it is not my favorite hotel on the strip. I much prefer THE Hotel at Mandalay Bay. The ambiance, etc. is much better at MB. Once they get some of the kinks worked out, Aria will be a model of a "green" hotel with technology of the future. Definitely check it out but I don't think it sets any new standards.

Reviews.Title: “Modern Luxury but still working out some kinks”
Reviews.Author: AAtravelstheworld
Reviews.Content: I checked in to Aria on a Saturday afternoon. The check-in desks where not overly crowded but it took over 20 minutes before an available receptionist could help us. We reserved one of their standard rooms but I was pleasantly surprised when we walked in. The room was a nice size, the decor was very modern and chic and the bathroom was a good size with excellent lighting. This hotel has been open for less than a month and while it has everything a top-notch Vegas hotel should have, they haven't worked out some of the small details. The floor-to-ceiling windows were filthy and really impacted your view of the skyline in day light (you would think a hotel covered in so much glass would clean the glass). My other complaint with cleanliness was that the room was very, very dusty. The carpet near the a/c vent was actually stained/discolored from the dust that was blowing out on it. The tops of the furniture are covered in glass, which was cleaned, but you could see all the dust under the glass on top of the furniture - it just looked very tacky. Housekeeping was a let down too. The hotel boasts that it offers all rooms a "turn down service". This only happened two of the four nights I was there. The housekeeping crew also did not restock the toiletries every day, even when the product was empty and in the trash can. Finally, one of the robes (left hanging in the bathroom) was taken, perhaps to be cleaned or something but a replacement never showed up. The over all experience was good. The room is packed with cool technology features, the bed was very comfortable and all the staff we spoke to were courteous and pleasant. I'm glad I had a chance to check out the new property and for the price we paid (about $150/night including taxes/fees), I would stay there again with hopes that the above mentioned issues would be sorted out in time.

Reviews.Title: “Stayed for 1 night only”
Reviews.Author: oreoiii
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent one night at the Aria Hotel. The hotel is beautiful and luxurious. They haven't worked out all the bugs yet as previous reviewers have stated such as the pool wouldn't be ready until 2 days later. The staff is very friendly and the hotel was very clean. Check-in was different. Hotels usually have 1 line for everyone but here there was a line for each check-in station like a grocery store. If you happen to stand beyond someone who has problems you may be waiting for awhile, but the hotel did have staff to redirect customers to other lines if one line was taking too long. We had a standard room, it was located at the end of the hallway. I suggest you find a room closer to the elevator as it was a pretty long walk. There are 4 hallways where your room can be so you have to pay attention whenever you get out of the elevator to make sure you don't go down the wrong way. The room was modern and had nice technological upgrades such as opening the curtins when you come in the door. The bed was comfortable and the sheets were soft. We didn't have many channels for the TV (I'm not sure how a previous reviewer stated there was over 600, unless he was in a better room). The only complaint I had about the room was the toilet paper was rough, the soap and shampoo either didn't have much in them or were previously used and there wasn't any simple amenitites such as plastic bags for laundry or pen and paper. I don't think they worked out all the kinks in valet parking as one time it was so crowded that we waited about 10 minutes in line to give our ticket and we were the 3rd people in line. They said it would take about 20 minutes once we gave the ticket to get our car, but it only took 5 minutes. The shopping center called Crystal had only a few stores open. It is meant to be a high end shopping center. There are these water tubes that you can create funnels in the tubes by spinning your and on the tube. It was very nice. One odd thing was that the coffee shop there was not open at 8:00 am. We had breakfast at the buffet. They had an upgraded buffet such as having shrimp in your omelet or roasted meat. I suggest you go to the buffet instead of the cafe there as it cost are pretty similar, you may save a buck going to the cafe. Overall, we enjoyed ourselves and would recommend this place to visitors.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Rooms - Average Food - Poor Club Service- Almost No AT&T Phone Service”
Reviews.Author: dfwbrighterorange
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the new Aria hotel in City Center over the 2010 MLK weekend. The Beginning: First impression is good. Check-in lines were not too long, about 3 parties deep at each station, All available check-in spots were staffed. Room configuration was as promised. The Room: The room was beautiful. Towels and bedding were first class. Bathroom was exceptionally well designed. Blackout curtains were motorized and worked great. The architecture is alot more likely to stand the test of time, compared to most Las Vegas properties. The Food: The two restaurants we visited were average. Food was not a very godd value, but about what you would expect in Vegas. The Bad: The Concierge desk was severely understaffed. Long lines in the lobby and poor service over the phone. We also had a botched reservation and poor experience at HAZE, their dance club. Had reserved a table with bottle service over the internet. When we got to the club, they did not have our reservation and the only table they had left was a 3 bottle minimum, at $500 per bottle, in a poor location. Well we only had 5 people in our party , so we could not have finished 3 bottles, at any price. Last downside was At&T phone service.....signal was almost nonexistent. Pitiful for a $1 billion plus property. Players Club was also drastically understaffed, line was 20 minutes long. Property has several smaller bars scattered throughout. The DEUCE was our favorite. Fun people and great service at the DEUCE. Although, as you would expect for Casino drinks, the drinks were weak. The drinks you pay full price for should not be weak. Overall a great property that will "hit its stride" once the service level kinks get worked out and they make the decision to not water down the drinks that are purchased.

Reviews.Title: “Not ready yet”
Reviews.Author: rnntraveler
Reviews.Content: This hotel put form over function in a few ways. The cell service in this hotel is horrible. Don't expect to keep in contact with your party while inside this hotel. There are spots that work but as soon as you turn your head, service drops. I'm not a smoker, but after all it's a casino, and there are plenty of them (someone I was traveling with is). There are barely any ashtrays to be found and was shocked to see none near the elevators. Did they want a fire in their garbage can? Most sportsbooks in a casino are open so many people can fit. This sports book is a small closed room and occupancy is limited. In the rooms, the main control remote is neat but is near useless. The rooms aren't anything special. The shower had an odd design where the glass on the door would steam up, which was fine, but as soon as the door was opened (outward) all the condensation would spill onto the floor. All things considered the hotel is nice. I'm not really sure what class of people they are looking for. The stores and restaurants and bars/clubs aim at the high end but it's certainly not up to par with Bellagio or Venetian. I'd compare it more to Mandalay Bay.

Reviews.Title: “OMG! This place is fabulous.”
Reviews.Author: Taniquan
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the new Aria Hotel for three days over the Christmas holiday and was duly impressed. First as to the hotel, the rooms are true state of the art 5 star rooms. The beds, bedding, large screen TV’s, motorized curtains, are all there and controlled by a bed side control panel. I have never seen anything like this in any hotel or anywhere. There were beautiful toiletries and a LARGE tub and shower. The television had about 600 television channels which made it impossible to flip through all the channels in one sitting. I cannot criticize anything in my room. The hotel is a casino so the lobby is all gambling and crowds. And the day after Christmas there were CROWDS. Every restaurant, coffee area, and other places serving food were crowded with LONG lines to get into them. And they did not provide any special shorter line for hotel residents. On the downside, I tried to use the TV based Folio Review and Checkout feature allowing me to review my bill on the TV and then checkout. The bill review feature worked but when I tried to checkout a note popped up “Unable to process checkout-Contact the front desk.” So I called the front desk and was put on automatic hold for (I timed it) four minutes and still no one answered. I will give the hotel a pass on this considering it just opened up and give them time to get everything in order. The hotel is beautiful and so is City Center. Crystals is the name of the attached shopping area. It is large, contemporary, artistic and tasteful. The down side of it is that there are not that many shops and restaurants in it. As for a shopping/eating area it does not hold a candle to the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace. But Crystals has only been opened for less than a month so perhaps more will come in the future. I ate at the Beso steak house at the City Center owned by Eva Longoria Parker. My bill for food was $122. I ordered a baked potato which was $8 and then for sour crème and bacon bits they charge $6 more. So that was a total of $14 for a baked potato!! The food, service and atmosphere were great but obviously priced on the high side. If you can afford it and like steak, give it a try.

Reviews.Title: “quality hotel, very hard to fault it. brilliant staff from managers to room maids”
Reviews.Author: neelio
Reviews.Content: Myself and nine friends checked into the hotel on a busy friday evening after arriving 2 days late from the uk due to snow. check in did take a fair time but due to it being a friday and us being late it was only to be expected. The rooms are amazing with a master control panel that does everything from turn on the television to open/close the curtains. The beds i can only describe as laying onto a giant marshmallow, comfortable is an understatement , six pillows as well ! The bathrooms have walk in showers, with room for four people, a sunken tub and his / her basins. The buffett breakfast is a must with a wonderfull array of food, you name it and they have it, all the staff i spoke to were polite and nothing was too much trouble. My only critisism of the whole complex was that the gaming area was slightly dimly lit, but this is really nit picking.I would recomend this hotel to anyone !

Reviews.Title: “Security”
Reviews.Author: bigman1233
Reviews.Content: After spending about 2 hours in the casino I returned to my room, upon doing so I found my room open. Upon checking I found out nothing was misting thank god, but I did notice that every room on my floor was unlooked. After securing my room I went down stairs to report finding my room and also the other rooms open to the front desk staff and secuirty. Please NOTE that all I got was sorry sir, no reason why. So if you do stay watch want you leave in your room.

Reviews.Title: “Much good ruined by critical issues”
Reviews.Author: ridgeley
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Aria for three nights, Sun-Wed., on a Stay 3/Pay for 2 Night special. Check in was fine, the room was neat and clean upon arrival. I was right across from the construction site, but the windows were sufficiently sound proof, that wasn't a problem. I like watching construction, so the view was fine. Everything in the room is so digital, though, I was opening and closing the drapes when I was trying to set the clock alarm. Some light switches were well labeled and obvious, others not. Interestingly, all the bulbs in the well lit room were incandescent, not florescent, and housekeeping left them on whenever they left. There was also no radio in the room, just the TV, and with spotty AT&T cell service, my iPhone radio apps wouldn't stay connected. (There is wifi, for pay, though I don't know how much.) My first full day I returned to the room at 2:15p and it hadn't been made up yet. It took two phone calls to housekeeping to get someone there, and then it was a very young man laughing and goofing around with a friend. Service people overall were very young and in greater need of managing. Everyone was very friendly. The bed was s-o-f-t, so if you like that, this is your place. I would have liked at least a slightly firmer mattress. Sheets were very nice, and I loved the towels. The final unacceptable aspect of the Aria was the not very hot shower. The hot water in the sink was plenty hot, but in the shower, it wasn't very hot, and the spray (the shower head couldn't be adjusted) was the quite cool. There's a lot of competition on the Strip now, especially in this down economy, so given time, most of these problems should be remedied.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel, not well managed just yet.”
Reviews.Author: TommyJames
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Aria during the Consumer Electronics Show. For starters they didn't have enough people checking guests in and out, however the quality of people seems above average. My largest single complaint is the shower water pressure is low. They use these pulsing heads to mask how low it is and it's a bit annoying. Dogs pee harder. The rooms are nicely appointed but surfaces seem cheap in places. The rooms are very dark so drop anything small and black on the floor and good luck finding it. The touch screens in the room are nice but you have to spend a little time learning how to use them. There is a lack of outlets in standard rooms (you'd think they would figure out that guests want an outlet near the bed by now for laptops and other "appliances"). The food in the cafe was above average and overall, I'd give the place above average marks. It's still a giant impersonal hotel that doesn't care much about individual guests, but that's the MGM group overall. The Bellagio still has more warmth esthetically (however they couldn't care less about guests) and is more centrally located, but this is sill a nice hotel.

Reviews.Title: “"Amateur Hour" at Aria.....won"t go back"”
Reviews.Author: drkk10
Reviews.Content: I went there Dec 30 for 2 nights with friends for new years eve. I have stayed at most hotels in vegas and generally consider Wynn/Encore as the benchmarks thus far. Pros: Overall the hotel has potential to be good, decent decor, clean etc. Interior is nice but not overwhelming Mattresses I thought were phenomenal: super comfortable, among the best ever for me. Restaurants are good: Bar Masa and Jean Phillipe Bakery are great. Rooms are clean and generally decent. Great views of strip. Cons: Service is BAD! Booked 2 queens; given king bed with no pullout sleeper? Front desk is generally unhelpful. I made a huge ordeal about the rooms and eventually was comped the room charge but not before many phone calls. The front desk manager is almost useless. The place generally feels as if it opened way to early before training the staff...and it shows in almost every way. Front desk is confused, valet doesn't function well. Operator is basically non-existant; hold times on phone can exceed 30 minutes. Restaurants don't function well. We all agreed that it was basically amateur hour when we were there.

Reviews.Title: “Until the hotel addresses the staff and service don't bother”
Reviews.Author: JudgeSchmails
Reviews.Content: Upon check in be prepared to wait in line for upwards of 30 minutes. When you decide to question the inefficiency be prepared for excuses and rude retorts from staff. Once you make your way from check in to room be prepared for an upscale nicely appointed room with unneccesary technology. When climbing into bed be prepared for a very comfortable mattress and nice bed linens. Expect to sleep comfortably if you are a light sleep until about 2:30 in the morning when the workers from the condo complex in development next door launch off a series of airhorns to indicate "lunchtime." (Project is being constructed around the clock). After falling back asleep be prepared for more airhorns throughout he evening. If you are given a room facing this construction ask for a new room. The second night brought on the dissapoinment of room service. A very easy order took in excess of 1.5 hours to arrive and when it did the food was cold. Good luck trying to get ahold of anyone to complain, you'll be on hold for at least 20 minutes. If you need to visit concierge it'[s hit or miss but if you missyou'll be in line for at least 20 minutes. Overall if they ever figured out their service issue I would stay there. If you are big on greatcustomer service run for the hills to The Bellagio or Wynn.

Reviews.Title: “Very Pleasant”
Reviews.Author: HedgeEndTraveller56
Reviews.Content: I stayed at Aria in Jan 2010 for 5 nights. This is a brand new hotel and it was nice having everything new!! From the moment we left the limo our bags were loaded onto a trolly and waited near checkin for us. Checkin was busy but we were swiftly dealt with and on our way. Cases were taken to our rooms and arrived 5 mins after i did, no probs. Our rooms were on the 21st floor and we did have to walk through Casino to get to elevators but this is no issue. Very pleased with room. Had a king room overlooking the Vdara hotel. Room is fully electronic, which may put some off, but using the bedside panel you can control the tv, temperature, lighting, curtains, room service, all at the touch of a button. Bed is very comfy and the 42" LCD TV is a nice addition. Plenty of wardrobe and draw space. Bathroom is lovely with dual sinks, and a large shower big enough for 2 with a large oval bath next to it. Bathroom contains all toiletries needed. Two bath robes were also provided. Large minibar in the room, but be careful everything is monitored electronically using sensors, so if you just move something you'll be charged. Prices aren't cheap with bottled water setting you back $5, and the bag of crisps $8, but they are nice. Hotel boasts a superb fitness centre but is pricey at $30 per day, but this includes the SPA. Plenty of bars and restaurants, we only used the buffet for breakfast each day and for one evening meal, breakfast service and food was very good and the evening menu is also very good. Hotel staff were very friendly and the waitresses are all lovely, lots of oriental girls and very classy dressed. Room service was very efficient, and can be requested simply by pressing the service button in your room, or select privacy and they wont come near you!! Only issue i had was the safe didn't work and neither did my colleagues, he was given another room straight away, however i stuck with it, and left valuables and laptop in the room and didn't feel an issue with this, foolish maybe, but it wasn't a problem. Hotel Casino is good, all the required games, waitresses service very good, and table staff very helpful. Our flight was delayed so we extended our room with no issue, there was supposed to be a charge for this, but we werent charged which was a bonus. Location of the hotel is not the best, but is not really a problem. A free monorail runs to the Bellagio, and there is a covered walkway too which is actually quicker to use. Taxi rank is always available too, but either way you are going to be doing a lot of walking, it is Vegas!! All in all i enjoyed my time at the Aria and would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Not as impressed”
Reviews.Author: Dark_Choc-a-holic
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Aria with friends for CES 2010. I have stayed on most of the hotels on the strip over a number of years. I know I booked online for 3 people however they indicated it was only 2 and therefore could not provide me 2 queen beds but rather one King. Although they were nice about it they were firm on not giving me what I requested. It didn't help that my printed receipt did not indicate the number of people I stated. I was promised a roll away bed at no charge but never received. The rooms are a lovely chocolate color but extremely small. The fridge is packed so you cannot put your own stuff and we had no safe in the room. I managed to work my remote just fine, the technology in the rooms was definitely a cool treat. The restroom was nice but not enough towels and the robes not so soft. I never came across a rude employee nor did I have issues with my key or housekeeping. We ate at Union restaurant & lounge where my steak was cooked perfectly and wine chilled to perfection. All was a true delight, not to mention so was Kaleo the server ;). The bed was a little too soft for my back I needed a little more firmness. The spa was nicely decorated but I've honestly had better massages. Haze nightclub has a great layout and spacious dance floor but cover & drink costs were not worth it. I was on the VIP list & truly have never paid cover at a club in Vegas before but $20 wasn't bad I guess. The security apologized about the delay but the line seemed to take forever to get moving. I tried several different bartenders but all my drinks tasted like a baby shower punch and had no effect whatsoever! So I believe they dilute their bottles. The DJ was not all that great either, I preferred the mixes at Tao. I also spent several hours on the casino floor and I have NEVER lost so much money in such a short amount of time! Perhaps it was a bad day for me but honestly I did not see any real winners around me as well. Overall, my stay was okay and not having smoke burn my eyes while in my room was the best! Especially in Vegas. However I was disappointed with the value vs. cost of this hotel. Believe me I have no problem forking out the funds for great value...I just didn't find it here. Would I recommend this hotel ... Yes but at a later time when they have learned to provide the type of service and value customers are clearly paying them for from top to bottom. Maybe my expectations were set too high... ?

Reviews.Title: “Don't Bother with Aria”
Reviews.Author: Checkplease2000
Reviews.Content: An indifferent and confused staff made this trip forgettable. You play Hell getting anyone at the desk on the phone. The rooms are full of techno gizmos that are slow and gimmicky, like a big clock that sits on the bedtable that apparently does two things - tell time and close the curtains. Who knows what other purpose it might serve as there is no guide to any of it. The TV stopped working first night and despite repeated calls no one came to fix it. Check out was not as big a nightmare as check-in, as crowds mingle about the desk looking for the first open station as uniformed hotel personnel stand around, determined to be of no help at all. The men's spa is YMCA simple, with lots of things that don't work. The restaurants are understaffed and the food is OK but not terrific. You're better off at the Bellagio.

Reviews.Title: “STAY SOMEWHERE ELSE”
Reviews.Author: lifeon2whls
Reviews.Content: Rooms - On initial impression the rooms are very nice. However, you quickly realize too many corners were cut. During my 4 nights there, I could hear everyone's music, conversations, etc. It was so bad that I could easy make out what people were saying to each other. Step into the bathroom and it sounded like the people were talking right in your very own bedroom! The bed was comfy but it was oddly slanted and then I noticed the box springs were broken. Hotel is less than a month old and already falling apart. Also, no coffee maker, robe, telephone book...just the normal things you'd expect to find. I didnt even see a bible in the room. Restaurants/Bars - Unless you are on an Uber budget, don't plan to eat at the hotel. A sandwich and a cup of coffee at their little "fast food" bakery will run you about $15. The lunch buffet is about the best bargain but do not go for the weekend brunch. Its a lack luster version of their breakfast mixed with the previous days left overs for a premium price. Same goes for dinner...its simply lunch with a premium price tag. The hotel lounges/bars tend to have some nice eye candy but expect to pay club level prices for drinks. Beers ran between $6-9 depending on the lounge. Staff - Walk in to find the front desk in chaos. There isn't a line...everyone just kind of piles in and hopes at some point they are able to rush to an open station before someone else. The staff that's there is helpful for the most part but I could care less after waiting for 45 minutes in line. Overall, I spent most of my 4 nights in this hotel trying to figure out how to leave. If you're on a budget, stay far away. If you have plenty of money to blow...go somewhere else. This place seems to want to charge a lot of money because they can, not because the quality is there.

Reviews.Title: “Great beds but that's about it”
Reviews.Author: aztraverler04
Reviews.Content: We felt this hotel was lacking any personality and seemed very dark inside. We attemped to use the wireless internet and it never worked for three straight days. Now my computer has a long list of viruses...not sure what happened there. The overall quality of the rooms is great and we loved how comfortable the beds were. Bathrooms are impressive as well but could use a little more room in the sink area. Be patient with the bedside controls as we had a heck of a time trying to get the tv to work with any speed. There are better places to stay on the strip for the price Aria is charging.

Reviews.Title: “Aria is modern, elegant, with an artsy vibe.”
Reviews.Author: OklahomaGoSooners
Reviews.Content: I traveled to Aria with my daughters, age 23 and 18, and we had a fabulous time. Check-in took about 10 minutes. Our connecting rooms were ready for us. The elevators were some of the best, most efficient, I have even seen at a large hotel. The hotel does not have a typical themed Las Vegas look. If you are wanting floral carpet and ornate columns or lots of gimmicks, do not stay here. It decorated with a lot of neutral colors, and the casino is a little dark, but I think very pretty. The restaurants that we tried were all good, and the best one was Lemongrass (Thai.) The city tram that transports you to Bellagio was easy to use and worked well for us. The hotel was set back from the strip, so it creates a very beautiful entrance, but is a bit of a walk to the street. The location is great, in the very center of the strip. Crystals is the shopping mall on the property, and contains a few, very high end shops with more to come. There were three nice art galleries open on the property that we enjoyed browsing. The sports book is very large and comfy and has a nice casual restaurant next to it that also has tvs with sports. The staff was very friendly and the only wait we had was once at the concierge desk for about 10 to 15 minutes and a short wait at the coffee shop in the morning. The taxi line did get a bit long on the weekend. We were not greeted by bell staff when we arrived and were never offered help with our bags until we were leaving the hotel. We didn't need help or would have asked for it. The beds were fabulously comfortable and the bedside control system worked wonderfully for us. We loved the good night button next to the bed that shut everything off and closed drapes. I also loved the bedside temperature controls and the way the wake up system worked. Tvs were very nice. Bathroom was great but the pressure in the shower was a little weak. The room had two closets and very nice, large drawers. There was no easily accessible outlet by the bed. I had to charge my phone on the desk or in the bathroom. The in room safe in the bedside drawer was the best I had ever used. The worse thing about the hotel was that our at&t Iphones barely worked at all. The best things were the architecture, beauty, comfort of the room, the technology in the room, and the overall friendliness of the staff. Overall we loved the hotel and would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing but good things to say!”
Reviews.Author: brianf06
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a 4 night stay (Jan 6-10) at the Aria that was half business and half pleasure. Last year, I stayed at the Encore a few weeks after it opened, and loved it, so I figured I'd compare the two. I received an outstanding deal via Southwest that had an Aria room and flight included. As a result, I upgraded into the Corner Suite on the 29th flloor. The room and the view were fantastic! I know that a lot of people have had tech issues in the Standard rooms, so I cannot comment on those issues. The tech issues take a little bit of time to work out, but otherwise are very easy to navigate and are quite convenient. The room was quite large at 920 square feet and had fantastic floor to ceiling views in the bedroom, the little living room area and in the BATHROOM! The maid service was very good, and check-in was painless, as well. The amenities in this room were great (heated toilet seats), free internet, daily newspaper, etc... I didn't have any problems with keys, plumbing etc.. The casino and the hallways were quite dark, and lacked the "elegance" of the Encore. However, besides that it was great! The elevators were super fast and I NEVER waited more than 10 seconds for an elevator during my entire trip. The Sports Book was great also. I really liked that it didn't have the betting parlor feel. Also, the rooms were very quiet! Great job on soundproofing! At Encore, you could easily hear the conversations of your neighbors through the walls. The architecture was amazing throughout the property. We ate at Sirio during a very busy night. We all thought that the food was excellent.The service was above average, but not perfect. We also ate a few quite meals at the Sports Bar and I thought that the service was pretty good there, as well. I really liked the layout of the property. It was really easy to navigate around and didn't see TOO BIG like other places like MGM, Caesar's and even the Venetian. I had a car and the parking lot was a little bit of a walk, but not too bad. Parking was never a problem, really. There are always kinks to be worked at a new property, and I think that they heading in the right direction at Aria. Everyone was friendly and helpful, and I'd certainly recommend this property to others. All in all, I think it ranked right up there with my experience at Encore last year. i liked the "elegant feel" and the brightness of the Encore better, but I thought that my room was much better at Aria, and the service was a trade off at both places. I'd give this about a 4.5 rating, but I'll bump it to a 5 due to the newness factor. I think that Aria will only continue to improve.

Reviews.Title: “Eye Candy”
Reviews.Author: sandmanj
Reviews.Content: One of the attractions of Las Vegas for me has always been taking in the art and architecture of the most unusual city in the world. While extremely modern and urban in design, contrasting starkly with the themed character of most of the hotels on the strip, I must say I felt overwhelmed taking it all in. From the sculptures to the walls, ceilings, and even the floors, the surroundings inside the Aria is enough to take one's breath away. Unlike some here, I had no problems checking in or out or with anything not working in the room, and I have no complaints about the maid service. The rooms were very relaxing and comfortable. While many of the restaurants are pricey, I enjoyed some of the less expensive eats, including the buffet. The buffet was $20 and had a decent selection of food. Better than TI or the MGM but inferior to Bellagio and the Wynn. Only one complaint, but it's a big one. I like to play slot machines. I made a point of arriving the morning of the first Saturday it was open, December 19, and stayed for three nights on an internet offer of $149/night + $50 in gaming credits. While the new "Sex And The City" machines were a lot of fun and kept you going for quite some time, none of the other machines I tried (and I tried a lot of them) would pay off more than pennies on the dollar, if at all. I recall not too soon after the reincarnated MGM opened, back in 1995, there was a bank of new machines there called the "Majestic Lions" machines, and they were lit up like a Christmas tree with people standing in line to play them because they were paying out $200, $300 and $1,000+ jackpots continuously. People traveled to stay at the MGM from all over the planet just to play those machines. The phenomenon lasted for about 10 years, before they tightened up the payouts and the crowds of gamblers disappeared, now replaced with roving packs of very noisy young partiers who can't hold their liquor. What I can't fathom is that although MGM management was smart enough to know that good paying machines draw crowds and keep the hotel rooms full from 1995 to 2005, apparently whoever's in charge of the casino at the MGM-owned Aria never learned that lesson. And this is tragic. Because Vegas has been going through an enormous economic slump, worse than the rest of the country, for the past couple of years, the City Center billed itself as a means of pulling Vegas back into prosperity. Sadly, that simply cannot happen with a brand new cavernous casino full of slot machines that are tighter than a badly rusted water faucet. Such a shame. I'd hate to see it go under and start dragging the rest of Vegas with it. So next trip to Vegas I'll go back to staying at the Palazzo where the basic suite is 720 square feet, everything is new and beautiful, and where there are enough slot machines that pay out well enough to keep you going for days. Plus the rooms are comped due to my very enjoyable play there. My short-lived adventure at the Aria is now history.

Reviews.Title: “I should have stayed somewhere else”
Reviews.Author: michin1
Reviews.Content: Where do I start? Check in took forever and hardly anyone was even waiting in line. Air conditioner in room did not work, the room was about 85 degrees for 2 days straight until someone came up and attempted to fix it. Don't even bother calling the front desk from your room, waited 30 minutes for someone to answer before I gave up and just went downstairs only to wait another 15 minutes for assistance. Guest book directory service had all the pages ripped out of it. Stationary wasnt replaced before entering my room. Bell hop delivered someone else's bag to my room. In a nutshell, I would have been happier at circus circus. At least i would have paid less for the same garbage. If I had one word to describe the hotel, it would be overrated.

Reviews.Title: “Aria Hotel and City Center Las Vegas”
Reviews.Author: lifesabeach4me
Reviews.Content: Just visited the Aria Hotel in the expansive City Center complex in Vegas. They have only been open since mid-Dec but it was very busy Friday night. It's a great space with a beautiful entry, modern/artsy decor and a younger hip vibe. Great choice of restaurants and bars scattered amongst the casino level and on the promenade level. Had dinner at Sirio, an italian restaurant. Food was very good and staff was very helpful. We tried the Veal Marsala and the Gnocchi and both were excellent. Good wine selections too. Be sure to check out Crystals, the adjacent shopping complex - it's a work of art!! Will definitely go back to Aria and City Center.

Reviews.Title: “Feels like a coldbusiness hotel in Las Vegas?!”
Reviews.Author: QP
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Aria for 3 nights a week after its grand opening. Due to it's "newness", there were numerous problems/issues we encountered during our stay. Check in / Front desk - sometimes choatic due to lack of one single wait line. People simply lined behind one of the desks. No attendant to direct the flow. I was put on hold more than 30 mins a couple times I called front desk from my room. We eventually gave up and went downstairs and waited another 15 mins before getting someone's attention Interior/Decor - contemporary.. very un-las vegas like.. some may like it some may not. Room - decent size but not nearly as spacious as the suites at the Venetians/like. Furnishing/decor is minimalistic/contemporary, what you'd expect from an upscale business hotel. equipped with high tech control that manages all lighting/curtain, etc. Casino - no smell of smoke due to it's newness... Service - people were very courteous but front desk reps/managers lack problem solving skills, unable to answer basic questions Billing - A MESS! front desk unable to identify charges made to the room. Location - Centrally located on the strip, but it's tucked away on the inside of the Citycentre. It takes 10 min walk to go from hotel to the strip thru the Crystals (the shopping ctr) Overall - If you're willing to pay $$$ to stay in one of the top Vegas hotel, skip this one! The Wynn/Encore offers much better value, service and ambience. Aria didn't live up to its hype/expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Very good looking hotel, beautiful rooms.”
Reviews.Author: RvanDijk
Reviews.Content: Hotel looks very good. Modern, but in a cosy way. On the best place on the Strip, close to the greater Hotels/Casinos. Directions are rubbish though. The Guest Elevators are too far away from the hotel lobby, so don't take too much luggage...

Reviews.Title: “Go for the Newness, Stay for the Comfy Beds!!”
Reviews.Author: Mrs-MrA
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria January 1-3, 2010. We are travellers who try go with the flow and make the best of any situation rather than let things ruin our hard earned vacations. Check in was easy, had to wait for just one person in front of us. While our booked rate was good, we had to get our incentives through the Players Club and make a few phone calls at check out. Staff had a few problems coding our keys, so it took a few tries. I laughed and joked with the staff, talked about their growing pains and how their guests have been. Asked for a high floor. We received floor 53- a lovely view of the strip and Planet Hollywood. You can actually see the back view of the hotel at the end of each floor- would have been much better to have a back view of the mountains, Orleans, Palms, etc but we were still happy. The rooms were beautiful. When you walk in the room there are two closets. When you open each a light turns on. In the closet, there are suitcase racks in each. Loved this feature as you didn' t have open messy suitcases all over the room. (dont usually unpack much for such a short stay). The bathrooms were beautiful, lots of towels, and many fresh towels throughout our stay. Loved the shower/tub set up. No problems with water heat or pressure. On several of the reviews people mention toilets slow to flush. We found them to be no different than our low flow toilets at home. Loved the double sinks in the bathroom. There is only about 1 1/2 feet of counter space between the sinks, but there is a large drawer to put all your toiletries in so you don't have to use the counter. We had no problems with the room technology, loved it actually. The best part of the room was the bed. I could have stayed in bed the whole time we were there. It was loaded with pillows and light and airy bedding. Sheets could have been a little softer, but they were still great. Rooms were still clean, with some construction dust & muck in places. Having recently moved into a new house, we know not all is always sparkly and shiny and it is easy to miss the little areas still to be cleaned. We had read the reviews about long waits for valet. My husband would always go down a few minutes before and we never really had to wait more than 10 minutes. This resort is very expensive. Bottled water at the gift shop, $6. We ordered 2 coffees and two danishes from the Coffee Bean and it was $17. The only meal we had there was breakfast room service. Service was excellent and our breakfast arrived within 20 mins of ordering. Coffee was great, my husband's french toast was wonderful. I had egs benedict which was very tasty, but a little bit cold. Meal was $50. We didn't eat anywhere else in the resort as the reviews on food hadn't been too good. We found it a very long walk through Crystals to get to the strip. Once you were outside, it was a long walk to the pedway to cross to Planet Hollywood with many staircases. I would imagine there are future plans to have escalators. Just before we left we found it was very quick, simple walk to get to the Monte Carlo- which might be the better way to go. Would we stay there again? ABSOLUTELY!

Reviews.Title: “Aria: A Pleasant Stay”
Reviews.Author: jmh4me
Reviews.Content: My three-night stay at the Aria (part of City Center) From January 3 to 6 was very good. I had read several reviews about the Aria, some poor and some mixed, so I was a bit worried about how my stay would turn out. Fortunately, I had a very nice visit. It appears as though the hotel is trying very hard to work the kinks out, and in my opinion they are making very good progress. You don’t have to drive on the Strip to reach the Aria. From the airport have your taxi driver head west on Tropicana, then take a right at Koval and then a left at Harmon. Harmon crosses the Strip into City Center. The pleasant episodes started right away. I arrived at the Aria at noon on Sunday. I was second in the check-in line when an employee walked up and escorted me to an open line at the station reserved for guests of the casino. I checked in and went to my room right away even though the official check-in wasn’t until 3:00. You have to walk through the casino to get to the guest elevators, but the walkways are wide enough to accommodate large crowds. Smoke in the casino wasn’t too bad, but maybe that’s because there weren’t too many people playing when I was there. The casino is darker than most, as others have already noted. The dealers were very friendly. Security guards are present at all times to ensure that only guests showing room keys are permitted on the guest elevators. I was assigned a room on the 53rd floor, facing westward. Actually, it really wasn’t the 53rd floor because the elevator button for the 50th floor was right next to the 39th. (BTW, I never had to wait very long for an elevator, but there were a couple of ‘ghost floor’ episodes where two buttons lit up even though I only touched one button.) While walking to my room I passed a room with a working ice machine. My room key worked perfectly throughout the trip. I lightly tapped the room key on the sensor and heard the door unlock (no sliding the key in and out). Several things happened when I opened the door for the first time: the curtains opened, the lights came on, the 42” flatscreen TV turned on and displayed my name on the monitor, and the TV speakers filled the room with pleasant, upbeat music. I turned the music off, expecting to hear traffic noise from I-15. But to my surprise the room was very quiet. The bed was very comfortable! All room controls are accessible with a master touchscreen monitor on the nightstand. It takes some getting used to, so be patient. Once the TV is on, however, you can use its remote to navigate – it’s easier than the master panel – but keep in mind that there is about a one-second delay between pressing the remote and seeing the change take place on the TV. With two closets and plenty of hangars, there was easily enough space for a week’s worth of clothes. The in-room safe, which is located in the nightstand, was large enough for my 14” laptop but not deep enough for my mini-DV camcorder. Service prices are high like the other strip hotels – $13 for a hamburger on the room service menu, $15/day for internet in the room, $1/minute to use a computer in the business center (15-minute minimum), $4 for a 12-ounce can of soda in the minibar, etc. Speaking of the minibar, the minibar is touch sensitive – if you accidentally take something out of its place you have about 45 seconds to put it back or you will be charged. There is no extra room in the minibar’s refrigerator for personal items, so use the ice bucket supplied in the room. (Sorry, but I didn’t find out if the Aria charged a resort fee to use the health club.) The bathroom in my room did have an electrical outlet. I found it between the sinks behind the Kleenex box. And yes you do have to step through the shower to get to the tub, so I stood in the tub while waiting for hot water to reach the shower (didn’t take long). The shower head and bathroom mirrors were tall enough for me (I’m 6’ 3”). The shower head is one of those non-adjustable water-saving types, so not much water comes out and it will take you longer than usual to rinse the shampoo out of your hair. Housekeeping was OK in that my room was all prepared. On the second day they took the used bath mat and did not leave me a new one. On the third day they took the trash can out of the toilet area. They never emptied the melted water in the ice bucket. The housekeepers were friendly, just like the casino employees, especially if you spoke Spanish. I’m not a gourmet eater, so I never tried the Aria’s restaurants or buffet. A CVS pharmacy (open 24/7) is a short walk away, and they have a small but decent selection of snacks and groceries. I bought orange juice and yogurt, brought them to the room, and kept them cold in the ice bucket. Also, several fast-food and mid-priced family restaurants are just across the street. The day before check-out I visited the Aria’s business center, where they printed my boarding passes for free. When catching a cab to the airport, note that the taxi pick-up point is a couple hundred feet from the drop-off point. A sign will show you the way. Many employees asked me if I was enjoying my stay. This was a minor annoyance, but I suspect they’re being prompted my management because of all of the trouble they had after opening less than a month ago. Other minor annoyances about the room include no business stationary, no coffee pot, and no phone book. The Aria does not have much for the kids – a small video arcade, swimming pools and a good ice cream shop. If you like brown you’ll love this hotel – brown is everywhere! I think the Aria is putting more emphasis on upscale chic with high tech and less emphasis on elegance. So I wouldn’t call it a five-star. I wouldn’t mind staying here again, but I like the elegance of other five-star hotels on the Strip. All in all, though, I enjoyed my stay there.

Reviews.Title: “Don't go!!!”
Reviews.Author: Juanpedrom
Reviews.Content: I stayed there for three nights on January and had really high hopes and expectations as the hotel was brand new. I had three rooms. The good: Location and a quick check in. The bad: 1. Asked for adjoining rooms, got rooms facing each other. 2. One of the rooms main door didn't close, called front desk waited for an answer and after ten minutes gave up and went to the lobby to request a new room. 3. Phones in one of the rooms did not work. 4. Safe deposit boxes were locked. Had to get someone from maintenance to open them, with you waiting for them. The really bad stuff: 1. Robe in one of the rooms had used show tickets in them and was dirty. 2. Linens in bed had nasty stains, hopefully chocolate stains. 3. Bathrooms were very poorly serviced, to the extreme that at one point we had to call down housekeeping to have the rooms and bathrooms serviced. The staff was hillarious, when we called to report the dirty robe and linens the reply we got was "but the towels were ok, weren´t they". Distant apologies but lacked "customer service". Also the valet was so far off the main entrance that it made it totally useless as compared to parking the car by yourself. In terms of expectations, meaning new five star hotel on the strip, I believe this hotel is the worst in Las Vegas.

Reviews.Title: “Sleek and Modern but not the Vegas I know”
Reviews.Author: SeichanG
Reviews.Content: Stayed at Aria the last week of December through the Jan 2nd. This hotel is part of the massive City Center Complex, where it is connected to a brand new shopping center, a brand new Apartement hotels, Mandarin Oriental, and Private Residence Towers. The complex is impressive, tall, sleek, very modern. It will give you an impression of being in the middle of an urban jungle like Hong Kong or Tokyo. That said, it lacked the charm that other Vegas hotels like Bellagio, Caesars, Venetian, or the Wynn has. The decor is very minimal and industrial looking. My husband did love this hotel because of the high ceiling and the glass roof on some area. The room again is very modern. When the door opened, the window pannel automatically will open. Large and tall window have nice views of the strip. The bathroom though is not very attractive, cold brown marble and square shower. I personally love the Wynn the best, but again, my husband thought the Wynn is too ornate and stuffy. If you don't like the Wynn, you might love this new hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Hair Hair Everywhere; Service As Poor As Plumbing”
Reviews.Author: BoaterGirlKim
Reviews.Content: Aria is horrible. Five star is sooo much more than a pretty building or IT gadgetry - it starts and ends with service which is less than non-existent at Aria. I stayed over New Years from 12/30/09 to 1/3/10, solo woman traveler. Will add pics later; wanted to get a review up as quickly as possible since the place is new with a quick Aria vs. Encore comparison. Drop-off/check-in: The Gray Line shuttle that I booked as part of the Orbitz package drops you off at the back of the hotel, kind of like supplies being dropped off at a loading dock. A bellman met the shuttle bus, greeted me, took my suitcase and told me to call down once I got to my room. Check-in was fine at 11:45 p.m. The staff seem like kids practicing their manners instead of polished professionals like at Encore. I asked for a high floor with a strip view. The young lady told me I'd be happy with the view. Room #1: I get to room 26161. The room is on the back side of the building facing the front of Vdara with a view of Palms. After calling down about my bags, I scoped out the room and took some photos. The floor had small light-colored mud spots. I noticed that the door didn't close all the way behind me so I shut it. A rushing, wind-tunnel noise ensued, perhaps due to the concavity in building design and the fact that this room is in the center of the curve. I wasn't about to deal with lack of sleep due to wind noise, so I knew a room change was in order. However, 45 minutes after getting to the room, my bags still hadn't arrived. I called the bell desk and they suggested I COME GET MY OWN BAG as they were backed up. (HUH?? AM I AT MOTEL 6???) It was at 12:45 a.m. and I was tired due to a long flight from D.C. with flight delays, so I sucked it up. Once I got downstairs, I was told that I couldn't get the bag myself as luggage is stored downstairs, so I could wait downstairs at the bell desk or in the casino, or return to my room and wait. I told them that I would be changing rooms first and call back to let them know to which which room to deliver the bag. Room change: The 2nd front desk person is a man who asks me, "Is the noise really that loud?" (HUH?? I WALKED DOWN TO COMPLAIN ABOUT IT, DIDN'T I???) He gives me keys to room 26106 after complain about the boring Vdara/Palms view. He tells me that the keys to the old room should work but if not, to use one of the hallway house phones to call security. I got nervous about that having read a previous reviewer's comments about being told to call security and waiting in the hall for an hour. I was able to get in the old room, grab my stuff and head down the hall to the new room. Hair, hair, everywhere: I scope the new room, check out my strip view, then turn down the bed spread and sheets. There is HAIR, long HAIR in the sheets. There is also hair in the felt/velour headboard. This must be a popular room because the hotel has only been open 2 weeks but there are at least 2 different hair types - brunette hair in the sheets and red hair in the head board. Hey, at least they weren't curlies, right? No, that was in the BATHROOM. Okay, only 1 curly, the rest were more long brunette hairs. I called down to housekeeping. They said they would send someone right up. By 1:45 a.m. when my bag finally arrived to my room, I finally just said screw it as I was exhausted. The other side of the bed was hair free, so I curled up on that side and slept as still as possible for the night - yes folks, I slept in a bed with other people's hair in the sheets at this TOUTED 5-STAR HOTEL. The next morning when I went to flush the toilet, a synchronized fountain event happened - water bubbled up the drains of both sinks. The toilet also backed up and water filled to the bowl's brim. I called for plumbing. Housekeeping was making their rounds, so I snagged a maid and showed her all the hair and explained that all the sheets and pillowcases needed to be changed. Meanwhile, I had tried to no avail to get my iPod going using their "state-of-the-art" control panel. I had a team in the room - 2 plumbers, 1 maid, and an IT gal. I had actually asked if the plumbers could come in 2 hours so I could get dressed. They came in 30 minutes - maybe the secret prompt service at Aria is use reverse psychology. The hotel management knows that the plumbing problem is property wide, and according to staff, management/ownership believes that sabotage may have occurred during the building process as plumbers have been finding grout when they have snaked the toilets. It took the plumbers 2 hours to snake my toilet, and at one point they thought they might have to disassemble the toilet. The maid was doing her thing. No wonder the carpets are already spotted - they have these cheap vacuum cleaners that look like a toy you'd give a girl at Christmas, only old. And this is at a place that's been open 2 weeks. The IT lady admitted that clicking the TV's connectivity icon is supposed to make the control panel recognize that there is something connected, but neither the iPod connection nor the USB connection work and management/ownership realizes that they spent $X-million for these features that don't work and will never work. The work-around is to just use a simple audio plug from any Radio Shack, Best Buy, etc. and plug your iPod into their system. I called the front desk to suggest that they make all front desk staff aware of this non-functionality to prevent guests from waiting 1-1/2 hours for IT to show up as I had done. I asked for free Internet for the duration of my stay because of this, and they obliged. I had to call down to the front desk every day once the 24 hours was up so they could renew it. The New Year's Eve party at Gold Lounge was nice with Cirque performers doing acrobatics on the bars and open bar 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. No organized champagne toast, just a sudden 10!...9!...8!...while you were mid-sentence, unaware that the hour had come. I tried to get into Club Haze Saturday night after talking with concierge desk staff Friday and Saturday about what was happening club wise. I was told guest DJ David Guetta was spinning Saturday, cover $100 guys, $20 ladies. Not once did any concierge staff mention that I should or even could purchase an advance ticket, much less offer to make the arrangement. I got to the club at 1 a.m. after a night at the poker tables and the line was backed up to the escalator. I explained to one of the bouncers that I was a hotel guest and concierge didn't suggest or even state that I could buy in advance and asked if there was a way to pay extra money for fast entry. I was told I was out of luck and that actually the club is separate from Aria even though it is inside the building and I would have to wait like anyone else. I headed back up the escalator to the poker room. Checkout/leaving: check-out went quickly. As promised, there were no room charges for Internet. Leaving: walked out to the semi-circle where a door man was standing. Asked about cabs and he pointed to the other end of the semi-circle and said I had to walk over to the cab station. (HUH?? You can't radio/motion/whistle/holler for a cab for me??) Had I not been very close to missing check-in time for my flight, I would have voiced my parenthetical question but I didn't have 5 minutes to have the conversation. I drag 50-pound suitcase, guitar, and carry-on bag around the semi-circle in front of the Mandarin to get in a cab. SUMMARY I think I'll stop here as I've painted a thorough enough picture of how Aria's lack of readiness, cleanliness polish, service.... Here's an overall summary: Rooms: Pros - nice neutral decor, panoramic windows. Cons: DIRTY (for 2 weeks old). DARK. Myriad towels but only 2 washcloths.
