Never could get the fridge/wet bar code to work. Bar with the usual overpriced fare but also a technology pack for $20 with an assortment of cords for computer and iPod in case you forgot your own. Technology: Roll the dice as to what will work in your room. This was an important feature for me. I'm a technical writer and so my work is very portable. Another guest laughed that nothing worked in their room - the curtains, the lighting. I was fortunate and both the bedside control screen as well as the TV remote control worked fine; the iPod and USB issue was the only thing that affected me. Food: Restaurants were overpriced - didn't eat at any. Elements gift shop has beer for $4-6 dollars if you don't want to pay $7 from the wet bar (but oh yeah, mine didn't work). Pool: Didn't check it out as it was closed. Service: Non-existent. Run by newbies who are like high-schoolers working a part-time after school restaurant or retail job. I heard another guest extoll in a thick Jersey Shore accent: "This place is a friggin joke...I ain't never comin' back!" The Philly girl in me whole-heartedly agreed - that's right East Coast, represent! LOL. Poker room: NICE. Roomy, good drink service, chips brought to you, friendly staff. One or two have complained about the noise as it's right on the edge of the main floor. Wasn't a distraction for me. Location: Great. Too bad the hotel is despicable in every other aspect besides the poker room. Shame, because it's in the thick of things on the strip where I like to be. If all I cared about were location, I stay across the street at Planet Hollywood (another "never again" - stayed twice and both times was given 6th floor view of ventilation system for 1st room - even with the "$20 sandwich" and many staff are rude). VERDICT: - I will never stay at Aria again. - Encore vs. Aria: ENCORE. I stayed at Encore over Inauguration weekend to get away from the D.C. madness and it was PHENOMENAL. I'll deal with the small time drain of strip traffic and the stuffy Deuce or a pricey cab to get to the places I want to go. Encore's rooms are superior in size, polish, and comfort with brightness and mirrors galore. The staff are PHENOMENAL. From the moment my daughter and I checked in at Encore, staff made us feel like royalty. The employees there have a quiet confidence about them that isn't cocky; rather, it makes you feel like they know they have the best establishment and are ready to show you just how good it is. I'm ready for them to show me again, especially if it happens to be a romantic excursion (do NOT pick Aria if you're in wooing mode - nothing ruins romance like being ticked off having to complain). Anywhoo, that's where I'll be next trip so if you see me at Encore, holla atcha girl LOL.

Reviews.Title: “All Technology , NEW EDGE, NOT GOOD”
Reviews.Author: SherryLee15
Reviews.Content: My husband and I come to Las Vegas after Christmas every year. This year we were soo excited to come to the Aria. A new hotel, somewhere we have never been. The check in was great we arrived at the Hotel and 30 minutes later we were in our room. At first we thought this is awesome with the curtains opening on arrival and all the technology for all the lights TV locks, but then if you hit the wrong button you are screwed. For example if you hit the goodnight switch on accident, it will take you several minutes and attempts to correct it. Overall the room was fine, just keep your reading glasses handy. Kudos to the elevators, we stayed on 23rd floor and we never had to wait for an elevator and the hotel was full. I am not a complainer but lordy the buffet was the worst I have ever had. We are from Texas and love good food. But when they didn't have a big variety and no American food was served exept I did get some mashed potatoes with raw clumps of potatoes in them. At the buffet price (90.00 for two) us country folks would at least like cooked potatoes and cheese on the salad bar.

Reviews.Title: “What a Disappointment! Vacation Wasted!”
Reviews.Author: NMtravelerNewMexico
Reviews.Content: Our friend that goes to Vegas all the time recommended we try the Aria since she had a casino host that moved there. She told us the host was the best in Vegas and doubted they would work at a hotel that wasn't just the best. Well.......... from start to finish it didn't go well. Check-in was over an hour and we didn't get the rooms we asked for (adjoining with the other couple we traveled with). The rooms weren't ready until after 5PM and when we did get to our rooms, one hadn't been cleaned from the previous occupants. We had problems with our keys from time to time and housekeeping was not good. The paid no attention to "do not disturb". The rooms were nice, but smaller than expected and the technology wasn't the most user friendly. NOT worth the money. Casino was okay, but we played for over two hours without being offered a drink. I know this place is new and we should expect some gliches, but when everything was over with, we wasted over 10 hours of our vacation on problems and issues (we were only there for two days). Waiting around for things to be fixed or remedied does not make a happy vacation. I would not recommend this hotel to anyone right now. We told our friend who recommended the Aria how unhappy we all were. She had reservations for later this month and quickly cancelled them for another Vegas property. Even though we know the Hotel is new, we would never try it again. The staff appeared to be totally overwhelmed with all of the problems and had just given up trying to make people happy. ... A real shame since we all were so excited to try out this great new innovative hotel.

Reviews.Title: “You never get a second chance to make a first impresstion”
Reviews.Author: green_limes
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a two night stay at Aria from January 1st to 3rd. Visited with a friend. We are both women in our early 30’s. Aria is not a 5 star hotel. Rooms smaller than I expected and we had a few problems. When we first arrived, I decided to have a shower. The water was luke warm and the pressure was very low. Also noticed when we arrived that we had no drinking glasses in the room and the ice bucket was full of water from the previous occupants. I called house keeping to get a new ice bucket and four glasses – I got 2 glassed and no ice bucket. The next morning, at 9am, after a second luke warm shower, we got a knock on the door. It was house keeping. I asked them to return in about an hour. We left for the day, and returned to our room at 3:30pm to find it untouched – we called back before we went to dinner and were assured that someone would come. After dinner at 8:30pm, we returned to an untouched room. By the time someone came it was 9:30pm so just asked for towels. For our entire stay from Friday at noon when we checked in, until Sunday afternoon when we checked out, our room did not get cleaned. There are not a lot of options for food in the hotel. More casual dining is needed. We ate at two of the restaurants. Lemongrass (Thai) – My friend and I decided to share a couple of dishes. We ordered Vegetarian Spring Rolls, Vegetarian Pad Thai and Yellow Curry Chicken. The spring rolls did not have much flavor and the dipping sauce tasted like it was picked up from a grocery store – nothing special. The Pad Thai did not have much flavor either. Curry was tasty. Overall, I would not recommend. It is not as good as most Thai take-out restaurants in Toronto. Julian Serrano (Tapas) – Everything tasted great. Service was excellent. Be forewarned, portions were small even for Tapas. I had chicken croquets, pan tomate, chicken skewers, white fish ceviche, a dish or fried potato with aioli. The ceviche was the best part of the meal. Very flavorful and fresh tasting. Great place to relax with a cocktail and have a few bites. All of the staff at the hotel were extremely friendly, I just think it is poorly run. I would not stay at Aria again. Not worth it. Go to Caesars instead.

Reviews.Title: “Lots of "computer issues"”
Reviews.Author: Vegasclint
Reviews.Content: We checked in for two nights on Christmas day. Once we finally got valet to park the car, we faced a mob of about 200-300 people waiting to check in due to the "system being down." Staff was good in that they called me 2 hours later as promised, saying the system was fixed. Upon return to the hotel, had to wait 30 minutes to check in. The slots were also a mess that day, and everything was a "hand pay" if you cashed out. I saw this when walking through (every screen had hand pay---30 cents, etc), so we just went to Monte Carlo. Valet parking is a real problem with drop off and pick up being so far apart. However, we discovered that the back entrance valet is much more convenient IF you know Vegas well enough to negotiate the back roads to use it. The Elvis show is far from ready. We felt ripped off even at the "preview' price of $130 per ticket. Honestly, it was so busy in the food venues, we chose to eat at other places, but this is not a convenient place to come and go, as we like to do when in Vegas. We stayed the next 3 nights at the Venetian, and had a great time there. Maybe the place will get it together, but this will be the only visit for us. The rooms were nice, but too much techno stuff to fool with to get the TV to come on, etc. Give me Caesars, Wynn, Venetian, even the Mirage anytime over this one. I hope they get it together because it needs to succeed, but it has a ways to go.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel but a lot of little things left to finish!”
Reviews.Author: SamCoventry
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Aria Resort and Casino from 25 December to 31 December 2009. We were going to Vegas for Christmas anyway, but we got a fantastic deal on flights and hotel, hence why we decided to stay at the newest hotel on the strip! I don’t regret staying at the Aria because it’s nice to stay somewhere that’s all new and sparkling, but given my time over again I’d probably wait a year or so and that’s what I’d recommend if anyone were to ask me whether they should stay there or not? We expected teething problems; after all, it’s a multi billion pound resort with thousands of rooms, with everything new to everyone, staff included, so anyone visiting shouldn’t expect everything to be flawless. CHECK-IN - When we arrived on Christmas Day, the computer systems were down (something that can happen in any hotel at any time, so I was appalled at the attitude of guests towards the check-in staff, this wasn’t their fault and they moved as fast as they could at a busy time). What I couldn’t accept was the inadequate training the staff had obviously received. We never take credit cards to Vegas (for obvious reasons), paying our hotel bill up front through Expedia or Travelocity. We have been to Vegas six times previously and not once have we been asked to leave credit card details at check-in for ‘incidentals’. This time the lady on check-in told us that if we weren’t prepared to leave credit card details then we would have to leave a deposit of $130 per day!!! We know exactly what each dollar is for when we bring our money to Vegas and we have a certain amount for gambling, a certain amount for food and a certain amount for shows etc, to take any money off us would have messed all this up! Anyway, after a small argument the check-in lady brought across her manager who immediately stated that this was incorrect and that we didn’t have to pay anything, all extras would just be deactivated from our room i.e. we wouldn’t be able to choose ‘pay-per-view movies’ or pay for internet access etc. All fine by us, you don’t come to Vegas to watch TV! What did annoy me is that whilst we were checking in (which took us over an hour) all the managers were just standing back and watching their staff mess things up. Perhaps if they were training them properly in the first place, there would have been fewer arguments at check-in, meaning fewer mistakes to clear up! ROOMS - Once we were finally checked in, we found our room pretty easily, through the casino to the guest elevators which is pretty standard in most Vegas hotels. Our key card worked first time and we didn’t have any problems with this throughout the duration of our stay. The room itself was fine. In my opinion, nothing special, the king size bed was standard size for Vegas, although the room itself was fairly small, definitely not as large as the room we had at the Mirage, earlier in the year. The technology was pretty hi-tec but an idiot’s guide on how to work it would have been helpful, if you pressed the wrong buttons you found yourself in complete darkness with the curtains closed! If you wanted to attach your ipod to the TV, then you had to purchase the accessories kit, whereas at the Mirage they have an ipod docking station which you can use for free! The bath and shower were fine and with reference to what someone previously stated, the shower is more than powerful enough! What did surprise me was that for a hotel which is supposed to be ‘green’, there is no plug for the sinks, so when my husband had a shave he just had to leave the water running – an oversight??!! I agree that there are not enough electrical sockets in the rooms, the only ones I could find (apart from the two in the bathroom which were inconveniently positioned) were two by the door. Housekeeping left a lot to be desired, for a hotel that had only been open for nine days, I expected everything to be immaculate. However, I found black hairs on the side of the bath and on the toilet floor, plaster dust in the entrance hall, which was still there the day we left and dried in concrete/cement in the carpets! Being fully booked is no excuse for poor housekeeping! Just an aside, when we first got into the room we couldn’t find the safe which I was beginning to get angry about until I discovered it in the nightstand in the lower drawer! FOOD – I can only comment on the buffet, Cafe Vettro and Jean Philippe’s patisserie as we didn’t dine anywhere else within the hotel. We used the buffet twice for brunch and found it more than satisfactory. Although not the Bellagio standards, there was more than enough choice to fill us up and keep us going until evening. Cafe Vettro is poor. They are trying to be more than they are and are trying to create upper class dining which isn’t working. In my opinion they should stick to what their name states and just serve cafe food instead of trying to be pretentious! Even in cheap and cheerful eateries, plates aren’t cleared until everyone has finished eating but here my husband’s plate was taken away before I was even half way through my meal– the height of bad manners and again this comes down to a training issue. The menu is limited, in fact there was only one thing on the whole menu that I wanted and I’m not a fussy eater so we could only eat there once! We were seated down a ramp overlooking the walkway to the Vdara and it was freezing cold, if they want to keep their customers they need to do something about the heating! Jean Philippe’s patisserie was to die for, I tried the ham and cheese croissant one morning, which was delicious, as was the cherry danish and the ice cream (gelato). Definitely worth a try. There needs to be a few more casual eating places within the City Center complex, saving you having to walk out onto the strip if you don’t want to pay $50 for a meal! CASINO – I actually enjoyed playing the slots in the casino and found them quite ‘friendly’. I won $1000 in my first hour of playing there! The only thing I found was that considering all the reviews stating that smoke will be drawn down into filters at the base of slot machines, I went back to my room each night reeking of cigarette smoke! Even my husband who is a smoker, complained about the smell of stale cigarette smoke each morning in the casino and this is something I have never experienced in any other casino on the strip. The casino is definitely smaller than many others on the strip but because of this appears friendlier and it doesn’t take long to be able to find your way around. There was never a lack of cocktail waitresses asking if you needed a drink, although the strawberry daiquiri’s which we both became addicted to varied depending on who made them. Sometimes they were creamy and out of this world but at other times it was just like eating coloured ice, with no flavour! SHOWS – We planned to use our Christmas money to book and see the Elvis show and it was money well spent. I’m not an Elvis fan but everyone recognises the music and we both loved it. No so much Cirque stuff as some of the other shows and a lot more singing and dancing but great fun and well put together. They are still previewing the show so expect a few basic errors but this is what previews are for and this is why you pay the discounted price. Definitely recommend it and we are now planning a trip to Graceland! The whole City Center is not finished and from what I’ve heard they had to rush to open it so that they could begin making money and you can tell! There is no colour anywhere on the outside, just a lot of concrete and if that’s the way it’s going to stay then I’m not impressed! Aria is set a long way back from the strip and we found it was a lot quicker to nip out of the North Valet entrance, along to Vdara and up the walkway to Bellagio and was also quicker than waiting for the tram. The Crystals is nowhere near finished and my first impressions were ‘what a waste of space’! So overall, would I stay at Aria again? Yes, definitely, but will I? Probably not for a long time. If there weren’t so many other hotels in Vegas that I hadn’t stayed at then, yes, I’d definitely stay at Aria but I want to stay at Wynn, Encore, Bellagio, Venetian and Mandalay Bay so that will cover a few more years!!!

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel but will not go again.”
Reviews.Author: VancouverC63
Reviews.Content: I was there on Christmas Day. There was a long wait for check in since their computer broke down. The staff are really nice and we were in our room in 2 hours after landing in Vegas. I was asking for slippers from house keeping, i phoned them at 12am i have been waiting until 2am in the morning and no one came. The next day i told house keeping to drop me the slippers in my room and they did it. That is a +. The phones were down on the secound day and we cannot phone in or out, asked housekeeping and they told me the whole building's phone system was down OMG. We went to the buffett it was fair not very good and not very bad don't need to go again. Overall i will not live in this hotel anymore, I have lived in Ceasar, Bellagio, Venetians, MGM. This is the worst of all. Sorry to say maybe i will go back in a couple years.

Reviews.Title: “View Bar - $20 a drink RIP OFF”
Reviews.Author: venicemermaid
Reviews.Content: Stopped in at the View Bar for a cocktail. No drink menus on the tables. Slow service. Ordered two well drinks and the check was $40.00. I don't care who you are or how much money you might have, that is just a blatant RIP OFF!

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Marvelous!”
Reviews.Author: CarolRizzie
Reviews.Content: Stayed four days over Christmas. Loved everything about it. It was so enjoyable that everytime we left the hotel we could not wait to get back. Easy to get around, Julian Serrano's is wonderful, fabulous buffet, room was perfect and staff could not have been more gracious and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Needs to work out the kinks...big time.”
Reviews.Author: kukiemama
Reviews.Content: The Aria is not ready for show time. It is a nice looking hotel...and that is it. The staff have not had adequate training. We checked in at 3:30pm with another family of 4. We were supposed to have rooms on the same floor...after a lot of run around and OUR time wasted, we did not get into our rooms until 9:00pm. At dinner, my friend had a shard of thick plastic in her salad at the cafe. They comped the salad. Our rooms were so far from the elevator, it took a good 10 minutes to get to them from the casino. No cell service, because ATT and Verizon have not been paid. To top it off, even with the privacy light on,housekeeping promptly knocked on our door at 9 am...woke us up...twice. That was the only time we saw them other wise service wasn't until 5 in the evening. Well.. you catch my drift. Don't waste your time. Wait a year. They did comp us $500 for food because of the inconveniences. Still wasn't worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Good service, Just average hotel”
Reviews.Author: kittybat
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Aria for 3 nights over Christmas mainly due to a good price deal on the internet, however I really wish we had just stayed longer at the Bellagio. Firstly i would like to say all staff we dealt with were more than helpful despite some other reviews saying not so. We did however think there should have been more on certain areas. Our room was small, and on entering the lobby part the floor was covered in builders debris and dust, no coathangers in wardrobe a call to House keeping sorted these points out. We were surprised at how small the bathroom was with very little counter space for any products and a badly placed electrical socket. The seperate WC is really seperated by a glass door and wall so if you like your privacy you have to shut 2 doors one being a really odd heavy sliding door then the glass door. Our phones stopped working one day unfortunately it was the day our next door neightbour was playing really loud bass heavy dance music..... The next night it happened again, so as our phones were working we phoned front desk who promptly said we could move rooms. In the meantime they sent security up and when they came the music was so loud they didn't hear them knock! The room we were sent to hadn't been cleaned so we had to go back down to front desk again to try for another room which thankfully was fine. This all took several hours needless to say we were due to check out next day and was the first time I have been glad to leave a hotel in Vegas. I would not stay here again, it feels like a London city centre hotel, fine but has none of the charm of many older Vegas hotels. Most of the public areas feel like an airport, and the casino is way too dark. We also experienced the ghostly pressing of random elevator floor buttons, I don't think its a bad hotel just not a very interesting one maybe in a few months time it will be okay.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid the spa - unless you like blaring CNN like at an airport!”
Reviews.Author: TigerMama12
Reviews.Content: Yuck. The entire design and plan of colors and amenities ruined by the not only one but two huge TVs blaring - one CNN and the other some trashy hillbilly reality show. Again I say Yuck. What is the point of going to a spa? To relax in quiet. I've never been to a noisier spa. Even the house music was too loud - even in the steam rooms. The worst crazy thing about this spa was there were absolutely NO towel or robe hooks. Now think about this...in the shower we had to hang our towel and robe over the door, change room set towels and clothes ON THE FLOOR!?! The spa may be fantastic - when its finished, but now, forget it.

Reviews.Title: “Do not stay here- it's a mess”
Reviews.Author: daisychui
Reviews.Content: Rooms clean but small. Shower pressure weak. it took me 1 hour 25 minutes to get items from housekeeping from a call since 12am. The staff were Well mannered and kept apologizing but giving the excuse that they only have 3 staff at night for housekeeping seriously worried me as this is clearly not enough for a 4000 room hotel and is not an excuse for such bad service delays. I gave 6 chaser calls and each time they said they would follow up but didn't until my final one70 minutes after my initial request. Really ridiculous n unacceptable. Las Vegas is an international city and this hotel shouldve been a lot more prepared for international guests. They did not have international voltage transformers for electrical appliances And after 2 clear requests although the staff were friendly they only brought me an adaptor which is not what I asked for! Soundproofing is also bad you can hear sirens from the 50+ floors. I only stayed here as encore and wynn were fully booked. I've stayed at those before and everything is perfect. You're in Vegas- with so many hotels to choose from u don't need to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Service, and feels like an airport terminal.”
Reviews.Author: r998
Reviews.Content: Yea its design is terrible, I feel like im still at an airport terminal when I arrived to check in. Way to go to make it feel like a "resort". First off, it seems very modern from the outside, but no where near the 5 star service by all means. Walking around the "crystal" shopping center lead us multiple "Dead ends" why would they design that? 2nd, We ate at 2 restaurants at Aria and both were terrible. Sirio (Italian) was not worth the price at all, the calamari was the worse I have ever tried in my life. Shabu Shabu was way toooo overpriced for low quality food. Casino: Wow talk about a dark closet. Its terrible, so bad its hard to see where your walking because of the ultra dark decor and lighting. Its a maze to get around and no way feels like a 5 star warm hotel. We checked out of Aria ASAP and transferred to other MGM group hotel Bellagio. I aslo recommend staying away.

Reviews.Title: “Aria: Achoo!”
Reviews.Author: phatwiley
Reviews.Content: First hotel to open in LV, "City Center." Ultra modern, straight lines, high ceilings, steel, and glass. Upon entering, there is an aroma infused into the air that was rather unpleasant, but, when the cigar, and tobacco smoke fill your nostrils, you will be happy for the other aroma. Lotta smoking going on. Because of the newness, there is a, "newness," energy with staff that is better understood with your stay. Takes more than 10min for front desk to answer. Request for luggage pick up was right on time! The rooms are completely computerized - TV, lights, curtains, all work from either TV remote or nightstand, "clock." If you mistakingly press the wrong button, the room goes dark, the curtains close/open, and you play hell trying to turn everything on again! lol The best thing, is the Patisserie-when you're in the area, you will see a crowd and not be able to know why - people are buying wonderful gelatos, expressos, sweets, and eating them in the seated area. This hotel is brand, spanking new - give them 6-9 mos. to get the rhythm in sinc - pass on all the food, you will be disappointed; Aria, Achoo! Oh! The bed was comfortable. "Necessary," items that are in the bathrooms, i.e.bath salts, mouth wash, sewing kit, lotions, gels. No coffee maker! Would I stay there again? Probably in the summer or 2010. Great photo ops, have wonderful water features.

Reviews.Title: “Novice Operators!”
Reviews.Author: Jehangard
Reviews.Content: Well, the building is monumental and if anything the level of the technology involved in each and every corner of the rooms and amenities is impressive, BUT, the people who are supposed to provide the services to you are not trained properly and almost nobody that I came across there was really ready to operate this huge machine. From the sommeliere who was not familiar with the wine list, to the dealer at the table who was not familiar with the pay offs! Sounds like the owners did not spend adequate time to properly train their staff and some sort of "learn as you go" strategy is taken up. I felt that they did not care about the type of service that I was getting there and they were only thinking to make it operational ASAP to start cashing out! It is a shame and reveals the mentality of the management. Give them a good 6 months time to get their act together and become able to provide you with the service that you deserve and you are paying for.

Reviews.Title: “It's coming around but still not yet ready”
Reviews.Author: MarkDC-Travel
Reviews.Content: Nice check-in, Bell staff, dealers and drink service. I have no doubt that this will be one of the best hotels on the strip as soon as they get the bugs worked out. Still problems with computers including hand pay of 25 cents! Phones not working sometimes and other materials not yet in place. I stayed in the Aria standard room 27-119 – Wow, very impressive. You should have already read about the electronics in the room so I will not get into that but I will say that Aria has set a new standard. The amount of space was fine. This hotel still has a lot of bugs to work out. It will probably take up to 6 months to a year before the hotel runs without major issues. What’s a major issue? How about computers going down and the telephone not working? The Entertainment Guide was empty. Staff at check-in were professional, helpful and polite. Bell desk was also really good. Room had a very large flat panel that generated lot of heat. This was very close to the thermostat. The result was a chilly room that I had to keep adjusting the temperature. At one point, I had to set it at 82 degrees to get the room to feel like 72 degrees. On a brighter note, the hotel that has extensive cable TV options as well as Hi Def. One of the few hotels with Hi Def on the strip. Others have the monitors, but few pay for the cable signal. The bed was a feather-top and oh so very comfortable. Had the phone been working on my first night, I would have ordered coffee the next morning. Had to wait until the second morning for that. Coffee was my first order of room service which came quickly and hot. Robes and slippers are provided. They also have a turndown service. Having traveled extensively overseas for my work, I admit that I have grown accustomed to such services. Although I had to go in search of a laundry bag and ticket (the housekeeping person said they did not have them for my floor yet), these were found without much effort at the Bell desk. Laundry was expensive compared to others on the strip - undergarments $3.25/ea, long sleeve shirt $11.00/ea, trousers $11.50/ea. All in all, I give this room 9.5 out of 10. Had to bring laundry to the bell desk since the phone was not working. The cafe provided a wonderful breakfast of steak & eggs. The beef melted in my mouth, Yummy! Casino was very busy, with lots of energy. Hot slots (got a $5,000 hand pay – sweet) and great dealers. Had a lot of fun here and saw several large hand pays during the course of one night. Perhaps at the cost of other MGM properties, I think the Aria hotel/casino is performing as hoped for MGM.

Reviews.Title: “The Aria is wonderful - we loved it!”
Reviews.Author: Sunflower0840
Reviews.Content: Just got back from staying at the Aria and it could not have been better, the room was amazing and the service was impeccable. I cannot understand some of these reviews as we were treated wonderful and everyone there from the buffet to the gift shops were the most pleasant I have experienced. I even forgot my curling iron and they literally led me directly to one. The Buffet is fantastic and Michael Mina's American Fish was delicious. My only complaint about the hotel was Jean Goerges steak house, for the money the portions were small and plain. Viva Elvis is one of the best shows in Vegas, comparable to Love at the Mirage. We had absolutely no problems with check in or our room, when we went to breakfast our room was clean when we got back. Very very beautiful hotel and wonderful service, we had an excellent vacation!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Simply stunning - Lived up to its hype!”
Reviews.Author: flagtraveler31
Reviews.Content: On December 17th, I received an email promotion for the Aria. After having read quite a bit and watched Vegas news clips from opening night, my wife and I excitedly reserved a room Dec. 27th-29th. It lived up to all the hype!!! We scored a basic king room on the 53rd floor with magnificent views of the desert and snow capped mountains to the west. What sunsets and sunrises. We could have stayed in the room the whole time and it would have been worth it! A beautiful flat screen TV with all High Definition channels. The bathroom has a separate shower and soaking tub! Setting the computer controls for the TV, curtains and lighting took a few minutes to figure out but it was pretty easy. WiFi was 15 dollar daily rate. We happily skipped this fee and were free of email for three days! The casino was easily the nicest I've seen in Vegas as you could actually see the light of day! We also rarely smelled cigarette/cigar smoke that we knew surrounded us and did not smell like smoke when we returned to the room. We did wait in line to check in, but it only took about 20 minutes and for the thee days we never saw more than 3 people in line. The staff were all friendly and helpful. I particularly enjoyed the Sports Book with its very intimate layout and low keyed atmosphere. The cocktail waitresses kept the drinks flowing in the litle time we spent in the casino. We had two outstanding dinners at the Italian Sirio and American Fish. At Sirio, my wife had the ravioli and I ordered the Shrimp Gnocchi. While the ravioli was good, the gnocchi was the best I've had. Very tender and smaller pieces than normal. The staff was super friendly and took time to chat with us. They really seemed excited to be there. The same was true of American Fish. My wife had steak and I had rock salt baked scallops. The waiter took my on a tour of the kitchen and explained how they grill the scallops in the salt. The dinners were about $120 including tip. Not too bad. We did have sticker shock at the $64 buffet and turned around and hit the street as we could see a McDonald's on the strip across from the Casino! We then found some great breakfast/lunch deals on the strip and decided that in the mornings we'd hit the strip for cheap food and drinks, and spend out money on the fine restaurants in the Casino. We enjoy playing draw poker, but had much better luck on the slots in small bars/restaurants on the strip than in any of the Casinos!!!! So we both give a big thumbs up to Aria! Well done!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Can Probably Do Better”
Reviews.Author: Theate3541
Reviews.Content: There is plenty to like at this mammoth new Las Vegas resort, plenty for them to improve on (namely in service aspects – which I won’t get into since the hotel is only 2 weeks old, so that’s kind of not fair), and a bit to go “huh, why did they do that.” Here’s my summary: Likes: 1) There are plenty of decent restaurant choices (and Sage is fantastic, easily one of Vegas’ best). No matter what kind of food you are in the mood for, most likely there is a place that will satisfy your craving. 2) The whole “urban center thing” is pretty cool. Granted, it isn’t the real NY, but what it aims to be is quite interesting, and definitely worth a look at, even if you don’t stay here. 3) The rooms are very high-tech, so if you’re someone who values staying a place where one control can run your entire stay, this isn’t a bad choice. Huh?: 1) The rooms are pretty small by Vegas high end standards (Encore rooms are 750 sqft, these are 520). This can become an issue, especially if a group would like to share a room. 2) That high-tech control panel thing is a better idea on paper than in reality. Frankly, I can pull my own curtains, so flipping through four menu pages to get the job done doesn’t interest me that much. 3) The mini-bar has a “technology kit” they sell for $20 that includes an Ethernet cable and an iPod docking cable. Hysterically, they list it as a “souvenir,” so all of you that are wondering what to get your friends from Vegas – how about an internet cable? 4) The spa is massive, but not that relaxing. For example, there are four whirlpools, but all of them are the same temperature. The steam room – barely steamy. The sauna, half broken (after two weeks). In addition, there are zero robe hooks throughout the men’s locker room, so you are forced to walk in a towel and leave your robe in the locker. Though these are relatively petty points, they are several of many (and who wants to deal with these kinds of things in a Vegas spa when there are so many nice ones out there). 5) Though the hotel is brand new, the carpets don’t look that clean in the rooms. This may be due to their color (a dark brown) that isn’t that forgiving, but in any respect, not what you’d love to see in a hotel room. In sum, Aria isn’t bad, but there are probably nicer places to stay in Vegas for the same money. Personally, I’d rather go to Wynn, Encore, or the Four Seasons (all of which can be had for roughly the same rate, depending on the dates you are looking for).

Reviews.Title: “Still some issues”
Reviews.Author: MartyMcFry
Reviews.Content: Stayed here on the 26-28th of December. First room that I got had the fire alarm chirping (I think it does that because the batter needs to be replaced). I called front desk and no one answered for over 30 mins so I gave up. I called Concierge and they said they'd call some engineers to look at the issue. No one showed up for 2 hours so I gave up and just went down to the front desk to complain. Got moved to a second room but this time the air conditioner didn't work! Again no one answered when I called front desk so I had to go down in person. Front desk said they would call facilities but didn't have give a time frame. Considering it was around bed time and no one showed up for 2 hours to fix the fire alarm.. I didn't expect the air conditioner to be fixed any time soon, so I requested for another room. Finally everything in the room worked. Around midnight I called housekeeping (pushed the housekeeping button on the phone) for slippers. Housekeeping said they didn't know how long it would take because they couldn't contact anyone in housekeeping..whatever that meant! They also said that if no one answered the door that they would leave the stuff I requested at the door. Anyway.. again 2 hrs pass and nothing and by then I was asleep. Next thing I know, I get a call and am told that someone is outside with my slippers! First off, I was told they'd leave the slippers outside. Secondly, I had the Privacy light on my door. I couldn't believe it! Front desk is a pain to talk to since they don't answer the phones, and it takes forever just waiting in line to talk to one of them. Overall the rooms did look nice and modern. The "smart rooms" are nice to have but it's definitely slow.. especially when controlling things through the TV. The casino area was a little too dark for me and I prefer the casino area of the Bellagio. As for the food, Sage was a pretty decent place to eat. The servers were friendly and courteous. Cafe Vettro had horrible food and slow service. Jean Philippe's was great. I love their gelato. So definitely lots of things still need to be worked out on the hotel side. When the bell hops asked how my stay was, I told them what I've been through and none of them seemed surprised.. as if they've heard a similar story plenty of times in the past 2 weeks. I say give it a couple more months or maybe next year before giving Aria a try.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful ambiance and attention to detail”
Reviews.Author: Bluskyla
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria Christmas night. This hotel seems to be a great one to stay at, but the entire time we were there, the computers were plagued with problems. I would give it 4-6 months before I would stay there again. We waited to check in for 1 hour because there was only one printer working for 15 check in stations. The rooms were amazing and we figured that would override the long wait to check in. To our dismay, the touch screen operation of the entire room would not open the curtains. The rooms are entirely controlled by computer, this includes temperature, curtains, TV, lighting and sound as well as the privacy settings. Everything worked by the curtains. It was an amazing view after we lifted them and climbed in behind them. While sitting in the room, the computer would randomly change the lighting pattern. That night when we crawled into bed, it was by far the best hotel bed I have ever slept in. As you slid in, it was almost as if the bed just surrounded you and hugged you into it. Also, when in the elevators, randomly certain floors would light up and then the elevator stop at those floors as if a ghost had pressed the button. We were able to wander around the hotel, and it is really beautiful. There was great attention to detail taken for many parts of it. We also did try the buffet, which I would rate up there with Bellagio and Mirage. All in all, the stay turned out to be really comfortable. The staff was really excellent and seemed to roll with all the punches the computers could dish out. I would stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “An Absolute Disaster....”
Reviews.Author: Casablancalily99
Reviews.Content: Aria was clearly not ready for prime-time.....we are frequent travelers to Las Vegas and stay at Bellagio, THE Hotel, etc. We arrived Christmas Day for what we had planned to be a three-night stay. We checked out after one night! NOTHING worked. It took an hour to check in and get our room, which caused us to pass on dinner so we could make it on time to the Elvis show. After the show, we selected the sushi restaurant, BarMasa, in the hotel. The restaurant was freezing cold; I had to go back up to my room to put on my long winter coat in order to dine. Guests were shivering and the management simply said - yes, it was cold in here yesterday too. (Why not fixed then?) Very overpriced menu for fine - not great, not imaginative, and not generous - sushi. Up in the room, we discovered that the extremely loud bathroom exhaust fan would not turn off. It is by now 10:30 pm. After being placed on hold and passed around at the front desk, no one could give advice on how to fix this problem. Finally they offered to send up Maintenance, which we declined, saying it was too late and we were just going to go to bed. We explicity said DO NOT send anyone. At 1:30 am, after being fast asleep for two and a half hours, there is pounding at our door. Two maintenance workers who had JUST received the repair call at 1:30 am! We sent them away. Next morning, as we prepared to order room service breakfast, none of the three phones in the room functioned. I had to use my cell phone to call the reservations line and get to a person at the front desk who told me that the entire hotel's phone system was down for more than an hour, but they "were working on it". We checked out and moved to the lovely, well-functioning , brand new Rush Tower at the Golden Nugget and salvaged our vacation. Incidentally, as we were checking out, the party in front of us in line were also complaining because their toilet would not stop flushing all night (!?!?) Clearly, Aria rushed to open in order to get the holiday business and satisfy debt-holders and stockholders. Systems were not checked, redundancy systems were not in place, and basic levels of service could not be ensured. A disaster of a place.

Reviews.Title: “MIssed the mark - major miss”
Reviews.Author: hmogod
Reviews.Content: Having experienced several oher casino hotel openings at this stage, Aria missed the mark. Staff is still trying to learn computer systems and there does not appear to have been any upstaffing for the learning curve. Wait time at registration was excessive and almost every registration required involvement of supervisor. Computer system crashes are common and from what staff says - daily. Buffet - joke - more like what you get offstrip than other major properties Spa - gym was fine but locker room lacks any attendants. They stay at the front desk and don't check in the back to offer service. Room Service - slow and way overpriced for what is delivered. Room computer - come on - $20 for a serial computer cable plus cost of service. Of course during my stay the room internet was not working so blew that $20. Staff spend all day telling me someone was coming to fix it only to find out 5 hours later that it was hotel wide Room electronic control is wired with cable so short you cannot lift it off the night stand Room elevators are all bunched into one hallway so security can pretend to see keys. massive conjestion the way they designed this area forcing people into each other to get through because there was no open area designed to wait on others. Biggest issue - cell phone dead zone in the middle of the casino.

Reviews.Title: “Innovative design, issues with service”
Reviews.Author: Viktor47
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Aria hotel for 5 nights, starting on opening night. Check-in was an ordeal, as they did not provide any line markers, so people were wandering in and cutting people off inadvertantly, as you couldn't really tell where the line was. We got up to our room and within 2 minutes had hotel security at our door telling us that we had to leave immediately as someone else had booked our room for the night. (Not exactly a nice start) We ate dinner at Julian Serrano and had a wonderful time - - great staff and great food! (We considered going to the Thai place but found it to be very expensive) The next morning, housekeeping was knocking on our door shortly after 9:00, despite our "privacy please" light being on. We stopped for breakfast at the Jean Philippe patisserie which was overpriced and the service was terrible. It took at least 10 minutes to get 2 lattes and one pastry, and even then they gave us a different pastry than the one we ordered! Concierge was hit and miss - - one woman (Barbara) was amazing and booked 5 things for us while my wife talked to another woman who took 15 minutes to print off one map. Self parking was clearly marked but one night they had staff blocking it off and pointing everyone to valet (causing a huge backup). We did a U turn and went into self parking anyway and found tons of spots - no idea why they were blocking it off. Our room was not cleaned at all one day, another day they only gave us one bath towel. When my wife called to ask for another, they said "Oh so you want a second towel??" like she was asking for something unreasonable. We only got turndown service one night, which was disappointing as at Caesar's and Bellagio the housekeeping service was marvelous. At checkout, the man helping us was most apologetic about our housekeeping issues but since we had booked through Expedia, he said that he couldn't give us a discount on the room. Overall pros: Beautiful new space, innovative design, quiet rooms, interesting artwork Overall cons: Dark casino, staff in need of a lot more training, lack of informal / inexpensive lunch options We would go back to Bellagio or Caesar's Palace instead of going back to Aria.

Reviews.Title: “Nice but needs improvement”
Reviews.Author: yeecheng
Reviews.Content: I understand this is a new hotel but they need to improve their check in AND check out procedures. Check in was horrible (long lines) and the some of the managers were just standing in the back smiling and talking to themselves while their workers were dealing with hostile guests trying to check in. Their express checkout (via tv) was not working so checking out was also a nightmare. Maid service was inconsistent. Got one bar of soap and several boxes of sea salts on the first night (of the three nights we stayed). When we asked for more soap, we got more sea salts instead (the boxes looked the same). They removed one of the robes and never replaced with another one. They could have easily left the ones we had in the room. Another problem is their self parking! It was always at capacity but they designed the parking structure so that there are so much space between each car (those spaces could have been used for more parking spaces). I love wide parking spaces but those were ridicuously wide (another car could easily parking in that space). Finally, their buffet was not up to par (as compared to say Belligio). It costed $27.00 but the food was similar to other $15.00 buffets. Not much choices and the quality was only so so. Overall, I would come back to this hotel after they work out the kinks.
